treatment_desc: Patient asked to make eye movements or exposed to bilateral tones or tapping while recalling traumatic events, with focus on most recent traumatic events with an extended time perspective.
citation: Acarturk C, Konuk E, Cetinkaya M, et al. The efficacy of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among Syrian refugees: results of a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2016 Sep;46(12):2583-93. doi: 10.1017/S0033291716001070. PMID: 27353367.

treatment_desc: Patients not allowed to receive any treatment through 5-week followup period
citation: Acarturk C, Konuk E, Cetinkaya M, et al. The efficacy of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among Syrian refugees: results of a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2016 Sep;46(12):2583-93. doi: 10.1017/S0033291716001070. PMID: 27353367.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007
citation: Acierno RE, Knapp RG, Tuerk PW, et al. A non-inferiority trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: in person versus home-based telehealth. Behav Res Ther. 2017;89:57-65. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2016.11.009. PMID: 27894058.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007
citation: Acierno RE, Knapp RG, Tuerk PW, et al. A non-inferiority trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: in person versus home-based telehealth. Behav Res Ther. 2017;89:57-65. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2016.11.009. PMID: 27894058.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT with patients constructing a detailed chronological account of his/her biography, with particular attention on traumatic experiences. Therapy aims to reorganize fragmented report of traumatic experiences into a coherent narrative with details about current and past emotional, physiological, cognitive, and behavioral reactions.
session_length: NR (session continues until trauma-related fear reaction shows a significant diminution; mean session length was 108 [SD 17.0] minutes)
def_treatment_completion: did not drop out of treatment
citation: Adenauer H, Catani C, Gola H, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for PTSD increases top-down processing of aversive stimuli -- evidence from a randomized controlled treatment trial. BMC Neurosci. 2011 Dec 19;12:127. doi: 10.1186/1471-2202-12-127. PMID: 22182346.

Adenauer H, Catani C, Gola H, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for PTSD increases top-down processing of aversive stimuli -- evidence from a randomized controlled treatment trial. BMC Neurosci. 2011 Dec 19;12:127. doi: 10.1186/1471-2202-12-127. PMID: 22182346.

treatment_desc: Sequences of large-magnitude, rhythmic saccadic eye movements while holding in mind the most salient aspect of a traumatic memory. (As described in: Shapiro F. Eye movement desensitization: a new treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 1989 Sep;20(3):211-7. PubMed PMID: 2576656.)
citation: Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

treatment_desc: Patients wore glasses during sleep that possess sensors with the ability to detect infrared waves that during the rapid eye movements (REM) period and which activates a musical instrument which delivers a light music
citation: Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

treatment_desc: Ten tDCS sessions delivered to the right (cathode) and left (anode) dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, with brain areas localized using EEG, over 10 consecutive weekdays
session_length: 20 minute treatment with 2mA delivered to scalp electrodes
citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M, Fitzgerald PB. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial. Brain research bulletin. 2019;153:273-8. PMID: 31560945.

treatment_desc: Ten sham treatment sessions, with scalp electrodes applied to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, over 10 consecutive weekdays.  Current ramped up for 30s and then ramped down.
citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M, Fitzgerald PB. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial. Brain research bulletin. 2019;153:273-8. PMID: 31560945.

treatment_desc: Stimulation applied to bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
session_length: 20 Hz for 2 seconds with inter-train interval of 28 seconds. Total train of 30, 1200 pulse per 15-minute session
frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

treatment_desc: Stimulation applied to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
session_length: 20 Hz for 2 seconds with inter-train interval of 28 seconds. Total train of 60, 2400 pulse per 30-minute session
frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

treatment_desc: Participants received stimulation that induced a contraction of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle, then magnetic coil switched to a sham coil with identical looks and sounds but prevents magnetic energy from plastic shell
frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

treatment_desc: Alpha-1 receptor blocker; titrated over 10 days, then maintained at 15 mg for duration of study
dose: 15 mg; titration: increased from 1 mg to 15 mg over first 10 days
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 2016-09-15;69(4):235-42. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

treatment_desc: Histamine H-1 blocker; increased from 10 mg over first 10 days to 100 mg, maintained at 100 mg for duration of study
dose: Initiated at 10 mg, increased to 100 mg
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 2016-09-15;69(4):235-42. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

treatment_desc: Identical shape and color to prazosin and hydroxyzine
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 2016-09-15;69(4):235-42. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

treatment_desc: Group sessions of CBT for PTSD based on Clark and Beck's method; all patients also received "SSRIs, neuroleptics, or benzodiazepines"
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure
citation: Akbarian F, Bajoghli H, Haghighi M, et al. The effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy with respect to psychological symptoms and recovering autobiographical memory in patients suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2015;11:395-404. doi: 10.2147/NDT.S79581. PMID: 25737635.

treatment_desc: All patients received "SSRIs, neuroleptics, or benzodiazepines;" control patients visited treatment center for medical and medication check
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure
citation: Akbarian F, Bajoghli H, Haghighi M, et al. The effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy with respect to psychological symptoms and recovering autobiographical memory in patients suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2015;11:395-404. doi: 10.2147/NDT.S79581. PMID: 25737635.

treatment_desc: Anticonvulsant drug; augmentation of participant's existing pharmacotherapy (such as neuroleptics, TCAs, benzodiazepines, SSRIs, sodium valproate, or carbamazepine)
dose: 12.5 to 500 mg; titration: 12.5 or 25 mg initial dose, increased in increments of 25 to 50 mg every 3 to 4 days until clinical response up to maximum dose of 500 mg
citation: Akuchekian S, Amanat S. The Comparison of Topiramate and Placebo in the Treatment of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Double- Blind Study. J Res Med Sci. 2004;9(5):240-4.

treatment_desc: Identical in appearance to topiramate 50 mg form; augmentation of participant's existing pharmacotherapy (such as neuroleptics, tricyclic antidepressants, benzodiazepines, SSRIs, sodium valproate, or carbamazepine).
dose: Titration details NR (Topiramate group started at 12.5 or 25 mg with maximum dose of 500 mg)
citation: Akuchekian S, Amanat S. The Comparison of Topiramate and Placebo in the Treatment of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Double- Blind Study. J Res Med Sci. 2004;9(5):240-4.

treatment_desc: Patient asked to focus on traumatic memory, then therapist queries for salient negative and positive cognitions related to the targeted memory while patients move his/her eyes to the therapist's index finger
citation: Aldahadha B, Al-Harthy H, Sulaiman S. The Efficacy of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing in Resolving the Trauma Caused by the Road Accidents in the Sultanate of Oman. Journal of Instructional Psychology. 2012;39(3/4):146-58.

Aldahadha B, Al-Harthy H, Sulaiman S. The Efficacy of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing in Resolving the Trauma Caused by the Road Accidents in the Sultanate of Oman. Journal of Instructional Psychology. 2012;39(3/4):146-58.

treatment_desc: Patients narrate their biography and encouraged to relive their trauma-related emotions until habituation was achieved
citation: Alghamdi M, Hunt NC, Thomas SA. The effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with traumatised firefighters in Saudi Arabia: a randomized controlled study. Behav Res Ther. 2015 Mar;66:64-71. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2015.01.008. PMID: 25701801.

Alghamdi M, Hunt NC, Thomas SA. The effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with traumatised firefighters in Saudi Arabia: a randomized controlled study. Behav Res Ther. 2015 Mar;66:64-71. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2015.01.008. PMID: 25701801.

treatment_desc: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor; augmentation of treatment with citalopram and valproate; randomized following 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate; rivastigmine 3 mg (total daily dose) for 4 weeks then 6 mg (total daily dose) for 8 weeks.
dose: 3 mg (total daily dose 6 mg); titration: 1.5 mg for 4 weeks (total daily dose 3 mg) then 3 mg for 8 weeks (total daily dose 6 mg)
def_treatment_adherence: used "Standard compliance checklist"
citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

treatment_desc: Placebo identical to rivastigmine; after 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate, randomized to placebo for 8 weeks in addition to treatment with citalopram and valproate.
def_treatment_adherence: used "Standard compliance checklist"
citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

treatment_desc: After 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate, randomized to no additional medications for 8 weeks, and continued routine medications (citalopram and valproate as established in run-in).
def_treatment_adherence: used "Standard compliance checklist"
citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

treatment_desc: Imaginal exposure portion based on program by Foa & Rothbaum (1989) with 60 minutes of imagery work each session; 3 sessions of imaginal exposure only, then 6 sessions focused on identifying and imagining reacting as they wished they had done, until a satisfying response could be used repetitively in imagery.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry. 2007 2016-09-15;38(4):345-70. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

treatment_desc: Based on the program by Foa & Rothbaum (1989) with 60 minutes of imagery exposure, but no in vivo exposure. Homework to listen to audiotaped exposure session 5 days per week and complete Standard Homework Diary Forms, which were reviewed at each therapy session.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry. 2007 2016-09-15;38(4):345-70. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

treatment_desc: Waitlist group created when waiting time to treatment increased "to about 3 months" at which time participants were informed they would start treatment after waiting period.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry. 2007 2016-09-15;38(4):345-70. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

treatment_desc:
PE: manualized therapy consisting of psychoeducation, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, imagery exposure, and processing; 2 introductory sessions and imagery exposure and processing during remaining sessions (6 to maximum of 13 sessions).

TAU: participants continued any treatment received before the study, including supportive counseling and medication; patients were asked to not change medication or dosages for duration of treatment.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Asukai N, Saito A, Tsuruta N, et al. Efficacy of exposure therapy for Japanese patients with posttraumatic stress disorder due to mixed traumatic events: A randomized controlled study. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Dec;23(6):744-50. doi: 10.1002/jts.20589. PMID: 21171135.

treatment_desc: TAU while on waitlist; continuation of any treatment received before the study, including supportive counseling and medication; patients were asked to not change medication or dosages for duration of treatment
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Asukai N, Saito A, Tsuruta N, et al. Efficacy of exposure therapy for Japanese patients with posttraumatic stress disorder due to mixed traumatic events: A randomized controlled study. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Dec;23(6):744-50. doi: 10.1002/jts.20589. PMID: 21171135.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Concurrent Treatment for PTSD and Substance Use Disorder Using Prolonged Exposure (COPE)
treatment_desc: Integrates Prolonged Exposure and CBT for SUD; sessions include psychoeducation, in vivo exposure and imaginal exposure; abstinence is not required to participate but is strongly encouraged.
trauma_detail: Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Accidents, Community/school violence, Natural or manmade disasters, Terrorism/policital violence/forced displacement; Other (physical assault, assault with a weapon, unwanted or uncomfortable sexual experience, captivity, severe human suffering, sudden violent death of someone close, sudden unexpected death of someone close, other very stressful event or experience)
citation: Back SE, Killeen T, Badour CL, et al. Concurrent treatment of substance use disorders and PTSD using prolonged exposure: a randomized clinical trial in military veterans. Addict Behav. 2019 Mar;90:369-77. doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2018.11.032. PMID: 30529244.

treatment_desc: Manualized evidence-based treatment; "teaches skills to help manage cravings and high-risk situations that commonly precipitate substance use."
trauma_detail: Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Accidents, Community/school violence, Natural or manmade disasters, Terrorism/policital violence/forced displacement; Other (physical assault, assault with a weapon, unwanted or uncomfortable sexual experience, captivity, severe human suffering, sudden violent death of someone close, sudden unexpected death of someone close, other very stressful event or experience)
citation: Back SE, Killeen T, Badour CL, et al. Concurrent treatment of substance use disorders and PTSD using prolonged exposure: a randomized clinical trial in military veterans. Addict Behav. 2019 Mar;90:369-77. doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2018.11.032. PMID: 30529244.

treatment_desc: Computerized cognitive training strategies to alter biases in attention. Intervention utilized the dot-probe task to train attention bias away from threat
session_length: Each session consisted of 160 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, then replaced by a pair of words presented for 500 millisecond
citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

treatment_desc: Repeated trials train patients to normalize fluctuations in threat-related attention bias
session_length: Each session consisted of 160 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, then replaced by a pair of words presented for 500 millisecond
citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

treatment_desc: Computerized cognitive training strategies to alter biases in attention. Intervention utilized the dot-probe task with pairs of angry and neutral faces to train attention bias away from threat
session_length: Each session consisted of 120 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, followed by a face pair display for 500 millisecond
citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

treatment_desc: Repeated trials train patients to normalize fluctuations in threat-related attention bias
session_length: Each session consisted of 120 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, followed by a face pair display for 500 millisecond
citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

treatment_desc: Reversible MAOI with SSRI activity; flexible dose with titration
dose: 150 mg; flexible dosing, titration: starting dose NR, titrated up to 150 mg
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
citation: Baker DG, Diamond BI, Gillette GM, et al. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-center study of brofaromine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 1995 Dec;122(4):386-9. doi: 10.1007/BF02246271. PMID: 8657838.

treatment_desc: Placebo
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
citation: Baker DG, Diamond BI, Gillette GM, et al. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-center study of brofaromine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 1995 Dec;122(4):386-9. doi: 10.1007/BF02246271. PMID: 8657838.

treatment_desc: Anticonvulsant; augmentation of standard medications of SSRIs (citalopram 20 to 40 mg per day or sertraline 50 to 200 mg per day) and sodium valproate (1000 to 1800 mg per day)
dose: 150 mg (total daily dose 300 mg); titration: 75 mg per day for one week, then 75 mg twice daily for one week, then 150 mg twice daily
def_treatment_adherence: monitored using a compliance checkllist
citation: Baniasadi M, Hosseini G, Fayyazi Bordbar MR, et al. Effect of pregabalin augmentation in treatment of patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Pract. 2014 Nov;20(6):419-27. doi: 10.1097/01.pra.0000456590.12998.41. PMID: 25406046.

treatment_desc: Placebo augmentation of standard medications of SSRIs (citalopram 20 to 40 mg per day or sertraline 50 to 200 mg per day) and sodium valproate (1000 to 1800 mg per day)
citation: Baniasadi M, Hosseini G, Fayyazi Bordbar MR, et al. Effect of pregabalin augmentation in treatment of patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Pract. 2014 Nov;20(6):419-27. doi: 10.1097/01.pra.0000456590.12998.41. PMID: 25406046.

treatment_desc: Treatment rationale, treatment target setting, and self-exposure instructions provided in first session. Then patients were exposed to simulated earthquake tremors with ability to control intensity, and instructed to confront their fear until they felt in control
session_length: 60 for first session, variable for simulation (mean 33 minutes, SD 18)
citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M. A randomized controlled study of single-session behavioural treatment of earthquake-related post-traumatic stress disorder using an earthquake simulator. Psychological Medicine. 2007;37(2):203-13. doi: 10.1017/S0033291706009123. PMID: 17254365.

treatment_desc: Participants assessed at week 4 and 8 after randomization, then received treatment
citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M. A randomized controlled study of single-session behavioural treatment of earthquake-related post-traumatic stress disorder using an earthquake simulator. Psychological Medicine. 2007;37(2):203-13. doi: 10.1017/S0033291706009123. PMID: 17254365.

treatment_desc: Shorter version of CBT with cognitive intervention limited to explanation of treatment rationale, focusing on reduction of fear and avoidance, and shifting focus from habituation to anxiogenic stimuli to enhancement of sense of control over traumatic stressor
citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M, et al. Single-session behavioral treatment of earthquake-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized waiting list controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2005;18(1):1-11. doi: 10.1002/jts.20011. PMID: 16281190.

treatment_desc: Participants completed a 6-week waiting period then were re-assessed
citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M, et al. Single-session behavioral treatment of earthquake-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized waiting list controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2005;18(1):1-11. doi: 10.1002/jts.20011. PMID: 16281190.

treatment_desc: Placebo identical to topiramate
dose: dose as topiramate-equivalent; 25 to 300 mg per day flexible dosing determined by tolerability; titration schedule: 25 mg/day for 1 week, increased to 50 mg/day in week 2, then increased in 50 mg/day increments each week to maximum of 300 mg/day in week 6, final dose maintained weeks 6 through 11, then tapered and discontinued in week 12.
def_treatment_adherence: Self-report and pill count, medication adherence rate calculated as total dose reported taken/total dose prescribed x 100
trauma_detail: combat-related, other ("civilian related trauma")
citation: Batki SL, Pennington DL, Lasher B, et al. Topiramate treatment of alcohol use disorder in veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2014 Aug;38(8):2169-77. doi: 10.1111/acer.12496. PMID: 25092377.

treatment_desc: Anticonvulsant medication + weekly medication management manualized counseling to promote adherence and reduce alcohol use
dose: 25 to 300 mg per day flexible dosing determined by tolerability; titration schedule: 25 mg/day for 1 week, increased to 50 mg/day in week 2, then increased in 50 mg/day increments each week to maximum of 300 mg/day in week 6, final dose maintained weeks 6 through 11, then tapered and discontinued in week 12.
def_treatment_adherence: Self-report and pill count, medication adherence rate calculated as total dose reported taken/total dose prescribed x 100
trauma_detail: combat-related, other ("civilian related trauma")
citation: Batki SL, Pennington DL, Lasher B, et al. Topiramate treatment of alcohol use disorder in veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2014 Aug;38(8):2169-77. doi: 10.1111/acer.12496. PMID: 25092377.

treatment_name: MI for smoking cessation + PTSD home telehealth care management program
ncptsd_treatment_name: Motivational Interviewing (MI) for smoking cessation + PTSD home telehealth care management program
treatment_desc: MI-based written smoking cessation curricula on home telehealth Health Buddy computer program and weekly telephone smoking cessation MI counseling by a nurse in addition to PTSD home telehealth care management program and nurse care manager. Mi-based smoking cessation curricula used MI material. A participant's response to a question dictated a different reply based on his or her stage of change. Nurse care managers used responses to promote identified health behavior change, and participants acquire a positive behavior (tobacco cessation)
session_length:
PTSD Health Buddy: 2 minutes;
MI counseling sessions: NR (average duration of call: 16.7 minutes)
frequency: PTSD Health Buddy: daily; MI counseling sessions: weekly
citation: Battaglia C, Peterson J, Whitfield E, et al. Integrating motivational interviewing into a home telehealth program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder who smoke: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Mar;72(3):194-206. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22252. PMID: 26783736.

treatment_name: PTSD home telehealth care management program
ncptsd_treatment_name: PTSD home telehealth care management program
treatment_desc: PTSD home telehealth care management services with a device called the Health Buddy, designed to help those with PTSD self-monitor and self-manage. This computer-like device is 12x8x4 inches with a LCD screen. Patient read information and four large buttons for responding to questions. Patient responses transmitted overnight to a secure data center and the next day's curriculum was downloaded to device. Control nurse care managers read patients responses daily, monitored changes in health status, placed outreach phone calls to patients with urgent needs, and coordinated care with primary medical and/or mental health providers.
citation: Battaglia C, Peterson J, Whitfield E, et al. Integrating motivational interviewing into a home telehealth program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder who smoke: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Mar;72(3):194-206. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22252. PMID: 26783736.

treatment_desc: Multicomponent intervention consisting of Flinders Program, usual care, self-help materials, and optional participation in the Stanford Chronic Disease Self-Management group program.
frequency: Varied (RN visits at 1, 3, 6, 9 months with phone calls at 4.5 and 7.5 months; standard group weekly over 2.5 hours for 6 weeks)
citation: Battersby MW, Beattie J, Pols RG, et al. A randomised controlled trial of the Flinders Program™ of chronic condition management in Vietnam veterans with co-morbid alcohol misuse, and psychiatric and medical conditions. Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2013 May;47(5):451-62. doi: 10.1177/0004867412471977. PMID: 23307806.

treatment_desc: Services available included "crisis intervention, alcohol-related education and counselling, pharmacological interventions, and cognitive behavioural and group pro- grams."
citation: Battersby MW, Beattie J, Pols RG, et al. A randomised controlled trial of the Flinders Program™ of chronic condition management in Vietnam veterans with co-morbid alcohol misuse, and psychiatric and medical conditions. Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2013 May;47(5):451-62. doi: 10.1177/0004867412471977. PMID: 23307806.

treatment_desc: Based on Blanchard and Hickling's individual CBT with modifications: treatment extended; detailed manual developed to standardize treatment; imaginal exposure assigned as homework and exposure to target trauma (MVA) conducted in writing; emphasis placed on teaching the principles of extinction to facilitate exposure during homework; treatment delivered by two therapists. Included: psychoeducation; exposure; mindfulness meditation; progressive muscle relaxation; cognitive therapy interventions and assertion training; behavioral activation; and, relapse prevention training.
citation: Beck JG, Coffey SF, Foy DW, et al. Group cognitive behavior therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: an initial randomized pilot study. Behav Ther. 2009 Mar;40(1):82-92. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.01.003. PMID: 19187819.

treatment_desc: Telephone contact by project coordinator using structured script to assess PTSD symptomatology and suicidality; minimal support provided; no active intervention administered.
citation: Beck JG, Coffey SF, Foy DW, et al. Group cognitive behavior therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: an initial randomized pilot study. Behav Ther. 2009 Mar;40(1):82-92. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.01.003. PMID: 19187819.

treatment_desc: Antidepressant with a monocyclic aminoketone structure and weak norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor.
dose: 100 to 300 mg total daily dose; titration: 100 mg for first 2 weeks, then if indicated, dosing increased to 100 mg twice daily. At week 4, if indicated, dosing increased to 150 mg twice daily
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 300 mg for completers, 180 mg for noncompleters
trauma_detail: combat-related, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (homicide, death/suicide of a loved one)
citation: Becker ME, Hertzberg MA, Moore SD, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of bupropion SR in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Apr;27(2):193-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318032eaed. PMID: 17414245.

treatment_desc: Placebo
trauma_detail: combat-related, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (homicide, death/suicide of a loved one)
citation: Becker ME, Hertzberg MA, Moore SD, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of bupropion SR in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Apr;27(2):193-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318032eaed. PMID: 17414245.

treatment_name: Trauma Management Therapy with Exposure Therapy
ncptsd_treatment_name: Trauma Management Therapy with exposure therapy
treatment_desc: Intensive exposure therapy including imaginal and in vivo exposure. Social and emotional rehabilitation involves general social skills training with anger management skills
session_length:
Individual exposure sessions: NR

Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: 90 minutes
frequency:
Individual exposure sessions: 3 times weekly for 5 weeks

Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: twice weekly for 2 weeks, then once weekly for 10 weeks (14 total sessions)
def_treatment_completion: completing all individual exposure sessions and 75% of group sessions
citation: Beidel DC, Frueh BC, Uhde TW, et al. Multicomponent behavioral treatment for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Anxiety Disord. 2011 Mar;25(2):224-31. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2010.09.006. PMID: 20951543.

treatment_desc: Intensive exposure therapy including imaginal and in vivo exposure, then therapist lead group psychoeducation and traditional "rap" group sessions where participants share experiences and garner support from other group members
session_length:
Individual exposure sessions: NR

Group psychoeducation sessions: 90 minutes
frequency:
Individual exposure sessions: 3 times weekly for 5 weeks

Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: twice weekly for 2 weeks, then once weekly for 10 weeks (14 total sessions)
def_treatment_completion: completing all individual exposure sessions and 75% of group sessions
citation: Beidel DC, Frueh BC, Uhde TW, et al. Multicomponent behavioral treatment for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Anxiety Disord. 2011 Mar;25(2):224-31. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2010.09.006. PMID: 20951543.

treatment_desc: Participants guided to breathe at resonant frequency and increase heartrate variability metrics using audiovisual feedback (participant watching a movie and the screen and volume zoom in/out based on physiological measures and set thresholds, used Zukor Media Player) and breath pacer on training screen.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, natural or manmade disasters, child other abuse, other ("work-related trauma [e.g. first responders]")
citation: Bell AN, Moss D, Kallmeyer RJ. Healing the neurophysiological roots of trauma: a controlled study examining loreta z-score neurofeedback and HRV biofeedback for chronic PTSD. NeuroRegulation. 2019;6(2):54-70. doi: 10.15540/nr.6.2.54.

treatment_desc: Training protocol individualized using NeuroGuide's Symptom Checklist-Neural Network Match method, with 3 networks and 5 metrics for each participant. Audiovisual feedback by participant watching a movie and the screen and volume zoom in/out based on physiological measures and set thresholds (used Zukor Media Player). Reward provision used Z-Tunes method with 2 selection criteria: 1) 70% of targeted metrics within set z-score range; 2) average of remaining 30% were moving in direction of z=0 (negative slope); z-score threshold adjusted during each session for reward rate of 24 to 36 rewards per minute.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, natural or manmade disasters, child other abuse, other ("work-related trauma [e.g. first responders]")
citation: Bell AN, Moss D, Kallmeyer RJ. Healing the neurophysiological roots of trauma: a controlled study examining loreta z-score neurofeedback and HRV biofeedback for chronic PTSD. NeuroRegulation. 2019;6(2):54-70. doi: 10.15540/nr.6.2.54.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Imagery rehearsal training (IRT) + trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
treatment_desc: Imagery rehearsal therapy sessions intended to alter the association between sleep and nightmares by rehearsing an alternate dream script in the daytime; followed by series of CBT sessions that included exposure to traumatic memories and to feared objects, activities and situations
session_length: Session length: 60 minutes for imagery rehearsal; 60 to 90 minutes for CBT
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Belleville G, Dube-Frenette M, Rousseau A. Efficacy of imagery rehearsal therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy in sexual assault victims with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2018 Aug;31(4):591-601. doi: 10.1002/jts.22306. PMID: 30070398.

treatment_desc: CBT sessions included exposure to traumatic memories and to feared objects, activities and situations. Sessions followed a 5-week waiting period including weekly check-in phone calls of about 5 minutes' duration.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Belleville G, Dube-Frenette M, Rousseau A. Efficacy of imagery rehearsal therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy in sexual assault victims with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2018 Aug;31(4):591-601. doi: 10.1002/jts.22306. PMID: 30070398.

treatment_desc: Therapist provided same psychoeducation as control group, explaining PTSD-related symptoms and dysfunctions that frequently occur. Patient, assisted by the therapist, construct a chronological report of his own biography with special focus on traumatic experience.
citation: Bichescu D, Neuner F, Schauer M, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for political imprisonment-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depression. Behav Res Ther. 2007 Sep;45(9):2212-20. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2006.12.006. PMID: 17288990.

treatment_desc: Therapist explain PTSD-related symptoms and dysfunctions that frequently occur
citation: Bichescu D, Neuner F, Schauer M, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for political imprisonment-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depression. Behav Res Ther. 2007 Sep;45(9):2212-20. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2006.12.006. PMID: 17288990.

treatment_desc: Manualized treatment with emphasis on helping the patient understand PTSD as a reaction to trauma and to normalize patient's view of his/her symptoms. Treatment included progressive muscle relaxation, reading aloud description of the MVA, in vivo exposure, and behavioral activation to counteract the numbing symptoms
treatment_duration_qual: planned 8 to 12 sessions total with an expected mode of 10
citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

treatment_desc: Manualized treatment with emphasis on helping the patient understand PTSD as a reaction to trauma and to normalize patient's view of his/her symptoms. Therapist provided support on issues raised, including interpersonal or relationship issues, work issues, etc.
treatment_duration_qual: planned 8 to 12 sessions total with an expected mode of 10
citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

treatment_desc: Waitlist
citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) + expressive writing
treatment_desc: Participants listened to audio recording that included an acceptance-based rationale and a guided mindfulness exercise. Participants then completed 2 expressive writing exercises
def_treatment_adherence: Score ≥2 on following writing direction
citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

treatment_desc: Participants listened to audio recording that included CBT rationale and a guided imagery exercise. Participants then completed 2 expressive writing exercises
def_treatment_adherence: Score ≥2 on following writing direction
citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

treatment_desc: Participants listened to audio recording on history of baseline then completed 2 expressive writing exercises
def_treatment_adherence: Score ≥2 on following writing direction
citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

treatment_desc: Magnetic stimulation applied to the left Dorsolateral Pre-frontal Cortex
dose: 20 Hz at 80% of patient's motor threshold; 1600 pulses per session
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

treatment_desc: Magnetic stimulation applied to the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
dose: 21 Hz at 80% of patient's motor threshold; 1600 pulses per session
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

treatment_desc: Administered the same TMS methodology as intervention groups only without magnetic stimulation from the coil. The sham TMS had a small electrical stimulator to mimic scalp sensation.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) +  trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
treatment_desc: Integrated trauma-focused cognitive and exposure-based interventions described by Foa et al (2007) and Ehlers & Clark (2000). Intervention included individual exposure-based treatment plus the following weekly group treatments: skills training, self-esteem intervention, mindfulness sessions, PTSD-specific psychoeducation, and non-specific group interventions (music therapy, art therapy)
session_length:
Individual sessions: 45 minutes

Group sessions: 90 minutes skills training, 60 minutes self-esteem intervention, 25 minutes mindfulness, 60 minutes PTSD-specific psychoeducation, and 90 minutes non-specific interventions
frequency:
Individual sessions: twice weekly

Group sessions: weekly
citation: Bohus MJ, Dyer AS, Priebe K, et al. Dialectical behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder after childhood sexual abuse in patients with and without borderline personality disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):221-33. doi: 10.1159/000348451. PMID: 23712109.

treatment_desc: Participants received 6 months of any treatment of their choice except DBT-PTSD
citation: Bohus MJ, Dyer AS, Priebe K, et al. Dialectical behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder after childhood sexual abuse in patients with and without borderline personality disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):221-33. doi: 10.1159/000348451. PMID: 23712109.

treatment_desc: Computerized cognitive training designed to prevent interfering thoughts from entering consciousness and removing them once they come to mind by improving cognitive performance on a working memory capacity test involving testing of sentence accuracy and memory under a condition of high proactive interference with item memoranda that were words for all trials; 3 blocks of training (45 trials) completed per session.
citation: Bomyea J, Stein MB, Lang AJ. Interference control training for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial of a novel computer-based intervention. J Anxiety Disord. 2015 Aug;34:33-42. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2015.05.010. PMID: 26114901.

treatment_desc: Computerized cognitive training designed to prevent interfering thoughts from entering consciousness and removing them once they come to mind by improving cognitive performance on a working memory capacity test involving testing of sentence accuracy and memory under a condition of low proactive interference with item memoranda that alternated between words and numbers every 3 trials; 3 blocks of training (45 trials) completed per session.
citation: Bomyea J, Stein MB, Lang AJ. Interference control training for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial of a novel computer-based intervention. J Anxiety Disord. 2015 Aug;34:33-42. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2015.05.010. PMID: 26114901.

treatment_desc: Education on PTSD symptoms and skills on how to choose and silently repeat a mantram - a word or phrase with spiritual associations chosen by the participant from a provided list. Repetition on Mantram is intended to train attention. Includes concepts of "slowing down" and "one-pointed attention". Used as a "pause button" for the mind to decrease reactivity to stress.
citation: Bormann JE, Thorp S, Wetherell JL, et al. A spiritually based group intervention for combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility study. J Holist Nurs. 2008 Jun;26(2):109-16. doi: 10.1177/0898010107311276. PMID: 18356284.

treatment_desc: Usual medical care with weekly or monthly case manager and/or primary care provider visits and medication management.
citation: Bormann JE, Thorp S, Wetherell JL, et al. A spiritually based group intervention for combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility study. J Holist Nurs. 2008 Jun;26(2):109-16. doi: 10.1177/0898010107311276. PMID: 18356284.

treatment_desc:
Mantram Repetition Program is a portable, meditation-based intervention that teaches concentrative meditation, slowing down, and one-pointed attention for training attention and regulating emotion; group sessions contained lectures, discussion, sharing, questions and answers, and homework.

TAU consisted of case management as needed to evaluate mental health status and to monitor treatments
citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Wetherell JL, et al. Meditation-based mantram intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized trial. Psychol Trauma. 2013 May;5(3):259-67. doi: 10.1037/a0027522.

treatment_desc: Case management as needed to evaluate mental health status and to monitor treatments
citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Wetherell JL, et al. Meditation-based mantram intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized trial. Psychol Trauma. 2013 May;5(3):259-67. doi: 10.1037/a0027522.

treatment_name: Observed and  Experiential Integration - Switching component
ncptsd_treatment_name: Observed and  Experiential Integration - Switching component
treatment_desc: Participant instructed to close his/her eyes and envision the traumatic incident. When patient experiences physical or emotional signs of distress, instruction is given to uncover the nondominant eye and cover the dominant eye. Dominant/nondominant eye is alternatingly covered or both uncovered.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bradshaw RA, McDonald MJ, Grace R, et al. A randomized clinical trial of Observed and Experiential Integration (OEI): a simple, innovative intervention for affect regulation in clients with PTSD. Traumatology (Tallahass Fla). 2014 Sep;20(3):161-71. doi: 10.1037/h0099401.

trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bradshaw RA, McDonald MJ, Grace R, et al. A randomized clinical trial of Observed and Experiential Integration (OEI): a simple, innovative intervention for affect regulation in clients with PTSD. Traumatology (Tallahass Fla). 2014 Sep;20(3):161-71. doi: 10.1037/h0099401.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for alcohol use
treatment_desc: Placebo tablets matched sertraline tablets.
def_treatment_adherence: 100 mg riboflavin tablets given with study drugs; also monitored by pill count
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (childhood trauma not specified)
citation: Brady KT, Sonne SC, Anton RF, et al. Sertraline in the treatment of co-occurring alcohol dependence and posttraumatic stress disorder. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2005 Mar;29(3):395-401. doi: 10.1097/01.ALC.0000156129.98265.57. PMID: 15770115.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for alcohol use + sertraline
treatment_desc: SSRI; 50 mg tablets
dose: 150 mg; titration: 50 mg for 2 days, 100 mg for 2 days, then 150 mg for the rest of the study
def_treatment_adherence: 100 mg riboflavin tablets given with study drugs; also monitored by pill count
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (childhood trauma not specified)
citation: Brady KT, Sonne SC, Anton RF, et al. Sertraline in the treatment of co-occurring alcohol dependence and posttraumatic stress disorder. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2005 Mar;29(3):395-401. doi: 10.1097/01.ALC.0000156129.98265.57. PMID: 15770115.

treatment_desc: SSRI; flexible dosing titrated in 50-mg increments based on clinical response and tolerability at no less than weekly intervals. Followed a 2-week single-blind placebo run-in period.
dose: 50 to 200 mg; titration: 25 mg for 1 week then increased to 50 mg, further increases in 50-mg increments with maximum 200 mg dose
def_treatment_adherence: compliance monitored by counts of returned medication
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (seeing someone hurt or die, kidnapping)
citation: Brady K, Pearlstein T, Asnis GM, et al. Efficacy and safety of sertraline treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2000 Apr;283(14):1837-44. doi: 10.1001/jama.283.14.1837. PMID: 10770145.

treatment_desc: Matched placebo. Followed a 2-week single-blind placebo run-in period.
def_treatment_adherence: compliance monitored by counts of returned medication
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (seeing someone hurt or die, kidnapping)
citation: Brady K, Pearlstein T, Asnis GM, et al. Efficacy and safety of sertraline treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2000 Apr;283(14):1837-44. doi: 10.1001/jama.283.14.1837. PMID: 10770145.

arm_n_randomized_qual: 7 assigned to alprazolam in first treatment period
treatment_desc: Benzodiazepine; titration over 2 weeks then steady dose for 3 weeks, followed by 2-week taper for patients taking alprazolam in first period (not included in treatment period)
dose: 1.5 to 6 mg; titration: initiated at 1.5 mg, titrated over 2 weeks to maximum 6 mg
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
citation: Braun P, Greenberg D, Dasberg H, et al. Core symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder unimproved by alprazolam treatment. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 1990 Jun;51(6):236-8.  PMID: 2189869.

arm_n_randomized_qual: 9 assigned to placebo in first treatment period
treatment_desc: Placebo
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
citation: Braun P, Greenberg D, Dasberg H, et al. Core symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder unimproved by alprazolam treatment. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 1990 Jun;51(6):236-8.  PMID: 2189869.

treatment_desc: Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction based on Kabat-Zinn approach tailored to PTSD and veterans. Elements include body scan meditation, sitting meditation, hatha yoga via group sessions and home practice
session_length: 2.5 hour sessions plus one 6-hour session during week 6
def_treatment_completion: completed the group and study procedures
citation: Bremner JD, Mishra S, Campanella C, et al. A pilot study of the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms and brain response to traumatic reminders of combat in Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom combat veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. Front Psychiatry. 2017 Aug 25;8:157. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00157. PMID: 28890702.

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation and group support
session_length: NR (same total number of hours as Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction group)
def_treatment_completion: completed the group and study procedures
citation: Bremner JD, Mishra S, Campanella C, et al. A pilot study of the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms and brain response to traumatic reminders of combat in Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom combat veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. Front Psychiatry. 2017 Aug 25;8:157. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00157. PMID: 28890702.

treatment_desc: After the patient has learned relaxation techniques, they are encouraged to re-experience the traumatic event. The patient is then confronted with the previously avoided stimuli, which beforehand are categorized in hierarchies, and learns skills to strengthen the feeling of control.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

treatment_desc: Treatment goal was to bring the patient in contact with the reality of the traumatic event and to bring about a decrease in the conditioned responses triggered by the event
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

treatment_desc: Aim of this therapy is limited to the solving of the intrapsychic conflicts resulting from the traumatic experience, with the therapist playing an active role.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

treatment_desc: Body awareness with psychotherapy

trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (death or injury of family member, threat)

treatment_desc: Beta blocker taken 90 minutes prior to trauma reactivation; all patients in study underwent trauma reactivation, writing a trauma narrative at the first visit which they read aloud at each visit.
dose: 1.67 mg/kg: 0.67 mg/kg short-acting plus 1.0 mg/kg long-acting
trauma_detail: combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (war zone, captivity, life threat, sudden unexpected death, other trauma not specified)
citation: Brunet A, Saumier D, Liu A, et al. Reduction of PTSD Symptoms with pre-reactivation propranolol therapy: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 May 1doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.17050481. PMID: 29325446.

treatment_desc: All patients in study underwent trauma reactivation, writing a trauma narrative at the first visit which they read aloud at each visit 90 minutes after receiving medication.
trauma_detail: combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (war zone, captivity, life threat, sudden unexpected death, other trauma not specified)
citation: Brunet A, Saumier D, Liu A, et al. Reduction of PTSD Symptoms with pre-reactivation propranolol therapy: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 May 1doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.17050481. PMID: 29325446.

treatment_desc: CBT included psychoeducation, CBT skills building, brief imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, cognitive restructuring and relapse prevention.
session_length: 60 minutes with 10 minutes of imaginal exposure
trauma_type: Other (emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality)
citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

treatment_desc: CBT included psychoeducation, CBT skills building, prolonged imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, cognitive restructuring and relapse prevention.
session_length: 90 minutes with 40 minutes of imaginal exposure
trauma_type: Other (emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality)
citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

treatment_desc: WL participants underwent a 3-month waiting period while CBT patients received treatment; WL patients then randomized to active treatment.
trauma_type: Other (emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality)
citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

treatment_name: Prolonged Imaginal Exposure with Cognitive Restructuring
treatment_desc: Psychoeducation and education about cognitive restructuring (first session); 6 sessions consisted of 25 minutes of cognitive restructuring including monitoring of thoughts and affective states, modifying thoughts, and identification and modification of underlying beliefs, followed by 45 minutes of imaginal exposure with patient-provided narrative of trauma experience, and homework included daily exercise of imaginal exposure; the final session focused om relapse prevention using both IE and CR strategies.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation and trauma narrative (first session); 6 sessions consisted of 45 minutes of imaginal exposure with patient-provided narrative of trauma experience,25 minutes of supportive counseling, and monitored homework included daily exercise of imaginal exposure; the final session focused om relapse prevention using exposure-based strategies. Cognitive restructuring was not provided in any sessions.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

treatment_desc: Therapy in unconditionally supportive role with trauma education and general problem-solving skills; homework to keep diary of current problems and mood states. Cognitive restructuring and imaginal exposure techniques were specifically avoided.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

treatment_desc: Exposure to traumatic memories using personal narrative of trauma, discussion of exposure experience, and homework for daily repetition of exposure exercise with monitoring; relapse prevention using imaginal exposure-based strategies. Each session was comprised of: 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 50 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

treatment_desc: Hierarchy of feared situations, in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, and daily homework assignments for approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%; relapse prevention using in vivo exposure-based strategies. Each session comprised of: 25 minutes in vivo exposure instructions, 65 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

treatment_desc: Development of hierarchy of feared situations, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, in vivo exposure exercises (in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, homework assignments for approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%), and relapse prevention using both imaginal exposure and in vivo exposure strategies. Each session comprised of: 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 25 minutes of in vivo exposure, 25 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

treatment_name: Imaginal exposure + In vivo exposure + Cognitive restructuring
treatment_desc:
Sessions comprised of 25 minutes cognitive restructuring, 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 25 minutes of in vivo exposure, and 10 minutes of homework assignments. Final session for relapse prevention using strategies from all 3 approaches.

Imaginal exposure: exposure to traumatic memories using personal narrative of trauma, discussion of exposure experience.

In vivo exposure: hierarchy of feared situations, in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, assignments to approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%.

Cognitive restructuring: identification and monitoring of dysfunctional, unrealistic, and catastrophic thoughts, and affect states and use of Socratic questioning, probabilistic reasoning and evidence-based thinking to modify thoughts.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

treatment_desc: Individual sessions including education about trauma reactions, anxiety management techniques (including Thai meditation), prolonged imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure to avoided situations, cognitive restructuring (modified to recognize ongoing and realistic threat of terrorist attacks), and relapse prevention.
citation: Bryant RA, Ekassawin S, Chakkraband MLS, et al. A randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in terrorist-affected people in Thailand. World Psychiatry. 2011 Oct;10(3):205-9.  PMID: 21991280.

treatment_desc: Supportive counseling without anxiety management, exposure, or cognitive restructuring.
citation: Bryant RA, Ekassawin S, Chakkraband MLS, et al. A randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in terrorist-affected people in Thailand. World Psychiatry. 2011 Oct;10(3):205-9.  PMID: 21991280.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Emotion Regulation Training followed by trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
treatment_desc:
Emotion regulation training (4 sessions) followed by CBT (7 sessions), with one introductory session for psychoeducation.

Emotion regulation training: individualized strategies with emotion tolerance skills, breathing retraining, or progressive muscle relaxation.

CBT: cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, hierarchy of feared events, and relapse prevention.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Mastrodomenico JA, Hopwood S, et al. Augmenting cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with emotion tolerance training: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2013 Oct;43(10):2153-60. doi: 10.1017/S0033291713000068. PMID: 23406821.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Supportive counseling followed by trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
treatment_desc:
Supportive counseling (4 sessions) followed by CBT (7 sessions), with one introductory session for psychoeducation.

Supportive counseling: non-directive with patient-led approach; avoided specific strategies and components of emotional regulation.

CBT: cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, hierarchy of feared events, and relapse prevention.
trauma_detail: accidents, community/school violence
citation: Bryant RA, Mastrodomenico JA, Hopwood S, et al. Augmenting cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with emotion tolerance training: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2013 Oct;43(10):2153-60. doi: 10.1017/S0033291713000068. PMID: 23406821.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + sertraline and/or mianserin
treatment_desc: Manualized CBT including methods from acceptance and commitment therapy, mindfulness exercises, and in vivo and visualized exposure. Doctor adjusts SSRI and provides psychoeducation at each consultation, which was manualized and cover the illness, treatment, sleep, lifestyle, physical activity and social relations, pain, cognitive function, and influence of illness on the family. Patients have weekly consultation with doctor for first 2 months, then monthly consultation for 4 months. Participants reporting sleeping problems were supplemented with mianserin (atypical antipsychotic). Participants with too many side effects from sertraline were switched to mianserin.
dose:
Sertraline: 25 to 200mg; titration: initial dose 2 mg, increased in 25 to 50 mg increments every 1 to 2 weeks with maximum dose of 200 mg
Mianserin: 10 to 30 mg
citation: Buhmann CB, Nordentoft M, Ekstrom M, et al. The effect of flexible cognitive-behavioural therapy and medical treatment, including antidepressants on post-traumatic stress disorder and depression in traumatised refugees: pragmatic randomised controlled clinical trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2016 Mar;208(3):252-9. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.114.150961. PMID: 26541687.

treatment_desc: Manualized CBT including methods from acceptance and commitment therapy, mindfulness exercises, and in vivo and visualized exposure.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) + group psychoeducation
treatment_desc: Individual trauma-specific therapy sessions using EMDR, plus relaxation therapy using PMR, and group psychoeducation sessions. Participants also had occupational therapy (100 minutes per day), sports therapy (50 minutes per day), and physiotherapy (100 minutes per week).
frequency: EMDR: twice per week; PMR: daily; Group psychoeducation: NR (total 250 minutes per week)
citation: Butler O, Willmund G, Gleich T, et al. Hippocampal gray matter increases following multimodal psychological treatment for combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder. Brain Behav. 2018 May;8(5):e00956. doi: 10.1002/brb3.956. PMID: 29761009.

treatment_desc: Waiting list control group

arm_n_randomized_qual: 74 randomized to CPT, excluded 7 patients treated as pilot case
treatment_desc: CBT targeting dysfunctional cognitions about the traumatic event, includes written exposure component.
trauma_detail: accidents, illness/medical procedure, other ("interpersonal", "loss", not specified)
citation: Butollo WH, Karl R, König J, et al. Psychother Psychosom. 2016 Jan;85(1):16-26. doi: 10.1159/000440726. PMID: 26610167.

treatment_desc: Based on gestalt therapy and consisted of 4 phases (safety, stability, confrontation, and integration). Therapist help patients identify and resolve the disruptions of contact so patient will be able to experience continuity of self and regain ability to shape interactions with the environment. Therapy includes exposure to traumatic event (confrontation phase)

treatment_desc: Atypical antipsychotic; binds to serotonin receptor subtypes with substantial affinities greater than its dopamine affinities. Effective serotonin receptor antagonist.
dose: 5 to 20 mg; titration: initial dose of 5 mg for 1 week, then 10 mg for 3 weeks, 15 mg for 2 weeks, up to potential maximum dose of 20 mg
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 14.1 mg/day (mean peak daily dosage during study)
trauma_detail: MST, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence, other (military harassment, "nurse in Vietnam", "Persian Gulf" [non-combat trauma])
citation: Butterfield M, Becker M, Connor K, et al. Olanzapine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot study. Int Clin Psychopharmacol. 2001;16(4):197-203.  PMID: 11459333.

treatment_desc: Placebo
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 13.9 mg (mean peak daily dosage during study)

treatment_desc: Manual-guided intervention designed to improve both PTSD and substance use, adapted for veterans and delivered in both individual and group format (sessions 1-4 delivered individually and sessions 5-12 in group format).
trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Capone C, Presseau C, Saunders E, et al. Is integrated CBT effective in reducing PTSD symptoms and substance use in Iraq and Afghanistan veterans? Results from a randomized clinical trial. Cognit Ther Res. 2018;42(6):735-46. doi: 10.1007/s10608-018-9931-8.

treatment_desc: Continuation of "usual VA care, such as medication management and individual or group psychotherapy in the substance use treatment program or PTSD clinics…"; trauma-focused treatments were not prohibited but more often treatments included skills training or supportive therapy.
trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Capone C, Presseau C, Saunders E, et al. Is integrated CBT effective in reducing PTSD symptoms and substance use in Iraq and Afghanistan veterans? Results from a randomized clinical trial. Cognit Ther Res. 2018;42(6):735-46. doi: 10.1007/s10608-018-9931-8.

treatment_desc: Second-generation antipsychotic
dose: 10 to 15 mg; titration: 5 mg for first week, 7.5 mg for second week, then 10 mg for 2 weeks, dose maintained for next 4 weeks or titrated up to 15 mg
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, community/school violence
citation: Carey P, Suliman S, Ganesan K, et al. Olanzapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: efficacy in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2012 Jul;27(4):386-91. doi: 10.1002/hup.2238. PMID: 22730105.

treatment_desc: Matching placebo

treatment_desc: Manual-based intervention according to Shapiro 1995. Each session included 20 to 28 back-and-forth motions while participants listened to traumatic scripts and focused on related images, negative cognitions and bodily sensations, and finally on the positive cognition
citation: Carlson JG, Chemtob CM, Rusnak K, et al. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 1998 Jan;11(1):3-24. doi: 10.1023/A:1024448814268. PMID: 9479673.

treatment_desc: Electromyographic electrode placement and feedback administration followed manualized protocol by Carlson, Basilio, & Heaukulani 1983. Biofeedback included a pure tone on the  headphones. Participants were also given a recorded cassette containing modified progressive relaxation instructions and written instructions for daily home use
citation: Carlson JG, Chemtob CM, Rusnak K, et al. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 1998 Jan;11(1):3-24. doi: 10.1023/A:1024448814268. PMID: 9479673.

treatment_desc: Manualized program including relaxation, attention diversion, and behavioral activation
citation: Carlsson J, Sonne C, Vindbjerg E, et al. Stress management versus cognitive restructuring in trauma-affected refugees‚Äö√Ñ√Æa pragmatic randomised study. Psychiatry Res. 2018 Aug;266:116-23. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.05.015. PMID: 29859498

treatment_desc: Manualized intervention consisting of psychoeducation and cognitive restructuring of negative thoughts resulting form traumatic experiences and exposure
citation: Carlsson J, Sonne C, Vindbjerg E, et al. Stress management versus cognitive restructuring in trauma-affected refugees‚Äö√Ñ√Æa pragmatic randomised study. Psychiatry Res. 2018 Aug;266:116-23. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.05.015. PMID: 29859498

treatment_desc: Manualized group music therapy employing methods used in psychodynamic music therapy, combination of active and receptive activities and emphasis on free improvisation. Patients were introduced to instruments and encouraged to improvise and therapists gave improvised instrumental support; verbal reflection on thoughts and feelings was encouraged; therapists used supportive psychotherapeutic interventions; personal statements about symptoms were highlighted and made relevant to the whole group.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (torture)
citation: Carr C, D'Ardenne P, Sloboda A, et al. Group music therapy for patients with persistent post-traumatic stress disorder -- an exploratory randomized controlled trial with mixed methods evaluation. Psychol Psychother. 2012 Jun;85(2):179-202. doi: 10.1111/j.2044-8341.2011.02026.x. PMID: 22903909.

treatment_desc: Maintained on clinic caseload with access to mental health care; assessments conducted by telephone. Received music therapy intervention after waiting period and completion of end of evaluation assessment.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (torture)

treatment_desc: Comprised of 3 rounds of cyclical breathing. Treatment also includes psychoeducation about stress reduction and group processes. Intervention consisted of a week-long workshop, followed by weekly group sessions for the first month and monthly group session for the next 5 months
session_length: 22 hours total during weeklong workshop, 2 hours subsequent group session
frequency: Daily during weeklong workshop, weekly for subsequent 1 month, then monthly for next 5 months
citation: Carter JJ, Gerbarg PL, Brown RP, et al. Multi-component yoga breath program for Vietnam veteran post traumatic stress disorder: randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress Disord Treat. 2013 Jul 31;2(3)doi: 10.4172/2324-8947.1000108.

Carter JJ, Gerbarg PL, Brown RP, et al. Multi-component yoga breath program for Vietnam veteran post traumatic stress disorder: randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress Disord Treat. 2013 Jul 31;2(3)doi: 10.4172/2324-8947.1000108.

treatment_desc: Three-module treatment including imaginal exposure (trauma narrative writing and identification of coping strategies), cognitive restructuring (from CPT), and behavioral skills development
trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, other (not specified)
citation: Castillo DT, Chee CL, Nason E, et al. Group-delivered cognitive/exposure therapy for PTSD in women veterans: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Trauma. 2016 May;8(3):404-12. doi: 10.1037/tra0000111. PMID: 26854355.

treatment_desc: Unstructured, nondirective individual support, which excluded treatment such as trauma review, cognitive restructuring, or behavioral treatment techniques
trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, other (not specified)
