treatment_desc: SSRI
dose: 60 mg; titration: initiated at 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg every 2 weeks until 60 mg, then maintained for weeks 8 through 12 if tolerated and clinically indicated
citation: Celik C, Ozdemir B, Ozmenler KN, et al. Efficacy of paroxetine and amitriptyline in posttraumatic stress disorder: an open-label comparative study. Klinik Psikofarmakol B√ºlteni. 2011 Sep;21(3):179-85. doi: 10.5455/bcp.20110627111141.

treatment_desc: TCA
dose: Initiated at 25 mg/day for first 3 days, followed by 50 mg/day on days 4 to 7, then 75 mg/day for following 2 weeks. Dose could be increased to 100 mg/day as necessary for weeks 3 and 4, then to 200 mg/day at end of week 5
citation: Celik C, Ozdemir B, Ozmenler KN, et al. Efficacy of paroxetine and amitriptyline in posttraumatic stress disorder: an open-label comparative study. Klinik Psikofarmakol B√ºlteni. 2011 Sep;21(3):179-85. doi: 10.5455/bcp.20110627111141.

treatment_desc: Adapted from Resick & Schnicke's (1993) CPT manual to include schema-discrepant and schema-congruent beliefs, and a session on assertiveness/communications, sexual intimacy, and social support. Intervention included weekly group sessions and individual therapy session in the first 9 and last week of intervention
session_length:
Group session: 90 minutes

Individual session: 60 minutes
citation: Chard KM. An evaluation of cognitive processing therapy for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Oct;73(5):965-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.965. PMID: 16287396.

treatment_desc: Telephone call to assess current emotional state and give supportive, nondirective, brief counseling if experiencing a crisis
citation: Chard KM. An evaluation of cognitive processing therapy for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Oct;73(5):965-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.965. PMID: 16287396.

treatment_desc: Atypical antidepressant (alpha-2 agonist); dose could be adjusted after 1, 2, and 6 weeks of treatment
dose: Initiated at 15 mg; maximum dose NR
citation: Chung MY, Min KH, Jun YJ, et al. Efficacy and tolerability of mirtazapine and sertraline in Korean veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized open label trial. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2004 Oct;19(7):489-94. doi: 10.1002/hup.615. PMID: 15378676.

treatment_desc: SSRI; dose could be adjusted after 1, 2, and 6 weeks' therapy, maximum dose NR
dose: Initiated at 50 mg; maximum dose NR
citation: Chung MY, Min KH, Jun YJ, et al. Efficacy and tolerability of mirtazapine and sertraline in Korean veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized open label trial. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2004 Oct;19(7):489-94. doi: 10.1002/hup.615. PMID: 15378676.

treatment_desc: Brief exposure therapy with a somatic and cognitive component. The subject pairs the traumatic memory with a self-acceptance statement, then taps a sequence of points on his/her body repeatedly until subjective units of distress decreases to 0. All subjects also received the standard of care at VA.
citation: Church D, Hawk C, Brooks AJ, et al. Psychological trauma symptom improvement in veterans using Emotional Freedom Techniques. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2013 Feb;201(2):153-60. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31827f6351. PMID: 23364126.

Church D, Hawk C, Brooks AJ, et al. Psychological trauma symptom improvement in veterans using Emotional Freedom Techniques. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2013 Feb;201(2):153-60. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31827f6351. PMID: 23364126.

treatment_desc:
Both treatment groups combined for analysis.

Trauma-focused group therapy: goal of treatment is to help survivors work through and integrate their traumatic abuse experiences; involves: reconstructing traumatic experiences; integrating the affect associated with the trauma; modifying negative views of self which arose due to the abuse; integration of traumatic history into conscious awareness of self and others.

Present-focused group therapy: goal to help survivors identify and modify maladaptive patterns of behavior which had arisen as a result of their traumatic past; treatment assumption that by focusing on the present, survivors can alter their current functioning and thereby address the impact of their abuse history.
citation: Classen CC, Koopman C, Nevill-Manning K, et al. A preliminary report comparing trauma-focused and present-focused group therapy against a wait-listed condition among childhood sexual abuse survivors with PTSD. J Aggress Maltreat Trauma. 2001 Jun;4(2):265-88. doi: 10.1300/J146v04n02_12.

Classen CC, Koopman C, Nevill-Manning K, et al. A preliminary report comparing trauma-focused and present-focused group therapy against a wait-listed condition among childhood sexual abuse survivors with PTSD. J Aggress Maltreat Trauma. 2001 Jun;4(2):265-88. doi: 10.1300/J146v04n02_12.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + exposure therapy
treatment_desc: STAIR (8 sessions) followed by exposure treatment (8 sessions). Exposure treatment was modified from prolonged exposure protocol with interpersonal skills practice instead of in vivo exposure to trauma stimuli, and meaning analysis introduced after the exposure.
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + supportive therapy
treatment_desc: STAIR (8 sessions) followed by supportive counseling (8 sessions). Supportive counseling with client-directed discussion of abuse history-related life problems.
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

treatment_desc: Supportive counseling (8 sessions) and exposure treatment (8 sessions). Supportive counseling with client-directed discussion of abuse history-related life problems. Exposure treatment was modified from prolonged exposure protocol with interpersonal skills practice instead of in vivo exposure to trauma stimuli, and meaning analysis introduced after the exposure.
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) plus modified Prolonged Exposure (PE)
treatment_desc: STAIR is CBT targeting development of emotion management and interpersonal skills. Topics include labeling and identifying feelings, emotion management, distress tolerance, acceptance of feelings, identification of trauma-based interpersonal schemas and conflict between trauma-generated feelings and current interpersonal goals, and role play related to issue of power and control. PE followed technique described by Foa & Rothbaum (1998), except in vivo exposure to rape-related cues was eliminated, while postexposure stabilization check, postexposure emotion-focused processing, and identification of negative interpersonal schemas and addressed with skills from STAIR.
frequency: STAIR: weekly; Modified PE: twice weekly
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
citation: Cloitre M, Koenen KC, Cohen LR, et al. Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation followed by exposure: a phase-based treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Oct;70(5):1067-74. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.70.5.1067. PMID: 12362957.

treatment_desc: Study coordinator monitored participants through phone session
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
citation: Cloitre M, Koenen KC, Cohen LR, et al. Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation followed by exposure: a phase-based treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Oct;70(5):1067-74. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.70.5.1067. PMID: 12362957.

treatment_desc: Manualized intervention according to Foa & Rothbaum 1998. Intervention includes participants repeatedly describe their trauma. All participants received outpatient substance use treatment, which included three times per week group coping-skills-based therapy for addiction and once every 1 or 2 weeks individual treatment for addition.
def_treatment_completion: attending all laboratory and clinical sessions
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
citation: Coffey SF, Stasiewicz PR, Hughes PM, et al. Trauma-focused imaginal exposure for individuals with comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol dependence: revealing mechanisms of alcohol craving in a cue reactivity paradigm. Psychol Addict Behav. 2006 Dec;20(4):425-35. doi: 10.1037/0893-164X.20.4.425. PMID: 17176177.

treatment_desc: Participants listened to an imagery-based relaxation audiotape during treatment session
def_treatment_completion: attending all laboratory and clinical sessions

Trauma-focused imaginal exposure for individuals with comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol dependence: revealing mechanisms of alcohol craving in a cue reactivity paradigm. treatment_name: Modified PE with trauma-focused motivational enhancement session, plus standard SUD TAU
ncptsd_treatment_name: Motivational enhancement session followed by modified Prolonged Exposure (PE) + standard substance use treatment as usual
treatment_desc: Prior to first PE session, participants received a 90-minute motivational enhancement therapy consisting of eliciting/developing discrepancy, presenting feedback, and future directions. Traditional PE according to Foa et al. (2007) consisting of imaginal and in vivo exposure techniques, psychoeducation about PTSD and its relationship with SUD, and breathing retraining. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of 9 sessions, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

treatment_name: Modified PE plus standard SUD TAU
treatment_desc: Prior to first PE session, participants received a 60-minute relaxation session. Traditional PE according to Foa et al. (2007) consisting of imaginal and in vivo exposure techniques, psychoeducation about PTSD and its relationship with SUD, and breathing retraining. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of 9 sessions, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

treatment_name: Healthy lifestyle sessions plus standard SUD TAU
ncptsd_treatment_name: Healthy lifetsyle session +  substance use treatment as usual
treatment_desc: Prior to first education session, participants received a 60-minute relaxation session. Education on health-related topics included sleep hygiene, progressive muscle relaxation, starting/maintaining an exercise program, personal role identification, healthy eating and nutrition, diabetes, monitoring goals and values, cancer, and HIV. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of Session 9, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

treatment_desc:
rTMS performed with Magstim stimulator with 9-cm diameter. Motor threshold was determined in each subject once which was defined as lowest stimulation intensity capable of inducing a visible movement at least five times out of 10. 

Treatment was administered over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (defined as 5 cm anterior to the motor cortex - following a parasagittal line)

Stimulus intensity was 80% of subject's motor threshold intensity
dose: 1 Hz for 5 seconds with intertrain interval of 55 seconds
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (occupational, unexpected death of relative)
citation: Cohen H, Kaplan Z, Kotler M, et al. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2004 Mar;161(3):515-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.161.3.515. PMID: 14992978.

treatment_desc:
rTMS performed with Magstim stimulator with 9-cm diameter. Motor threshold was determined in each subject once which was defined as lowest stimulation intensity capable of inducing a visible movement at least five times out of 10. 

Treatment was administered over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (defined as 5 cm anterior to the motor cortex - following a parasagittal line)

Stimulus intensity was 80% of subject's motor threshold intensity.
dose: 1 Hz for 2 seconds per train with intertrain interval of 55 seconds

treatment_desc: SSRI; increased by 10 mg per week to maximum 60 mg/day based on response and tolerability
dose: 10 to 60 mg; titration: initiated at 10 mg, increased by 10 mg per week to maximum 60 mg
def_treatment_adherence: Pill counts
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters. other (traumatic bereavement, father in intensive care unit, witnessed emotional abuse)

treatment_desc: Capsules matched fluoxetine and titration schedule the same
dose: Initiated at 10 mg, titrated to maximum 60 mg

treatment_desc: Selective GABA reuptake inhibitor; initial 12-week open-label tiagabine treatment for all patients, those with at least minimal response or better on CGI-I scale randomized for continuation at same dose
dose: 2 to 16 mg; continued dose established in open-label phase (open-label phase titration: 2 mg for 1 week then increased by 4 mg increments per week with maximum 16 mg)

treatment_desc: Matched placebo. Followed 12-week open-label tiagabine period, with those randomized to placebo tapered off tiagabine by 2 mg every 3 days.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (unexpected death of or threat of harm to a loved one; unwanted therapeutic abortion)
citation: Connor KM, Davidson JRT, Weisler RH, et al. Tiagabine for posttraumatic stress disorder: effects of open-label and double-blind discontinuation treatment. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2006 Jan;184(1):21-5. doi: 10.1007/s00213-005-0265-3. PMID: 16341846.

treatment_desc: Veterans chose a repetitive nightmare related to their war-zone experiences, alter the nightmare script during waking hours using imagery techniques, and mentally research the revised script daily
citation: Cook JM, Harb GC, Gehrman PR, et al. Imagery rehearsal for posttraumatic nightmares: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Oct;23(5):553-63. doi: 10.1002/jts.20569. PMID: 20839311.

treatment_desc: Contains psychoeducation about PTSD nightmares and sleep disturbances and elements of CBT for insomnia
citation: Cook JM, Harb GC, Gehrman PR, et al. Imagery rehearsal for posttraumatic nightmares: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Oct;23(5):553-63. doi: 10.1002/jts.20569. PMID: 20839311.

treatment_desc: Standard therapy including imaginal or in vivo exposure, relaxation techniques, and cognitive therapy targeting anxious cognitions, automatic thoughts, dysfunctional beliefs, vulnerability schemas and emotions related to the trauma
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Cottraux J, Note I, Yao S-N, et al. Randomized controlled comparison of cognitive behavior therapy with Rogerian supportive therapy in chronic post-traumatic stress disorder: a 2-year follow-up. Psychother Psychosom. 2008 Jan;77(2):101-10. doi: 10.1159/000112887. PMID: 18230943.

treatment_desc: Therapy does not include any active component of CBT (e.g., relaxation, exposure advice, structured cognitive therapy). Therapist used active listening with an empathic attitude, and had unconditionally positive regard for the patients. Therapist reassured patients when they expressed anxiety and emphasize the importance to ventilate problems verbally
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Cottraux J, Note I, Yao S-N, et al. Randomized controlled comparison of cognitive behavior therapy with Rogerian supportive therapy in chronic post-traumatic stress disorder: a 2-year follow-up. Psychother Psychosom. 2008 Jan;77(2):101-10. doi: 10.1159/000112887. PMID: 18230943.

treatment_desc: TCA; variable dose with initial titration over 2 weeks followed by increase if necessary and tolerated; both groups received supportive therapy and medication management
dose: 50 to 300 mg variable dose; titration: 50 mg increased in 25 mg increments to 100 mg over 1 week, by 50 mg increments to 200 mg over the following week, then increased if necessary as tolerated
citation: Davidson J, Kudler H, Smith R, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder with amitriptyline and placebo. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1990 Mar;47(3):259-66. PMID: 2407208.

treatment_desc: Placebo; both groups received supportive therapy and medication management
citation: Davidson J, Kudler H, Smith R, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder with amitriptyline and placebo. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1990 Mar;47(3):259-66. PMID: 2407208.

treatment_desc: Flexible dose sertraline based on clinical response and tolerability with 1 week run-in period at 25 mg dose.

treatment_desc: MBSR sessions included body scan meditation, sitting meditation, and mindful stretching. Six-hour retreat prior to week 6 included extended practices and mindful walking and eating. Participants given two guided meditation CDs to practice at home.
trauma_detail: Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (noncombat military, civilian)
citation: Davis LL, Whetsell C, Hamner MB, et al. A multisite randomized controlled trial of mindfulness-based stress reduction in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychiatric Research and Clinical Practice. 2018b Nov 5;1(2):39-48. doi: 10.1176/appi.prcp.20180002..

treatment_desc: Therapy was psycho-educational and addressed symptoms of PTSD and the effects of PTSD on daily life. Allowed shared support and positive experiences with other veterans. The groups had a present focus that avoided discussion of traumas. Participants were assigned to keep a journal and had a lunch gathering to partially control for the MBSR retreat.
trauma_detail: Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (noncombat military, civilian)
citation: Davis LL, Whetsell C, Hamner MB, et al. A multisite randomized controlled trial of mindfulness-based stress reduction in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychiatric Research and Clinical Practice. 2018b Nov 5;1(2):39-48. doi: 10.1176/appi.prcp.20180002..

treatment_desc: Designed primarily as an attention control, but in order for the program to be perceived as a credible treatment, it matched the physical activity of the yoga program with low intensity walking in addition to didactics and discussion of wellness topics
trauma_detail: MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (childhood, not specified; other adult, not specified)
citation: Davis LW, Schmid AA, Daggy JK, et al. Symptoms improve after a yoga program designed for PTSD in a randomized controlled trial with veterans and civilians. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Apr 20 doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/tra0000564. PMID: 32309986.

treatment_desc: Yoga instruction including components of Hatha Yoga: postures (asanas), breathing practices (pranayama), and relaxation. Home practice support included instructional DVD and audio device, handout with figures depicting sequence of poses, and a yoga mat and eye pillow.
trauma_detail: MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (childhood, not specified; other adult, not specified)
citation: Davis LW, Schmid AA, Daggy JK, et al. Symptoms improve after a yoga program designed for PTSD in a randomized controlled trial with veterans and civilians. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Apr 20 doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/tra0000564. PMID: 32309986.

treatment_desc: Phenylpiperazine derivative; presynaptic serotonin reuptake inhibitor, postsynaptic 5-hydroxytryptamine 2A receptor antagonist, with modest norepinephrine uptake inhibition
dose: 200 to 600 mg total daily dose; initial dose 200 mg titrated in increments of 100 mg every 4 days as tolerated to maximum therapeutic benefit, with a maximum dose of 600 mg
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault
citation: Davis LL, Jewell ME, Ambrose S, et al. A placebo-controlled study of nefazodone for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a preliminary study. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2004;24(3):291-7.  PMID: 15118483.

treatment_desc: Look-a-like placebo capsules
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault

treatment_desc: Centrally-acting alpha-2 agonist; increased from 1 to 2 mg based on symptoms and side effects, as tolerated
dose: 1 to 2 mg
citation: Davis LL, Ward C, Rasmusson A, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of guanfacine for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2008;41(1):8-18.  PMID: 18362867.

treatment_desc: Placebo intervention not described;  trial reported as double-blind
citation: Davis LL, Ward C, Rasmusson A, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of guanfacine for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2008;41(1):8-18.  PMID: 18362867.

treatment_desc: Increases GABA levels in brain; enteric-coated, delayed release; dose increased as tolerated to maximum benefit
dose: 1000 to 3000 mg total daily dose; titration: initial dose 500 mg twice a day, increased in 500-mg increments with maximum dose 3000 mg/day
def_treatment_adherence: Blinded serum valproic acid morning trough levels
adhered_pharmacotherapy_percent_detail: serum level 82.9 (30.1) mg/L at week 8 (authors conclude that "compliance may have been variable")
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (non-specified)
citation: Davis LL, Davidson JR, Ward LC, et al. Divalproex in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in a veteran population. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2008 Feb;28(1):84-8. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318160f83b. PMID: 18204347

treatment_desc: Visually identical to divalproex tablets
def_treatment_adherence: Technician provided sham reports for morning trough levels for placebo group
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (non-specified)
citation: Davis LL, Davidson JR, Ward LC, et al. Divalproex in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in a veteran population. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2008 Feb;28(1):84-8. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318160f83b. PMID: 18204347

treatment_desc:
Concurrent individual CPT and art therapy.
CPT: sessions 1 through 8 of manualized treatment (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2007) "designed to challenge negative cognitions associated with trauma" .
Art therapy: followed protocol by Campbell (2014) and involving "psychoeducation, goal setting, creating a sense of safety, creating and processing one’s visual trauma narrative, identifying and addressing symptoms and triggers, integrating the trauma with the rest of their experiences, identifying grief and loss caused by combat trauma, reconstructing worldviews and self-concept, and reviewing artworks and recovery-oriented goals... participants were given six directives to construct the visual trauma narrative: 1) Create an image of a time before the trauma that you felt peaceful and safe—a positive memory; 2) Create an image of the last moment you remember directly before the trauma; 3) Create an image of what happened during the trauma; 4) Create an image of a moment you can remember right after the trauma; 5) Create an image of a time when you were safe from the physical threats of war; 6) Create an image of a time when you tried to self-soothe."
treatment_duration_qual: total 16 hours; 8 hours CPT plus 8 hours art therapy
citation: Decker KP, Deaver SP, Abbey V, et al. Quantitatively improved treatment outcomes for combat-associated PTSD with adjunctive art therapy: randomized controlled trial. Art Therapy. 2018;35(4):184-94. doi: 10.1080/07421656.2018.1540822.

treatment_desc:
Concurrent individual CPT and supportive psychotherapy.
CPT: sessions 1 through 8 of manualized treatment (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2007) "designed to challenge negative cognitions associated with trauma".
Supportive psychotherapy: "focused on present-centered concerns, with the goal of reinforcing healthy and adaptive patterns of thoughts and behaviors to reduce symptoms of PTSD and depression"
treatment_duration_qual: total 16 hours; 8 hours CPT plus 8 hours supportive psychotherapy
citation: Decker KP, Deaver SP, Abbey V, et al. Quantitatively improved treatment outcomes for combat-associated PTSD with adjunctive art therapy: randomized controlled trial. Art Therapy. 2018;35(4):184-94. doi: 10.1080/07421656.2018.1540822.

treatment_desc: Combined CPT and smoking cessation; "smoking was conceptualized and integrated into treatment as an avoidance behavior that interferes with processing PTSD symptoms". Participants taught to apply cognitive restructuring skills from CPT to smoking cessation. Smoking cessation content followed Integrated Care for Smoking Cessation treatment manual, and was identical to that of the Present-focused smoking cessation arm except for use of cognitive restructuring skills in the CPT arm.
citation: Dedert EA, Resick PA, Dennis PA, et al. Pilot trial of a combined cognitive processing therapy and smoking cessation treatment. J Addict Med. 2019 Jul/Aug;13(4):322-30. doi: 10.1097/ADM.0000000000000502. PMID: 30664539.

treatment_desc: Cognitive behavioral smoking cessation treatment following the Integrated Care for Smoking Cessation manual; treatment is present-focused. "The smoking cessation treatment in this arm was identical to the smoking cessation component of the [combined CPT + smoking cessation] group, except that the [present-focused smoking cessation] arm did not utilize formal cognitive restructuring to address smoking triggers."
citation: Dedert EA, Resick PA, Dennis PA, et al. Pilot trial of a combined cognitive processing therapy and smoking cessation treatment. J Addict Med. 2019 Jul/Aug;13(4):322-30. doi: 10.1097/ADM.0000000000000502. PMID: 30664539.

treatment_desc:
D-cycloserine prior to PE sessions

PE: standardized program including prolonged imaginal exposure (30 minutes each session), in vivo exposure assignments and homework of exposure using recorded session audiotape.

D-cycloserine: glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor partial agonist, taken 1 hour prior to start of each PE session
dose: 50 mg
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (violent nonsexual assault; "miscellaneous")
citation: de Kleine RA, Hendriks GJ, Kusters WJ, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine to enhance exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2012 Jun 1;71(11):962-8. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.02.033. PMID: 22480663.

treatment_desc:
Placebo prior to PE sessions

PE: standardized program including prolonged imaginal exposure (30 minutes each session), in vivo exposure assignments and homework of exposure using recorded session audiotape.

Placebo: identical in appearance to D-cycloserine, taken 1 hour prior to start of each PE session
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (violent nonsexual assault; "miscellaneous")
citation: de Kleine RA, Hendriks GJ, Kusters WJ, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine to enhance exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2012 Jun 1;71(11):962-8. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.02.033. PMID: 22480663.

treatment_desc: Participants track extreme hand movements while holding in mind a representative picture of the traumatic event. On average, 24 back-and-forth sweeps were given for each set until subjective units of distress decrease to 0. Eye movement desensitization repeated until no more imaginal picture arises
citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

treatment_name: Reactive Eye Dilation Desensitization and Reprocessing
treatment_desc: Participant concentrates on the imaginal picture and accompanying body sensation while concentrating on a black box emitting flashing light at rate of 4 flashes per second.
citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

treatment_desc: Participants continued their usual treatment without additional support from research therapist
citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

treatment_name: Exposure therapy with virtual reality plus D-cycloserine
treatment_desc: Participants recounted their trauma while wearing a virtual reality helmet with a computer simulation of the September 11th attacks. Graded scenarios increased in intensity and detail, target of 45 minutes "in the virtual world". D-cycloserine: antibiotic, also used as a cognitive enhancer, given 90 minutes before sessions beginning with session 2.
dose: 100 mg
def_treatment_adherence: verbal inquiry about medication ingestion before session
citation: Difede J, Cukor J, Wyka KE, et al. D-cycloserine augmentation of exposure therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2014 Apr;39(5):1052-108. doi: 10.1038/npp.2013.317. PMID: 24217129.

treatment_name: Exposure therapy with virtual reality plus placebo
treatment_desc: Participants recounted their trauma while wearing a virtual reality helmet with a computer simulation of the September 11th attacks. Graded scenarios increased in intensity and detail, goal 45 minutes "in the virtual world". Matched placebo given 90 minutes prior to start of therapy beginning at session 2.
def_treatment_adherence: verbal inquiry about medication ingestion before session
citation: Difede J, Cukor J, Wyka KE, et al. D-cycloserine augmentation of exposure therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2014 Apr;39(5):1052-108. doi: 10.1038/npp.2013.317. PMID: 24217129.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
treatment_desc: Participants received individual treatment as usual by a psychotherapist, psychiatric nurse, or psychiatrist. In addition, participants received a stabilizing group CBT program based on manual by Zlotnick et al. (1997). Group session included psychoeducation aimed at attaining a sense of cognitive mastery, cognitive behavioral skills focused on identifying and modifying dysfunctional behavior, thoughts, and beliefs about the trauma. Treatment focused on the present, positive reinforcement, and empowerment, and avoided sharing individual trauma histories
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse
citation: Dorrepaal E, Thomaes K, Smit JH, et al. Stabilizing group treatment for complex posttraumatic stress disorder related to child abuse based on psychoeducation and cognitive behavioural therapy: a multisite randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2012;81(4):217-25. doi: 10.1159/000335044. PMID: 22585094.

treatment_desc: Participants received individual treatment by a psychotherapist, psychiatric nurse, or psychiatrist

citation: Dorrepaal E, Thomaes K, Smit JH, et al. Psychother Psychosom. 2012;81(4):217-25. doi: 10.1159/000335044. PMID: 22585094.

treatment_desc: Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) alpha receptor agonist indicated for the treatment of sleep, given at bedtime
dose: 3 mg
trauma_detail: Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (observed violence to or death of a loved one)

Double-blind randomized controlled study of the efficacy, safety and tolerability of eszopiclone vs placebo for the treatment of patients with post-traumatic stress disorder and insomnia. treatment_desc: Individual psychotherapy adapted from IPT to address needs of depressed women with childhood sexual abuse histories in the community health setting. The 4 adaptations to the IPT protocol are: 1) expanded treatment period to 16 sessions over 32 weeks; 2) used engagement analysis to "help patients identify and problem-solve social, practical, and psychological barriers to treatment participation"; 3) used a sociocultural formulation "to help patients identify ways in which cultural and economic influences (e.g., family beliefs, ethnic identities, religious practices, racism, and poverty) may affect their interpersonal problems and depression"; 4) an "interpersonal-patterns" problem area replaced the "interpersonal deficits" problem  area, "the interpersonal-patterns problem area is used to help patients recognize longstanding patterns of behavior and emotion commonly seen among individuals with trauma histories that could undermine social health"
citation: Duberstein PR, Ward EA, Chaudron LH, et al. Effectiveness of interpersonal psychotherapy-trauma for depressed women with childhood abuse histories. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2018 Oct;86(10):868-78. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000335. PMID: 30265045.

treatment_desc: Clinician choice of psychotherapy among treatments typically used in a community mental health clinic; therapists were not restricted from "reasonable therapeutic activities or interventions"
citation: Duberstein PR, Ward EA, Chaudron LH, et al. Effectiveness of interpersonal psychotherapy-trauma for depressed women with childhood abuse histories. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2018 Oct;86(10):868-78. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000335. PMID: 30265045.

treatment_desc: Based on Ehlers and Clark's model that addresses excessively negative appraisals of the traumatic event or its sequelae, disturbance in autobiographical memory, and dysfunctional cognitive and behavioral strategies. Includes behavioral activation early in therapy.
def_treatment_completion: completed ≥6 sessions or ended therapy earlier as agreed by the therapist because of noticeable improvement
psychotherapy_sessions_qual: patients received additional average 2.0 [SD 3.2] sessions after 12-week period for a total of 7.8 [SD 5.1] sessions
trauma_detail: terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence, accidents
citation: Duffy M, Gillespie K, Clark DM. Post-traumatic stress disorder in the context of terrorism and other civil conflict in Northern Ireland: randomised controlled trial. BMJ. 2007 Jun 2;334(7604):1147-50. doi: 10.1136/bmj.39021.846852.BE. PMID: 17495988.

trauma_detail: terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence, accidents
citation: Duffy M, Gillespie K, Clark DM. Post-traumatic stress disorder in the context of terrorism and other civil conflict in Northern Ireland: randomised controlled trial. BMJ. 2007 Jun 2;334(7604):1147-50. doi: 10.1136/bmj.39021.846852.BE. PMID: 17495988.

treatment_desc: Orally active selective CRF1 receptor antagonist that suppressed ACTH response to stress, reduced anxiety
dose: 350 mg
def_treatment_adherence: completed treatment and complied with medication regimen (daily dosing diary and verification by serum levels)
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 923 ng/mL (mean concentration at 6 weeks among compliant patients)
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (unspecified child abuse, unspecified)
citation: Dunlop BW, Binder EB, Iosifescu D, et al. Corticotropin-releasing factor receptor 1 antagonism is ineffective for women with posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2017 Dec;82(12):866-74. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2017.06.024. PMID: 28793974

treatment_desc: Matching placebo tablet
def_treatment_adherence: completed treatment and complied with medication regimen (daily dosing diary)

treatment_desc: Treatment according to the Australian Guidelines for the treatment of Adult with Acute Stress Disorder for PTSD (Australian Centre for Posttraumatic Mental Health. Australian Guidelines for the Treatment of Adults with Acute Stress Disorder and Post-traumatic Stress Disorder. Melbourne, VIC: ACPMH; 2007). Treatment included psychoeducation, anxiety management by deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, graded in vivo exposure, and relapse prevention.
citation: Dunne RL, Kenardy JA, Sterling M. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for the treatment of PTSD in the context of chronic whiplash. Clin J Pain. 2012 Nov-Dec;28(9):755-65. doi: 10.1097/AJP.0b013e318243e16b. PMID: 22209798.

Dunne RL, Kenardy JA, Sterling M. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for the treatment of PTSD in the context of chronic whiplash. Clin J Pain. 2012 Nov-Dec;28(9):755-65. doi: 10.1097/AJP.0b013e318243e16b. PMID: 22209798.

treatment_desc: Treatment seeks to modify negative thoughts associated with rape. Coping skills training includes progressive muscular relaxation, thought-stopping, cognitive distractions, and instruction in gradual exposure
citation: Echeburua E, de Corral P, Sarasua B, et al. Treatment of acute posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: an experimental study. J Anxiety Disord. 1996 May-Jun;10(3):185-99. doi: 10.1016/0887-6185(96)89842-2.

treatment_desc: Progressive muscular relaxation training according to Bernstein & Borkovec (1973)
citation: Echeburua E, de Corral P, Sarasua B, et al. Treatment of acute posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: an experimental study. J Anxiety Disord. 1996 May-Jun;10(3):185-99. doi: 10.1016/0887-6185(96)89842-2.

treatment_desc: Manualized treatment; goal is to modify excessively negative appraisals, correct the autobiographical memory disturbance, and remove the problematic behavior and cognitive responses.
frequency: Weekly for 3 months, followed by up to 3 monthly booster sessions
citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

treatment_desc: Participants were given a 64-page booklet providing cognitive behavioral principles for the treatment of PTSD (Understanding Your Reactions to Trauma) and an additional 4-page sheet which focused on common avoidance behaviors and safety-seeking behaviors after motor vehicle accidents; one meeting with a clinician to explain use of the booklet and provide motivation to follow advice in the booklet.
citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

treatment_desc: Single meeting with clinician covering rationale and protocol for assessments and monitoring; regular monitoring with the same assessments and timing as other arms.
citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

treatment_desc: Intensive delivery (5 to 7 days) of Ehlers and Clark’s model of cognitive therapy aimed at reducing the patient’s sense of current threat by identifying and modifying excessively negative appraisals of the trauma, elaborating the trauma memory and discriminating triggers of intrusive re-experiencing, and reducing the use of cognitive strategies and behaviors that maintain the problem. Up to 2 sessions one week and one month after intensive period and up to 3 optional monthly booster sessions.
trauma_detail: child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic death of others, not specified)
citation: Ehlers A, Hackmann A, Grey N, et al. A randomized controlled trial of 7-day intensive and standard weekly cognitive therapy for PTSD and emotion-focused supportive therapy. Am J Psychiatry. 2014 Mar;171(3):294-304. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13040552. PMID: 24480899.

treatment_desc: Standard delivery of Ehlers and Clark’s model of cognitive therapy aimed at reducing the patient’s sense of current threat by identifying and modifying excessively negative appraisals of the trauma, elaborating the trauma memory and discriminating triggers of intrusive re-experiencing, and reducing the use of cognitive strategies and behaviors that maintain the problem.
treatment_duration_qual: plus optional monthly booster session for 3 months
trauma_detail: child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic death of others, not specified)
citation: Ehlers A, Hackmann A, Grey N, et al. A randomized controlled trial of 7-day intensive and standard weekly cognitive therapy for PTSD and emotion-focused supportive therapy. Am J Psychiatry. 2014 Mar;171(3):294-304. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13040552. PMID: 24480899.

treatment_desc: Therapy focused on patients’ emotional reactions rather than their cognitions; designed to provide a credible therapeutic alternative to control for nonspecific therapeutic factors
treatment_duration_qual: plus optional monthly booster session for 3 months
trauma_detail: child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic death of others, not specified)

treatment_desc: Cognitive rehabilitation combining "[goal management training], content-free cueing, and the n-back task, delivers these via a mobile device, and involves support o a family member or friend." Three home visits by a clinical facilitator; mobile applications ("Mind Jogger" for cueing, and "IQ Boost" for n-back task). Family member/friend attended home visits, were given goal management training educational materials, and instructed to provide support and encouragement to veteran participant.
session_length:
Session length:
Home visits: 60 to 90 minutes
Cognitive and goal management training: NR
frequency: Home visits: every 2 months; Cognitive and goal management training: daily
citation: Elbogen EB, Dennis PA, Van Voorhees E,E., et al. Cognitive rehabilitation with mobile technology and social support for veterans with TBI and PTSD: a randomized clinical trial. J Head Trauma Rehabil. 2018. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/htr.0000000000000435. PMID: 30169439

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation on TBI and visual memory training using mobile device. Three home visits by a clinical facilitator; mobile application "Unotan Memory" for visual memory exercises. Family member/friend attended home visits, were given psychoeducational materials on TBI and brain functioning, and instructed to provide support and encouragement to veteran participant.
session_length:
Session length:
Home visits: 60 to 90 minutes
Visual memory training: NR
frequency: Home visits: every 2 months; Visual memory training: daily
psychotherapy_sessions_qual:
Home visits: 2.73 (0.54) (both arms combined);
Visual memory training: 90.77 (57.27);
citation: Elbogen EB, Dennis PA, Van Voorhees E,E., et al. Cognitive rehabilitation with mobile technology and social support for veterans with TBI and PTSD: a randomized clinical trial. J Head Trauma Rehabil. 2018. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/htr.0000000000000435. PMID: 30169439

treatment_desc:
Acupuncture: Hair-thin, solid needles manually inserted into subcutaneous tissue or muscle at specified points. Acupoints include: Urinary Bladder, Liver, Large Intestine, Kidney, Heart, Pericardium, Ren, Du, Ear Shenmen, and Yingtang. 

Usual PTSD care: care as outlined in the VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for Management of Post-Traumatic Stress.
citation: Engel CC, Cordova EH, Benedek DM, et al. Randomized effectiveness trial of a brief course of acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder. Med Care. 2014 Dec;52(12 Suppl 5):S57-64. doi: 10.1097/mlr.0000000000000237. PMID: 25397825.

treatment_desc: Medications and psychotherapy as guided by existing standards, outlined in VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for Management of Post-Traumatic Stress.
citation: Engel CC, Cordova EH, Benedek DM, et al. Randomized effectiveness trial of a brief course of acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder. Med Care. 2014 Dec;52(12 Suppl 5):S57-64. doi: 10.1097/mlr.0000000000000237. PMID: 25397825.

treatment_name: Delivery of Self Training and Education for Stressful Situations-Primary Care version
ncptsd_treatment_name: Delivery of Self Training and Education for Stressful Situations-Primary Care version
treatment_desc:
Online CBT-based and stress inoculation training approach in a Nurse-guided format.

Includes online educational information about PTSD, stress, and trauma. Homework activities on strategies to manage stress and anger, and to promote better sleep hygiene. Training in cognitive reframing techniques.
trauma_detail: combat-related, MST
citation: Engel CC, Litz B, Magruder KM, et al. Delivery of self training and education for stressful situations (DESTRESS-PC): a randomized trial of nurse assisted online self-management for PTSD in primary care. Gen Hosp Psychiatry. 2015 Jul-Aug;37(4):323-8. doi: 10.1016/j.genhosppsych.2015.04.007. PMID: 25929985.

treatment_desc: Consists of usual primary care PTSD treatment augmented with low intensity care management, feedback to the primary care provider, and training of the clinic providers in management of PTSD.
trauma_detail: combat-related, MST
citation: Engel CC, Litz B, Magruder KM, et al. Delivery of self training and education for stressful situations (DESTRESS-PC): a randomized trial of nurse assisted online self-management for PTSD in primary care. Gen Hosp Psychiatry. 2015 Jul-Aug;37(4):323-8. doi: 10.1016/j.genhosppsych.2015.04.007. PMID: 25929985.

treatment_desc: Integrated, collaborative care for PTSD and depression with telecare central specialist support/services. Nurse care managers provided basic psychosocial support, monitored/encouraged medication and psychotherapy adherence, connected participants to specialty services, and helped participants make evidence-based treatment decisions; stepped pharmacologic and specialty mental health services with online cognitive-behavioral self-management, CBT by telephone with psychologist, and site therapists for face-to-face psychotherapy; central symptom registry for identification of those in need of treatment change; central specialist/services with psychiatrist for treatment monitoring and suggestions to primary care provider, psychologist delivering CBT by telephone and training/coaching care managers, and care manager to support other care managers and participants who moved, left the military, etc.
citation: Engel CC, Jaycox LH, Freed MC, et al. Centrally assisted collaborative telecare for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among military personnel attending primary care: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Intern Med. 2016 Jul 1;176(7):948-56. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2016.2402. PMID: 27294447.

treatment_name: Re-Engineering Systems of Primary Care Treatment in the Military
treatment_desc: Treatment as usual with the RESPECT-Mil program. Integrated mental health for PTSD and depression using 3-component model: 1) screening at each clinic visit and use of symptom severity tools for diagnosis and assessment; 2) monthly contact by nurse care managers, who provided symptom status to the primary care clinician; 3) increased access to non-primary care clinic-based mental health specialists.
citation: Engel CC, Jaycox LH, Freed MC, et al. Centrally assisted collaborative telecare for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among military personnel attending primary care: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Intern Med. 2016 Jul 1;176(7):948-56. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2016.2402. PMID: 27294447.

treatment_desc: Treatment followed the "Patient Manual and Therapy Manual" by Falsetti and Resnick. Treatment included components of CPT adapted from Resick & Schnicke (1993) and "Mastery of Your Anxiety and Panic" by Barlow & Craske (1988, 1994). Participants were presented with cognitive-behavioral models of PTSD and panic, and participated in exposures directed at physiological, cognitive, and behavioral channels of anxiety.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Falsetti SA, Resnick HS, Davis JL. Multiple channel exposure therapy for women with PTSD and comorbid panic attacks. Cogn Behav Ther. 2008;37(2):117-30. doi: 10.1080/16506070801969088. PMID: 18470742.

treatment_desc: Participants were contacted by phone every 2 weeks and offered supportive counseling
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Falsetti SA, Resnick HS, Davis JL. Multiple channel exposure therapy for women with PTSD and comorbid panic attacks. Cogn Behav Ther. 2008;37(2):117-30. doi: 10.1080/16506070801969088. PMID: 18470742.

treatment_desc: SSRI; titrated in 12.5 mg increments (1 capsule) to maximum of 5 capsules as tolerated over 8-week medication adjustment period
dose: 12.5 to 62.5 mg; titration: initiated at 12.5 mg, titrated to maximum 62.5 mg over 8 weeks
trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma)
citation: Fani N, Kitayama N, Ashraf A, et al. Neuropsychological functioning in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder following short-term paroxetine treatment. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2009 Jan 1;42(1):53-68.  PMID: 19204651.

treatment_desc: Placebo started at 1 capsule per day, increased by 1 capsule per study visit as tolerated, up to 5 capsules per day during 8 week medication adjustment period.
dose: 1 to 5 capsules (paroxetine equivalent 12.5 to 62.5 mg); titration: initiated at 1 capsule increased as tolerated to maximum of 5 capsules over 8 weeks
trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma)
citation: Fani N, Kitayama N, Ashraf A, et al. Neuropsychological functioning in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder following short-term paroxetine treatment. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2009 Jan 1;42(1):53-68.  PMID: 19204651.

treatment_desc: Treatment included education about post-trauma reactions, relaxation training, imaginal exposure therapy with cognitive restructuring, instruction for self-directed graduated in-vivo behavior practice.
citation: Fecteau GW, Nicki RM. Cognitive behavioural treatment of post traumatic stress disorder after motor vehicle accident. Behav. Cogn. Psychother. 1999 Jul;27(3):201-14.
Fecteau GW, Nicki RM. Cognitive behavioural treatment of post traumatic stress disorder after motor vehicle accident. Behav. Cogn. Psychother. 1999 Jul;27(3):201-14.

dose: 0.5 mg/kg

treatment_desc: SSRI + adhesive electrode pads placed 1 cm radial to Nei-Guan (PC6) with minimum stimulation fro 30 seconds then ramped off over next 15 seconds
dose: Sertraline initiated at 25 mg/day titrated up to 100 mg/d over 7 days
def_treatment_adherence: pill counted daily

treatment_desc: Treatment adhered to manual by Foa, Hearst-Ikeda, Dancu, Hembree & Jaycox (1997), which included breathing retraining, and imaginal and in vivo exposure. In session 8, participants with <70% improvement on PTSD outcome were encouraged to participate in additional 3 PE sessions
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence

session_length:
Individual session: 60 minutes

Group session: 90 minutes

PE augmented with oxytocin

PE: individual, manualized, trauma-focused CBT

Oxytocin: hypothalamic neuropeptide; self-administered intranasal spray 45 minutes prior to PE therapy (sessions 2 through 9)

treatment_desc: Prolonged exposure with repeated imaginal exposures, processing the memory, and homework including in vivo exposure. Naltrexone starting dose given for a minimum of 3 days and titrated up within 1 week. All patients also received supportive counseling including medication management, adherence monitoring, and education about alcohol dependency.
dose: Start at 50 mg up to 100 mg
frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Naltrexone: daily
def_treatment_adherence: ≥80% adherence to medication and attendance at supportive counseling. Naltrexone given with 100 mg riboflavin, and urine riboflavin tests were used to monitor medication compliance; pill counts also used
trauma_detail: Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (not specified)
citation: Foa EB, Yusko DA, McLean CP, et al. Concurrent naltrexone and prolonged exposure therapy for patients with comorbid alcohol dependence and PTSD: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2013 Aug 7;310(5):488-95. doi: 10.1001/jama.2013.8268. PMID: 23925619.

treatment_desc: Prolonged exposure with repeated imaginal exposures, processing the memory, and homework including in vivo exposure. Placebo identical to naltrexone given at starting dose for a minimum of 3 days and titrated up within 1 week. All patients also received supportive counseling including medication management, adherence monitoring, and education about alcohol dependency.
dose: Start with placebo tablet identical to 50 mg naltrexone, titrate up to 100 mg
frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Placebo: daily

treatment_desc: Smoking cessation counseling (20 to 30 minutes) followed by PE (90 minutes) including imaginal exposure and in vivo exposure with weekly homework. dose: Dose: 1.0 mg (after titration)

treatment_desc: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, description of treatment method and rationale, and explanation for origin of fear and anxiety. Seven sessions comprised of breathing exercises, deep muscle relaxation, thought stopping to counter ruminative or obsessive thinking, cognitive restructuring, guided self-dialogue, covert modeling, and role-playing.
citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

treatment_desc: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, explanation of treatment rationale and treatment planning. Seven sessions comprised of imaginal exposure in which participants were instructed to imagine reliving the assault in vivid detail while describing it aloud, using present tense, and repeating for approximately 60 minutes of the session. Homework as at least once daily listening to tape-recorded narrative, with additional homework including in vivo exposure.
citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

treatment_desc: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, explanation of treatment rationale and treatment planning. Seven sessions in which participants were taught a general problem-solving technique with therapists in unconditionally supportive role. Homework with diary-keeping of daily problems and attempts at problem solving. Participants were immediately redirected to focus on current daily problems if discussion of assault occurred.
citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

treatment_desc: Individual treatment following manual; 2 sessions included information gathering, treatment rationale, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy, and in vivo homework; remaining sessions included homework review, imaginal exposure, and homework assignment; homework to listen to tape recordings of imaginal exposure from sessions, and in vivo exposure.
session_length:
120 minutes for 2 sessions
90 minutes for 7 sessions
def_treatment_completion: did not drop out of treatment
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
citation: Foa EB, Dancu CV, Hembree EA, et al. A comparison of exposure therapy, stress inoculation training, and their combination for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder in female assault victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999;67(2):194.  PMID: 10224729.

treatment_desc: Individual treatment following manual, program adapted from Veronen and Kilpatrick (1983); 2 sessions included information gathering, breathing retraining, and treatment rationale and planning; remaining 7 sessions focused on coping skills for management of assault-related anxiety and postassault problems; coping skills included: deep muscle relaxation, cue-controlled and differential relaxation, thought stopping, cognitive restructuring, guided self-dialogue, covert modeling, and role-play. Homework to practice the coping skills to manage anxiety and fear in daily activities. Explicit in vivo homework instructions were omitted.
session_length:
120 minutes for 2 sessions
90 minutes for 7 sessions
def_treatment_completion: did not drop out of treatment
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence

treatment_desc: Individual treatment following manual; combination of PE and SIT included education, training on SIT coping skills, in vivo exposure, and imaginal exposure; homework assigned for exposure and coping skill practice
session_length: 120 minutes for first 2 sessions, 90 minutes for remaining 7 sessions

treatment_desc: Manualized procedures according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum 2007. Nonresponders continued through Session 12

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy (Ford, 2015) including psychoeducation, eliciting day triggers for PTSD alarm reactions and teaching skills to inhibit impulsive emotional and behavioral reactions. Intervention teaches the "Slow down, Orient Self-check" skill and other skills to replace alarm reaction with emotional self-regulation.

treatment_desc: Off-site PTSD care team used telemedicine technology to support the PTSD treatment delivered by clinic providers. treatment_desc: PE therapy delivered via streaming-video calls using Tango (free application downloaded to the phone which uses the 3G network); no changes made to PE treatment other than mode of delivery. Participants loaned an iPhone 4 with service plans for duration of treatment.

treatment_desc:
Modified application of traditional CPT (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2008); primary modifications: length of intervention individually tailored with conclusion based on predefined specified end-state criterion (4 to 18 possible sessions); up to 2 optional "stressor sessions" offered when a participant experienced a significant psychosocial stressor or emergency during the course of therapy, and participant's choice whether to use the stressor session.
End-state criterion for termination of treatment: PDS ≤20, BDI ≤18, agreement between the therapist and participant that treatment goals had been attained, and negative PTSD status on CAPS by blind rater.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
citation: Galovski TE, Blain LM, Mott JM, et al. Manualized therapy for PTSD: flexing the structure of cognitive processing therapy. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2012 Dec;80(6):968-81. doi: 10.1037/a0030600. PMID: 23106761.

treatment_desc: Daily monitoring of PTSD and depressive symptoms; 3 phone interviews for CAPS administration and inquiry into progress on symptom monitoring, overall symptom severity, and general distress but without cognitive therapy or other trauma-focused intervention.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
citation: Galovski TE, Blain LM, Mott JM, et al. Manualized therapy for PTSD: flexing the structure of cognitive processing therapy. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2012 Dec;80(6):968-81. doi: 10.1037/a0030600. PMID: 23106761.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Sleep-directed hypnosis followed by Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
treatment_desc:
Sleep-directed hypnosis for 3 weeks followed by 12 weeks of CPT.

Scripted hypnosis targeting sleep impairment (no trauma-related material) with focus on sleep onset difficulty and mid-sleep awakening and inability to fall back to sleep; utilized psychoeducation, hypnotic trance using eye fixation technique, guided imagery and redirection of mental activity. Participants instructed to practice daily using audiotape of hypnosis session.

CPT targeting interpretations of the trauma itself and then current and future maladaptive and inaccurate beliefs about world, self and others; patients taught to identify, question, challenge and replace faulty assumptions and thoughts about traumatic event and its implications in their current life.
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
citation: Galovski TE, Harik JM, Blain LM, et al. Augmenting cognitive processing therapy to improve sleep impairment in PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2016 Feb;84(2):167-77. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000059. PMID: 26689303.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Sleep and symptom monitoring followed by Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
treatment_desc:
Sleep and symptom monitoring for 3 weeks followed by 12 weeks of CPT.

Daily monitoring of PTSD, depressive symptoms, and sleep, with weekly phone checks.

CPT targeting interpretations of the trauma itself and then current and future maladaptive and inaccurate beliefs about world, self and others; patients taught to identify, question, challenge and replace faulty assumptions and thoughts about traumatic event and its implications in their current life.

Symptom monitoring: NA

CPT sessions: 60 minutes

treatment_desc: Treatment includes psychoeducation for anxiety management and exposure to traumatic event through a Z800 head-mounted display (e-Magin Corp) that displays a footpath surrounded by dense vegetation where participants had to follow a column of virtual soldiers. Ambush, gun firing, motor, and waiting for evacuation near an injured soldier were added gradually each session
citation: Gamito P, Oliveira J, Rosa P, et al. PTSD elderly war veterans: a clinical controlled pilot study. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):43-8. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2009.0237. PMID: 20528292.

treatment_desc: Treatment includes psychoeducation for anxiety management and imaginal exposure

treatment_desc: EEG biofeedback with sensors placed at T3-T4. Training parameters followed flexible, principle-based manual with defined rules to adjust reward frequency and training time; reward frequency adjusted based on the participant's clinical response (number of over- or under-arousal symptoms); training time increased in 3-minute increments when participant reported positive change.
dose:
inhibit frequencies: 4 to 7 Hz and 22 to 36 Hz
reward frequency: 12 to 15 Hz
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, other (not specified)
citation: Gapen MA, van der Kolk BA, Hamlin E, et al. A pilot study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2016 Sep;41(3):251-61. doi: 10.1007/s10484-015-9326-5. PMID: 26782083.

treatment_desc: EEG biofeedback with sensors placed at T4-P4. Training parameters followed flexible, principle-based manual; inhibit frequencies: 4-7 Hz and 22-36 Hz; reward frequency: initial 12-15 Hz, adjusted based on the participant's clinical response (number of over- or under-arousal symptoms); training time increased in 3-minute increments when participant reported positive change.
dose:
inhibit frequencies: 4 to 7 Hz and 22 to 36 Hz
reward frequency: 12 to 15 Hz

treatment_desc: Activity-based sport intervention (sailing) that seeks to empower participant, change negative self-image, enhance self-efficacy, hope, and the ability to enjoy life, to develop control over symptoms, and improve social and emotional regulation skills. Each session began with a summary of previous lesson, followed by sailing in a group and different sea-related activities. Session ends with a debrief and discussion of sailing-related and personal issues
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
citation: Gelkopf M, Hasson-Ohayon I, Bikman M, et al. Nature adventure rehabilitation for combat-related posttraumatic chronic stress disorder: a randomized control trial. Psychiatry Res. 2013 Oct 30;209(3):485-93. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2013.01.026. PMID: 23541513.

Gelkopf M, Hasson-Ohayon I, Bikman M, et al. Nature adventure rehabilitation for combat-related posttraumatic chronic stress disorder: a randomized control trial. Psychiatry Res. 2013 Oct 30;209(3):485-93. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2013.01.026. PMID: 23541513.

treatment_desc: Treatment followed The EFT Manual (Craig & Fowlie 1995; Church, 2013) where therapists guided participants through traumatic emotional events until emotional intensity reduces via office or telephone sessions or televideo conferencing calls. All participants received usual care by primary care provider
citation: Geronilla L, Minewiser L, Mollon P, et al. EFT (Emotional Freedom Techniques) remediates PTSD and psychological symptoms in veterans: A randomized controlled replication trial. Energy Psychology. 2016;8(2):29.

treatment_desc: Participants received usual care by primary care provider and completed a 30-day waiting period
citation: Geronilla L, Minewiser L, Mollon P, et al. EFT (Emotional Freedom Techniques) remediates PTSD and psychological symptoms in veterans: A randomized controlled replication trial. Energy Psychology. 2016;8(2):29.

treatment_desc: Individualized psychotherapy, consisting of psychoeducation, imaginary guidance, writing assignments and mementos, domain of meaning or integration, and a farewell ritual

treatment_desc: Participants monitored by a nonassessor psychologist

treatment_desc: Treatment delivered using manual; elements included: psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal exposure with processing or discussion of the content during session, and in vivo exposure.

treatment_desc: Treatment delivered using manual; content shared directed by client with therapist offering support with respect to trauma related memories; elements included: psychoeducation, breathing retraining, reviewing daily difficulties as a manifestation of PTSD related to trauma (without directive imaginal exposure).
trauma_detail: natural or manmade disaster, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement

treatment_desc: Combine aerobic and resistance exercise with yoga poses presented within a framework of mindfulness principles based on the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction and Mindful Breathing principles

treatment_desc: Participants could participate in Integrative Exercise after 12 weeks of waiting period
citation: Goldstein LA, Mehling WE, Metzler TJ, et al. Veterans group exercise: a randomized pilot trial of an integrative exercise program for veterans with posttraumatic stress. J Affect Disord. 2018 Feb;227:345-52. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2017.11.002. PMID: 29145076.

treatment_desc: Antiprogestogen
dose: 600 mg
citation: Golier JA, Caramanica K, Demaria R, et al. A pilot study of mifepristone in combat-related PTSD. Depress Res Treat. 2012;2012:393251. doi: 10.1155/2012/393251. PMID: 22611490.

treatment_desc: Matched placebo
citation: Golier JA, Caramanica K, Demaria R, et al. A pilot study of mifepristone in combat-related PTSD. Depress Res Treat. 2012;2012:393251. doi: 10.1155/2012/393251. PMID: 22611490.

treatment_desc: Brief, non-traumatizing trauma-focused CBT in which a consolidated trauma memory is reactivated using a brief narrative, then patients are presented with healthy dissociative distancing experiences and exercises to modify the perceptual structure of the memory
trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)

trauma_detail: MST, combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)

treatment_desc: Supervised community-based exercise training for older veterans; integrates cognitive behavioral strategies during exercise program, targeting 5 sources of self-efficacy: "(1) self-monitoring and mastery experi- ence; (2) education of physiologic responses to exercise; (3) outcome expectations; (4) barriers to participation; and (5) modeling and social support". Includes individual exercise prescription, with one-on-one and independent exercises which emphasized "aerobic, strength, balance, and flexibility exercises. Modalities included body weight, free weight, cables, and exercise bands; treadmills and stationary bikes were used for aerobic training".
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
psychotherapy_sessions_qual: 82% (range 23 to 100%) (of participants who attended at least one session)
citation: Hall KS, Morey MC, Bosworth HB, et al. Pilot randomized controlled trial of exercise training for older veterans with PTSD. J Behav Med. 2019 Jul 1doi: 10.1007/s10865-019-00073-w. PMID: 31264055.

treatment_desc: Continued usual care in VA clinics.
citation: Hall KS, Morey MC, Bosworth HB, et al. Pilot randomized controlled trial of exercise training for older veterans with PTSD. J Behav Med. 2019 Jul 1doi: 10.1007/s10865-019-00073-w. PMID: 31264055.

treatment_desc: Placebo augmentation to sertraline or paroxetine (open-label sertraline or paroxetine during phase 1 of study; see comments for phase 1 details).
dose: Comparable dosing to ziprasidone 120 to 160 mg
dose_at_study_end_point_qual: all individuals reached targeted dosing range

treatment_desc: Ziprasidone augmentation to sertraline or paroxetine (open-label sertraline or paroxetine during phase 1 of study; see comments for phase 1 details).
dose: 120 to 160 mg total daily dose, as tolerated
dose_at_study_end_point_qual: all individuals reached targeted dosing range
