[Erratum appears in J Psychopharmacol. 2011;25(6):852.] J Psychopharmacol. 2010 June;25(4):439-52. doi: 10.1177/0269881110378371.

treatment_desc: MDMA, a psychoactive compound scheduled in the U.S. as a drug of abuse (ecstasy), and also used as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received both MDMA-assisted "non-directive or client-directed" therapy sessions, following a treatment manual with a male or female co-therapy team, and additional non-drug therapy sessions.
dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, nondrug sessions 90 minutes

Dose: 125 mg (followed 1.5 to 2 hours later by an optional supplemental dose of half the initial dose)
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (firefighter/police officer)
citation: Mithoefer MC, Mithoefer AT, Feduccia AA, et al. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans, firefighters, and police officers: a randomised, double-blind, dose-response, phase 2 clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Jun;5(6):486-97. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30135-4. PMID: 29728331.

treatment_desc: MDMA, a psychoactive compound scheduled in the U.S. as a drug of abuse (ecstasy), and also used as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patient received both MDMA-assisted "non-directive or client-directed" therapy sessions, following a treatment manual with a male or female co-therapy team, and additional non-drug therapy sessions.
dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, non-drug sessions 90 minutes

Dose: 75 mg  (followed 1.5 to 2 hours later by an optional supplemental dose of half the initial dose, but NR on final cumulative dose)
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (firefighter/police officer)
citation: Mithoefer MC, Mithoefer AT, Feduccia AA, et al. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans, firefighters, and police officers: a randomised, double-blind, dose-response, phase 2 clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Jun;5(6):486-97. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30135-4. PMID: 29728331.

treatment_desc: MDMA used as an active control, as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients  received both MDMA-assisted "non-directive or client-directed" therapy sessions, following a treatment manual with a male or female co-therapy team, and additional non-drug therapy sessions.
dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, non-drug sessions 90 minutes

Dose: 30 mg  (followed 1.5 to 2 hours later by an optional supplemental dose of half the initial dose)
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (firefighter/police officer)
citation: Mithoefer MC, Mithoefer AT, Feduccia AA, et al. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans, firefighters, and police officers: a randomised, double-blind, dose-response, phase 2 clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Jun;5(6):486-97. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30135-4. PMID: 29728331.

treatment_desc: Manualized CBT treatment protocol with virtual reality exposure showing combat environment
citation: Miyahira SD, Folen RA, Hoffman HG, et al. The effectiveness of VR exposure therapy for PTSD in returning warfighters. Stud Health Technol Inform. 2012;181:128-32.  PMID: 22954842.

treatment_desc: Brief telephone contacts
citation: Miyahira SD, Folen RA, Hoffman HG, et al. The effectiveness of VR exposure therapy for PTSD in returning warfighters. Stud Health Technol Inform. 2012;181:128-32.  PMID: 22954842.

treatment_desc: CPT according to Resick (2001), CBT with primary focus on cognitive interventions and includes exposure to traumatic memory through writing and reading accounts
citation: Monson CM, Schnurr PP, Resick PA, et al. Cognitive processing therapy for veterans with military-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2006 Oct;74(5):898-907. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.74.5.898. PMID: 17032094.

Monson CM, Schnurr PP, Resick PA, et al. Cognitive processing therapy for veterans with military-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2006 Oct;74(5):898-907. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.74.5.898. PMID: 17032094.

treatment_desc: Includes 3 phases that include both in- and out-of-session exercises. Phase I: establishing rationale for therapy and relationship safety. Phase 2: Avoidance. Phase 3: Influence of trauma on relationship trust, control, emotional closeness, and physical intimacy
frequency: Twice weekly for phases 1 and 2, weekly during phase 3.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Monson CM, Fredman SJ, Macdonald A, et al. Effect of cognitive-behavioral couple therapy for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2012 Aug 15;308(7):700-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2012.9307. PMID: 22893167.

treatment_desc: Wait for 3 months before receiving treatment
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Monson CM, Fredman SJ, Macdonald A, et al. Effect of cognitive-behavioral couple therapy for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2012 Aug 15;308(7):700-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2012.9307. PMID: 22893167.

treatment_desc: Training group sessions following manual; aim of treatment is to enhance the specificity with which participants retrieve personal events from their autobiographical memory; uses concepts of specific vs over general memories; sessions involve training using neutral, positive, and negative cues, recall exercises and homework.
citation: Moradi AR, Moshirpanahi S, Parhon H, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of Memory Specificity Training in improving symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 May;56:68-74. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.03.002. PMID: 24705337.

treatment_desc: No additional contact.
citation: Moradi AR, Moshirpanahi S, Parhon H, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of Memory Specificity Training in improving symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 May;56:68-74. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.03.002. PMID: 24705337.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused treatment according to Schauer et al. (2011)
citation: Morath J, Gola H, Sommershof A, et al. The effect of trauma-focused therapy on the altered T cell distribution in individuals with PTSD: evidence from a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2014 Jul;54:1-10. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2014.03.016. PMID: 24726027.

Morath J, Gola H, Sommershof A, et al. The effect of trauma-focused therapy on the altered T cell distribution in individuals with PTSD: evidence from a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2014 Jul;54:1-10. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2014.03.016. PMID: 24726027.

treatment_desc: Individual PE delivered by home-based telehealth; includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal and in vivo exposure. Number of sessions dependent on treatment response - early responders "could graduate before attending 15 sessions if they completed six or seven sessions of PE and had PCL‐5 scores <21 for two consecutive sessions" or PCL-5 score <30 (cutoff score for PCL-5 revised during study).
citation: Morland L, Mackintosh MA, Glassman L, et al. Home-based delivery of variable length prolonged exposure therapy: a comparison of clinical efficacy between service modalities. 2019 Dec 24. doi: 10.1002/da.22979. PMID: 31872563.

treatment_desc: In-home-in-person individual PE; includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal and in vivo exposure. Number of sessions dependent on treatment response - early responders "could graduate before attending 15 sessions if they completed six or seven sessions of PE and had PCL‐5 scores <21 for two consecutive sessions" or PCL-5 score <30 (cutoff score for PCL-5 revised during study).
citation: Morland L, Mackintosh MA, Glassman L, et al. Home-based delivery of variable length prolonged exposure therapy: a comparison of clinical efficacy between service modalities. 2019 Dec 24. doi: 10.1002/da.22979. PMID: 31872563.

treatment_desc: Individual PE delivered in office-based telehealth; includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal and in vivo exposure. Number of sessions dependent on treatment response - early responders "could graduate before attending 15 sessions if they completed six or seven sessions of PE and had PCL‐5 scores <21 for two consecutive sessions" or PCL-5 score <30 (cutoff score for PCL-5 revised during study).
citation: Morland L, Mackintosh MA, Glassman L, et al. Home-based delivery of variable length prolonged exposure therapy: a comparison of clinical efficacy between service modalities. 2019 Dec 24. doi: 10.1002/da.22979. PMID: 31872563.

treatment_name: Group CPT-cognitive only delivered via videoteleconferencing
treatment_desc: Variant of CPT that excludes the written trauma narrative. Modified version includes psychoeducation, skill building exercises, and practice strategies to restructure thoughts
citation: Morland LA, Mackintosh M-A, Greene CJ, et al. Cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder delivered to rural veterans via telemental health: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2014;75(5):470-6. doi: 10.4088/JCP.13m08842. PMID: 24922484.

treatment_desc: Variant of CPT that excludes the written trauma narrative. Modified version includes psychoeducation, skill building exercises, and practice strategies to restructure thoughts
citation: Morland LA, Mackintosh M-A, Greene CJ, et al. Cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder delivered to rural veterans via telemental health: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2014;75(5):470-6. doi: 10.4088/JCP.13m08842. PMID: 24922484.

treatment_desc: Individual manualized cognitive processing therapy delivered by video teleconferencing
def_treatment_adherence: number of assignments completed
citation: Morland LA, Mackintosh MA, Rosen CS, et al. Telemedicine versus in-person delivery of cognitive processing therapy for women with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Nov;32(11):811-20. doi: 10.1002/da.22397. PMID: 26243685.

treatment_desc: Individual manualized cognitive processing therapy delivered in person
citation: Morland LA, Mackintosh MA, Rosen CS, et al. Telemedicine versus in-person delivery of cognitive processing therapy for women with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Nov;32(11):811-20. doi: 10.1002/da.22397. PMID: 26243685.

treatment_desc: Program includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, and cognitive restructuring
trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Mueser KT, Rosenberg SD, Xie HY, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive-behavioral treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in severe mental illness. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):259-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.259. PMID: 18377122.

trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Mueser KT, Rosenberg SD, Xie HY, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive-behavioral treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in severe mental illness. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):259-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.259. PMID: 18377122.

treatment_desc: CBT program including breath retraining and cognitive restructuring
citation: Mueser KT, Gottlieb JD, Xie H, et al. Evaluation of cognitive restructuring for post-traumatic stress disorder in people with severe mental illness. Br J Psychiatry. 2015 Jun;206(6):501-8. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.114.147926. PMID: 25858178.

treatment_desc: Includes breathing retraining and educational components of the CBT program
citation: Mueser KT, Gottlieb JD, Xie H, et al. Evaluation of cognitive restructuring for post-traumatic stress disorder in people with severe mental illness. Br J Psychiatry. 2015 Jun;206(6):501-8. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.114.147926. PMID: 25858178.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused individual therapy; sessions included: psychoeducation about trauma and related symptoms, treatment rationale and description, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and discussion/processing, as well as in vivo homework assignments between sessions.
trauma_detail: combat-related, terrorism/political violence
citation: Nacasch N, Foa EB, Huppert JD, et al. Prolonged exposure therapy for combat- and terror-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized control comparison with treatment as usual. J Clin Psychiatry. 2011 Sep;72(9):1174-80. doi: 10.4088/JCP.09m05682blu. PMID: 21208581.

treatment_desc: Usual treatment with nondirective, psychodynamically oriented therapy and/or medication and counseling; therapy delivered by the same therapists as the PE intervention and was not focused on the traumatic event.
trauma_detail: combat-related, terrorism/political violence
citation: Nacasch N, Foa EB, Huppert JD, et al. Prolonged exposure therapy for combat- and terror-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized control comparison with treatment as usual. J Clin Psychiatry. 2011 Sep;72(9):1174-80. doi: 10.4088/JCP.09m05682blu. PMID: 21208581.

treatment_desc: Short-duration PE therapy according to treatment manual for PE (Foa et al., 2007), with imaginal exposure portion limited to 20 minutes of a 60-minute session. The first 2 sessions (pre-randomization) included treatment rationale, information gathering about trauma history, most disturbing trauma, breathing retraining, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy and homework assignments. Remaining sessions (postrandomization) included homework review, imaginal exposure for 20 minutes followed by processing, and assignment of in vivo exposure homework.
session_length:
Session length: 60 minutes
Imaginal exposure portion: 20 minutes
def_treatment_completion: Supervisor and therapist agreed that the patient's self-reported symptoms of PTSD remained low and stable (minimum 10, maximum 15 sessions)
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, accidents
citation: Nacasch N, Huppert JD, Su Y-J, et al. Are 60-minute prolonged exposure sessions with 20-minute imaginal exposure to traumatic memories sufficient to successfully treat PTSD? A randomized nonininferiority clinical trial. Behav Ther. 2015 May;46(3):328-41. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2014.12.002. PMID: 25892169.

treatment_desc: Long-duration (typical) PE therapy according to treatment manual for PE (Foa et al., 2007), with imaginal exposure portion of 40 minutes and a 90-minute session. The first 2 sessions (prerandomization) included treatment rationale, information gathering about trauma history, most disturbing trauma, breathing retraining, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy and homework assignments. Remaining sessions (postrandomization) included homework review, imaginal exposure for 40 minutes followed by processing, and assignment of in vivo exposure homework.
session_length:
Session length: 90 minutes
Imaginal exposure portion: 40 minutes
def_treatment_completion: Supervisor and therapist agreed that the patient's self-reported symptoms of PTSD remained low and stable (minimum 10, maximum 15 sessions)
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, accidents
citation: Nacasch N, Huppert JD, Su Y-J, et al. Are 60-minute prolonged exposure sessions with 20-minute imaginal exposure to traumatic memories sufficient to successfully treat PTSD? A randomized nonininferiority clinical trial. Behav Ther. 2015 May;46(3):328-41. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2014.12.002. PMID: 25892169.

treatment_desc: Individual, past-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy for PTSD/SUD; covered 17 topics relevant to both PTSD and SUD. Both interventions included "a check-in, inspirational quotation, handouts, and check-out"; participants also allowed to "attend nonstudy therapies and supports including 12-step self-help groups, except for current PTSD or PTSD/SUD evidence-based therapy models."
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (NR)
citation: Najavits LM, Krinsley K, Waring ME, et al. A randomized controlled trial for veterans with PTSD and substance use disorder: creating change versus seeking safety. Subst Use Misuse. 2018 Sep 19;53(11):1788-800. doi: 10.1080/10826084.2018.1432653. PMID: 29461920.

treatment_desc: Individual, present-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy for PTSD/SUD; 17 of the 25 topics in Seeking Safety were used in order to keep dose of therapy the same between interventions (the 17 topics were same for all participants). Both interventions included "a check-in, inspirational quotation, handouts, and check-out"; participants also allowed to "attend nonstudy therapies and supports including 12-step self-help groups, except for current PTSD or PTSD/SUD evidence-based therapy models."
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (NR)
citation: Najavits LM, Krinsley K, Waring ME, et al. A randomized controlled trial for veterans with PTSD and substance use disorder: creating change versus seeking safety. Subst Use Misuse. 2018 Sep 19;53(11):1788-800. doi: 10.1080/10826084.2018.1432653. PMID: 29461920.

treatment_desc: Low-frequency rTMS to the right prefrontal cortex
dose: 1 Hz at 100% motor threshold, 18,000 pulses total
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Nam D-H, Pae C-U, Chae J-H. Low-frequency, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for the treatment of patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, sham-controlled study. Clin Psychopharmacol Neurosci. 2013 Aug;11(2):96-102. doi: 10.9758/cpn.2013.11.2.96. PMID: 24023554.

treatment_desc: Identical rTMS treatment except lateral wing of coil raised 90 degrees off the head, with edge of medial wing of the coil still touching scalp.
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Nam D-H, Pae C-U, Chae J-H. Low-frequency, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for the treatment of patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, sham-controlled study. Clin Psychopharmacol Neurosci. 2013 Aug;11(2):96-102. doi: 10.9758/cpn.2013.11.2.96. PMID: 24023554.

treatment_desc: Second-generation antipsychotic augmentation; all patients also continued baseline antidepressant treatment for PTSD. Following a 2-week placebo lead-in, aripiprazole 5 mg/day taken for 2 weeks, 5 to 10 mg/day for 2 weeks, 5 to 15 mg/day for 2 weeks, and finally 5 to 20 mg/day taken for 2 weeks.
dose: Initiated at 5 mg, titrated to maximum 20 mg
citation: Naylor JC, Kilts JD, Bradford DW, et al. A pilot randomized placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive aripiprazole for chronic PTSD in US military veterans resistant to antidepressant treatment. Int. Clin Psychopharmacol. 2015;30(3):167-74. doi: 10.1097/YIC.0000000000000061. PMID: 25647451.

treatment_desc: Augmentation with placebo capsules identical to active drug; all patients also continued baseline antidepressant treatment for PTSD. Double-blind treatment followed a 2-week placebo lead-in.
citation: Naylor JC, Kilts JD, Bradford DW, et al. A pilot randomized placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive aripiprazole for chronic PTSD in US military veterans resistant to antidepressant treatment. Int. Clin Psychopharmacol. 2015;30(3):167-74. doi: 10.1097/YIC.0000000000000061. PMID: 25647451.

treatment_desc: Carried out according to manual by Schauer et al. (2005). Participants construct a chronological account of his own biography. Then the counselor discussed traumatic experiences with focus on current emotional, physiological, cognitive, and behavioral reactions to the experience until habituation of the emotional reactions
citation: Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

treatment_desc: Counselors address psychological and social needs expressed by the participant by relating current problems to past traumatic experiences. Counselors can use narrative exposure of traumatic events as part of therapy, but is not required
citation: Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

treatment_desc: Intervention according to manual by Schauer et al. (2005) containing psychoeducation and participants narrating their biography
citation: Neuner F, Kurreck S, Ruf M, et al. Can asylum-seekers with posttraumatic stress disorder be successfully treated? A randomized controlled pilot study. Cogn Behav Ther. 2010;39(2):81-91. doi: 10.1080/16506070903121042. PMID: 19816834.

treatment_desc: Participants encouraged to continue their current treatment or were referred to institutions of public mental health care
citation: Neuner F, Kurreck S, Ruf M, et al. Can asylum-seekers with posttraumatic stress disorder be successfully treated? A randomized controlled pilot study. Cogn Behav Ther. 2010;39(2):81-91. doi: 10.1080/16506070903121042. PMID: 19816834.

treatment_desc: Centrally acting alpha-2 receptor agonist
dose: 0.5 mg at week 1, titrated by 0.5 mg per week up to 1 to 3 mg
def_treatment_adherence: assessed by pill count
citation: Neylan TC, Lenoci M, Samuelson KW, et al. No improvement of posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms with guanfacine treatment. Am J Psychiatry. 2006 Dec;163(12):2186-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.12.2186. PMID: 17151174.

treatment_desc: Placebo
def_treatment_adherence: assessed by pill count
citation: Neylan TC, Lenoci M, Samuelson KW, et al. No improvement of posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms with guanfacine treatment. Am J Psychiatry. 2006 Dec;163(12):2186-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.12.2186. PMID: 17151174.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused behavioural treatment with graduated exposure to imaginal and in-vivo trauma experiences delivered Individually. Homework involved listening to imaginal and engaging in in-vivo exposures.
trauma_detail: MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

treatment_desc: Health education specific to PTSD veterans, including symptoms, negative coping behaviors, and healthy lifestyle. Group sessions fostered social support and personal expression
trauma_detail: MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

treatment_desc: Sitting meditation with eyes closed to quiet thoughts; PTSD symptoms not specifically addressed. Meditation technique taught in 5 sessions on consecutive days in a group format with lectures and some one-on-one instruction. Seven group maintenance sessions taught over the rest of the 3-month period. Home practice of two 20-minute daily sessions encouraged.
frequency: Daily for 5 days then on average every 11 days ("gradually spaced")
trauma_detail: MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, cognitive restructuring and writing assignments
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (war-related)
citation: Nijdam MJ, Gersons BP, Reitsma JB, et al. Brief eclectic psychotherapy v. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;200(3):224-31. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.111.099234. PMID: 22322458.

treatment_desc: During EMDR therapy, the most distressing images of the traumatic event are identified and processed consecutively. After the patient has focused on an image with the corresponding negative cognition, the most distressing emotion and the bodily location of the emotion, the patient is continuously asked to follow the therapist’s finger making saccadic movements in alternation with the patient’s own associations.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (war-related)
citation: Nijdam MJ, Gersons BP, Reitsma JB, et al. Brief eclectic psychotherapy v. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;200(3):224-31. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.111.099234. PMID: 22322458.

treatment_desc: 2 in-person sessions and 6 phone sessions; participants given Mindfulness Handbook which covered mindfulness topics: defining mindfulness, noticing sensations, noticing thoughts and emotions, beginners' mind, choice, patience, and continuing to practice; in-person sessions included mindfulness exercises; participants instructed to practice with guided mindfulness exercises on provided CD and track practice.
session_length: Session length: 45-minute in-person sessions and 20-minute phone sessions
def_treatment_adherence: Self-reported proportion of assigned readings completed and the amount of unguided practice
citation: Niles BL, Klunk-Gillis J, Ryngala DJ, et al. Comparing mindfulness and psychoeducation treatments for combat-related PTSD using a telehealth approach. Psychol Trauma. 2012 Sep;4(5):538-47. doi: 10.1037/a0026161

treatment_desc: 2 in-person sessions and 6 telephone sessions; participants given PTSD Education Handbook complementing treatment and providing education on issues of trust, safety, self-care, relationships and trauma, coping and healing, change, and moving forward; treatment focused on educating participants on how PTSD may affect their lives, and encouraged reflection and gave suggestions on positive coping without specific coping techniques (no relaxation exercises or behavioral activation).
session_length: Session length: 45-minute in-person sessions and 20-minute phone sessions
def_treatment_adherence: Self-reported proportion of assigned readings completed
citation: Niles BL, Klunk-Gillis J, Ryngala DJ, et al. Comparing mindfulness and psychoeducation treatments for combat-related PTSD using a telehealth approach. Psychol Trauma. 2012 Sep;4(5):538-47. doi: 10.1037/a0026161

treatment_desc: Treatment followed the alpha/theta protocol by El-Hage, Quide, Radua & Olff (2013) where participants relax with eyes closed. Participants asked to recall positive memory to increase cerebral theta waves. Feedback consisted of audio of river waves representing alpha waves and ocean waves representing theta waves
citation: Noohi S, Miraghaie AM, Arabi A, et al. Effectiveness of neuro-feedback treatment with alpha/theta method on PTSD symptoms and their executing function. Biomed Res. 2017;28(5):2019-27.
Noohi S, Miraghaie AM, Arabi A, et al. Effectiveness of neuro-feedback treatment with alpha/theta method on PTSD symptoms and their executing function. Biomed Res. 2017;28(5):2019-27.

treatment_desc:
Basic body awareness therapy: manualized physical exercise with "slow, guided movements while standing, sitting and lying down, aiming at normalising and improving balance, muscle tension, free breathing and awareness." Participants also encouraged to do exercises as homework.
TAU: interdisciplinary treatmen with medical doctor and psychologist; medical doctor focused on pharmacological treatment as needed and psychoeducation; psychologist followed manual for treatment - "individual flexible CBT with elements of acceptance and commitment therapy, stress management and mindfulness."
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced dsplacement, other ("violence from relatives")
citation: Nordbrandt MS, Sonne C, Mortensen EL, et al. Trauma-affected refugees treated with basic body awareness therapy or mixed physical activity as augmentation to treatment as usual-A pragmatic randomised controlled trial. PLoS ONE [Electronic Resource]. 2020;15(3):e0230300. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0230300. PMID: 32163509.

treatment_desc:
Mixed physical activity: followed manual; "bsic exercises focusing on improving strength, endurance, balance and coordination, using simple tools such as water bottles, bicycle, resistance bands, grocery bags etc." (tools selected which would allow participants to practice exercises at home). Participants also encouraged to do exercises as homework.
TAU: interdisciplinary treatmen with medical doctor and psychologist; medical doctor focused on pharmacological treatment as needed and psychoeducation; psychologist followed manual for treatment - "individual flexible CBT with elements of acceptance and commitment therapy, stress management and mindfulness."
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced dsplacement, other ("violence from relatives")
citation: Nordbrandt MS, Sonne C, Mortensen EL, et al. Trauma-affected refugees treated with basic body awareness therapy or mixed physical activity as augmentation to treatment as usual-A pragmatic randomised controlled trial. treatment_desc: MDMA is a psychoactive compound [Schedule 1 in the U.S. as a drug of abuse (ecstasy]). MDMA was given as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received MDMA-assisted psychotherapy, music therapy and "body work" (e.g. hand-holding) with 2 therapists present over an 8-hour period, followed by non-drug therapy sessions the following day, and at one- and two-weeks post MDMA treatment.
dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, NR for non-drug sessions

Dose: 187.5 mg (125 mg followed 2.5 hours later by 62.5 mg)
frequency: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; one non-drug session the morning after each MDMA-assisted session, followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure

treatment_desc: Low-dose MDMA used as an "active placebo" to maintain blinding "since MDMA's effects can be easily discerned by both subjects and investigators." Chosen dose expected "to produce minimal, but detectable subjective effects," but no significant therapeutic effect. Low-dose MDMA was given as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received low-dose MDMA-assisted psychotherapy, music therapy and "body work" (e.g. hand-holding) with 2 therapists present over an 8-hour period, followed by non-drug therapy sessions the following day, and at one- and two-weeks post MDMA treatment.
dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, NR for non-drug sessions

Dose: 37.5 mg (25 mg followed 2.5 hours later by 12.5 mg)
frequency: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; one non-drug session the morning after each MDMA-assisted session, followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart

treatment_desc: SSRI; flexible dosing, single dose in the morning; if no response at week 8, dose increased from 20 to 40 mg
dose: Initiated at 20 mg, could be increased to 40 mg

treatment_desc: MAOI Antidepressant; flexible dosing, daily dose divided between 8 am and 8 pm; if no response at week 8, increased from 450 mg to 900 mg

treatment_desc: Atypical antidepressant; flexible dosing, daily dose divided between 8 am, 4 pm, and 11 pm; if no response at 8 weeks, increased from 37.5 to 50 mg

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation in the first session, then treatment proceeds with "lifeline" exercise where patient chronologically narrates her life using stones to mark traumatic events and flowers to mark joyful events. Therapists also provided consultation on safety issues and current violence.

treatment_desc: Psychoeducation and supportive counseling individually tailored to each patient, including life skill training, cognitive-behavioral techniques, acceptance and commitment therapy, improvement of self-knowledge, and involvement of violent husbands as needed.

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy developed for use with psychedelics; followed patients' process with no agenda or solutions offered. session_length: Preparatory sessions: 90 minutes; MDMA sessions: 8 hours; Integrative sessions: NR
frequency: Preparatory sessions: interval NR; MDMA sessions: one month apart; Integrative sessions: ~10 days apart

treatment_desc: EMDR follows protocol according to Shapiro (2005), which involves participant isolating a visual representation of a traumatic memory, holding the memory, negative statement, evoked emotion, and area of body where the emotion is experienced while visually follow clinician's fingers for a set of 25 eye movements. All participants also received standard treatment for addiction, including clinical interviews, baclofen administration, anxiolytics/antidepressants administration, heroin substitution therapy, medications for PTSD treatment, and psychoeducation
frequency: Three sessions in first month, followed by monthly sessions
trauma_detail: other (sexual abuse, physical abuse or physical threatening or negligence, emotional abuse)
citation: Perez-Dandieu B, Tapia G. Treating trauma in addiction with EMDR: a pilot study. J Psychoactive Drugs. 2014 Oct-Dec;46(4):303-9. doi: 10.1080/02791072.2014.921744. PMID: 25188700.

treatment_desc: Clinical interviews, baclofen administration, anxiolytics/antidepressants administration, heroin substitution therapy, medications for PTSD treatment, and psychoeducation

treatment_desc: Intermittent theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex at 80% motor threshold (1800 pulses, 9.5 minutes) using a Magstim Rapid 2+1 system.

treatment_desc: Sham synchronized TMS was identical to active synchronized TMS except it did not use rotating magnets. Sham stimulation followed by optional unblinded synchronized TMS for another 4 weeks, delivered on a separate device from the one used for blinded stimulation.

treatment_desc: Active synchronized TMS for 4 weeks. Optional unblinded synchronized TMS for another 4 weeks, delivered on a separate device from the one used for blinded stimulation.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) with breathing biofeedback
treatment_desc: CBT following model developed by Foa et al (1995) that included imaginal and in vivo exposure, psychoeducation, and anxiety management. A device measures breathing frequency and provides immediate feedback (sound) when breathing frequency is outside preprogrammed frequency
treatment_duration_qual: flexible number of sessions until subjective units of distress‚ ≤30
trauma_detail: accidents, other (sexual or physical abuse)

treatment_desc: Program teaches participants to attend to the present moment (immediate emotional and physical states) in a nonjudgmental and accepting way. Sessions include didactic training and formal practice in 3 meditation techniques: body scan, sitting meditation, and mindful yoga. Intervention modified to include PTSD psychoeducation.

treatment_desc: Participants completed a 30-minute bout of moderate-intensity treadmill exercise (70% of age-predicted HRmax) immediately prior to each PE session. PE was manualized treatment program including education about trauma; breathing retraining: prolonged and repeated imaginal exposure to the trauma memories; prolonged and repeated in vivo exposure to safe situations; assignment of homework; and monitoring compliance of homework assignments.

treatment_desc: Two sham right-sided SGB treatments, with normal saline injected into musculature anterolateral to the anterior tubercle of C6, performed at 0 and 2 weeks with outcomes measured at 8 weeks

citation: Rae Olmsted KL, Bartoszek M, Mulvaney S, et al. Effect of Stellate Ganglion Block Treatment on Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms: A Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Nov 6:1-9. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.3474. PMID: 31693083.

treatment_desc: Two right-sided SGB treatments, with ropivicaine injected into ganglion site at level of C6 anterior tubercle, performed at 0 and 2 weeks with outcomes measured at 8 weeks
dose: 7 to 10 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine
citation: Rae Olmsted KL, Bartoszek M, Mulvaney S, et al. Effect of Stellate Ganglion Block Treatment on Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms: A Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Nov 6:1-9. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.3474. PMID: 31693083.

treatment_desc: Atypical antipsychotic; dose increased in increments of 20 mg twice daily
dose: Initiated at 20 mg, titrated to maximum 80 mg

treatment_desc: Placebo

treatment_desc: SSRI and partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptor; 10 mg/day on days 1 to 7, 20 mg/day on days 8 to 14, 40 mg/day weeks 3 through 12, with the option to adjust dose based on response and tolerability; tapered off vilazodone over weeks 13 and 14, no treatment week 15
dose: Initiated at 10 mg/day, increased to maximum 40 mg/day
def_treatment_adherence: counts of returned medications
citation: Ramaswamy S, Driscoll D, Reist C, et al. A double-blind, placebo-controlled randomized trial of vilazodone in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder and comorbid depression. Prim Care Companion CNS Disord. 2017 Aug 24;19(4):17m02138. doi: 10.4088/PCC.17m02138. PMID: 28858440.

treatment_desc: Matched active treatment
def_treatment_adherence: counts of returned medications

treatment_desc: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; 1 mg/day for 3 days, 2 mg/day for 4 days, then based on response and tolerability increased to 4 mg/day for 7 days, 6 mg/day for 7 days, and then 10 mg/day.
dose: Initiated at 1 mg and titrated to maximum 10 mg
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Kanter ED, et al. Reduction of nightmares and other PTSD symptoms in combat veterans by prazosin: a placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2003 Feb;160(2):371-3. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.371. PMID: 12562588.

treatment_desc: Placebo
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Kanter ED, et al. Reduction of nightmares and other PTSD symptoms in combat veterans by prazosin: a placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2003 Feb;160(2):371-3. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.371. PMID: 12562588.

treatment_desc: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; 1 mg for 3 days, 2 mg through day 7, then titrated based on response and tolerability to 4 mg through day 14, 6 mg through day 21, 10 mg through day 28, 15 mg after 28-day visit.
dose: Initiated at 1 mg, titrated to maximum 15 mg
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Hoff DJ, et al. treatment_desc: Placebo capsules indistinguishable from prazosin
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Hoff DJ, et al. treatment_desc: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; titrated for up to 6 weeks based on response and tolerability, with a lower morning dose and higher bedtime dose, and separate titration schedules for men and women with lower doses for women
dose: Initiated at 1 mg for both men and women, titrated to maximum 25 mg for men and 12 mg for women
frequency: Daily (divided into smaller morning and larger bedtime doses)
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: Bedtime dose 15.6 mg for men and 7.0 mg for women. Midmorning dose 4.0 mg for men and 1.7 mg for women.
dose_at_study_end_point_sd: Bedtime dose (6.0) mg for men and (3.5) mg for women. Midmorning dose (1.4) mg for men and (0.5) mg for women.
citation: Raskind MA, Peterson K, Williams T, et al. A trial of prazosin for combat trauma PTSD with nightmares in active-duty soldiers returned from Iraq and Afghanistan. Am J Psychiatry. 2013 Sep;170(9):1003-10. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12081133. PMID: 23846759.

treatment_desc: Capsules indistinguishable from the 3 active drug capsules (1 mg, 2 mg, 5 mg); titration period for both placebo and active arms
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: Bedtime dose 18.8 mg for men and 10.0 mg for women. Midmorning dose 4.8 mg for men and 2.0 mg for women.
dose_at_study_end_point_sd: Bedtime dose (3.3) mg for men and (0.0) mg for women. Midmorning dose (0.8) mg for men and (0.0) mg for women.
citation: Raskind MA, Peterson K, Williams T, et al. A trial of prazosin for combat trauma PTSD with nightmares in active-duty soldiers returned from Iraq and Afghanistan. Am J Psychiatry. 2013 Sep;170(9):1003-10. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12081133. PMID: 23846759.

treatment_desc: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; titrated based on response and tolerability, with a lower morning dose and higher bedtime dose, and separate titration schedules for men and women with lower doses for women. After the first 10 weeks, other pharmacologic therapies (except prazosin, trazodone, or psychostimulants) or psychotherapeutic treatments could be added, discontinued, or modified by treating clinicians.
dose: Initiated at 1 mg for both men and women, titrated to maximum 20 mg for men and 12 mg for women
frequency: Daily (divided into smaller morning and larger bedtime doses)
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Chow B, et al. Trial of prazosin for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans. N Engl J Med. 2018 Feb 8;378(6):507-17. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa1507598. PMID: 29414272.

treatment_desc: Capsules identical to the 3 active drug capsules (1 mg, 2 mg, 5 mg); titration period for both placebo and active arms. After the first 10 weeks, other pharmacologic therapies (except prazosin, trazodone, or psychostimulants) or psychotherapeutic treatments could be added, discontinued, or modified by treating clinicians.
citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Chow B, et al. Trial of prazosin for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans. N Engl J Med. 2018 Feb 8;378(6):507-17. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa1507598. PMID: 29414272.

treatment_desc: Investigational anxiolytic and anticonvulsant; biweekly dose escalations by 200 mg twice daily, based on tolerability
dose: Initiated at 200 mg, titrated to maximum 600 mg
def_treatment_adherence: counted returned supplies; and compared plasma trough levels of ganaxolone to predicted therapeutic levels (≥20 ng/mL)
trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
citation: Rasmusson AM, Marx CE, Jain S, et al. A randomized controlled trial of ganaxolone in posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2017;234(15):2245-57. doi: 10.1007/s00213-017-4649-y. PMID: 28667510.

treatment_desc: Gelatin capsules identical to those containing ganaxolone
def_treatment_adherence: counted returned supplies
trauma_detail: combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse

treatment_desc: Prolonged exposure therapy sessions included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, discussion, and in vivo exposure homework. Placebo titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks.
frequency: Psychotherapy: 13 sessions over 24 weeks; Placebo: daily
def_treatment_adherence: completing all 13 sessions and taking sertraline at week 24
citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

treatment_desc: Prolonged exposure therapy sessions included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, discussion, and in vivo exposure homework. Sertraline titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks.
dose: Dose: sertraline adjusted between 50 and 200 mg
frequency: Psychotherapy: 13 sessions over 24 weeks; Sertraline: daily
def_treatment_adherence: completing all 13 sessions and taking sertraline at week 24
citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

treatment_desc: Sertraline titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks. Enhanced medication management ending at week 12 provided to balance time, psychoeducation, and clinician support compared with PE therapy groups
dose: 50 to 100 mg
def_treatment_adherence: taking sertraline at week 24
citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy including psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, and emotional processing.
citation: Rauch SAM, King AP, Abelson JL, et al. Biological and symptom changes in posttraumatic stress disorder treatment: a randomized clinical trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Mar;32(3):204-12. doi: 10.1002/da.22331. PMID: 25639570.

treatment_desc: Therapy following the Shea manual (Schnurr 2007), with psychoeducation (2 sessions) and discussion of current experience of PTSD symptoms and coping (remaining sessions).
citation: Rauch SAM, King AP, Abelson JL, et al. Biological and symptom changes in posttraumatic stress disorder treatment: a randomized clinical trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Mar;32(3):204-12. doi: 10.1002/da.22331. PMID: 25639570.

treatment_desc: Treatment involves creation of group cohesion, improving coping skills, imaginal and in vivo exposure exercises, and guided imagery exercise
citation: Ready DJ, Mascaro N, Wattenberg MS, et al. A controlled study of group-based exposure therapy with Vietnam-era veterans. J Loss Trauma. 2018;23(6):439-57. doi: 10.1080/15325024.2018.1485268. PMID: 133654049.

treatment_desc: Sessions focus on current problems related to PTSD symptoms and problem-solving
frequency: Twice weekly; Booster session once every 3 weeks
citation: Ready DJ, Mascaro N, Wattenberg MS, et al. A controlled study of group-based exposure therapy with Vietnam-era veterans. J Loss Trauma. 2018;23(6):439-57. doi: 10.1080/15325024.2018.1485268. PMID: 133654049.

treatment_desc: Therapist provided trauma-related stimuli in a gradual manner through a virtual reality environment. Participants were asked to give a Subjective Units of Distress Scale every 5 minutes and to scan their body to report levels of tension.
citation: Ready DJ, Gerardi RJ, Backscheider AG, et al. Comparing virtual reality exposure therapy to present-centered therapy with 11 U.S. Vietnam veterans with PTSD. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):49-54.  PMID: 20528293.

treatment_desc: Supportive therapy involving psychoeducation, teaching problem-solving techniques, and helping participants through a focus on problems occurring in their lives
citation: Ready DJ, Gerardi RJ, Backscheider AG, et al. Comparing virtual reality exposure therapy to present-centered therapy with 11 U.S. Vietnam veterans with PTSD. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):49-54.  PMID: 20528293.

treatment_desc: Each session included healing touch using two protocols: biofield treatment, and amygdala treatment. Participants also received standard of care during both phases.
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
citation: Reeve K, et al. Examining the impact of a Healing Touch intervention to reduce posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms in combat veterans. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy. 2020. doi: 10.1037/tra0000591.

treatment_desc: Medication and psychotherapy delivered by the subjects regular practitioners and a variety of other interventions, such as relaxation training, meditation, archery, or yoga.
citation: Reeve K, et al. Examining the impact of a Healing Touch intervention to reduce posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms in combat veterans. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy. 2020. doi: 10.1037/tra0000591.

treatment_desc: Manualized intervention according to Foa et al. (2007), includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, repeated and prolonged imaginal exposure to traumatic memory, cognitive and emotional processing of traumatic material, and in vivo exposure to safe but feared situations
citation: Reger GM, Koenen-Woods P, Zetocha K, et al. Randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure using imaginal exposure vs. virtual reality exposure in active duty soldiers with deployment-related posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Prolonged Exposure (PE) with virtual reality exposure
treatment_desc: Intervention follow PE treatment protocol according to Foa et al. (2007) with traumatic memory shown through virtual reality headset. While wearing headset, patient verbally describe the events.
citation: Reger GM, Koenen-Woods P, Zetocha K, et al. Randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure using imaginal exposure vs. virtual reality exposure in active duty soldiers with deployment-related posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

treatment_desc: Atypical antipsychotic
dose: 0.5 mg for 3 days, then 1 mg/day after 3 days, then increase weekly by up to 1 mg/day to 4 mg/day.  Could increase to maximum of 8 mg/day after week 5
frequency: Daily at bedtime initially, then could be 2 or 3 times daily
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: overall 1.41 mg, mean 2.05 mg at week 8
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
citation: Reich DB, Winternitz S, Hennen J, et al. A preliminary study of risperidone in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse in women. J Clin Psychiatry. 2004 Dec;65(12):1601-6. PMID: 15641864.

treatment_desc: Placebo
frequency: Once daily at bedtime initially, then up to 2 or 3 times daily
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
citation: Reich DB, Winternitz S, Hennen J, et al. A preliminary study of risperidone in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse in women. J Clin Psychiatry. 2004 Dec;65(12):1601-6. PMID: 15641864.

treatment_desc: Group yoga sessions comprised of centering and breathing exercises, body warm-ups, physical poses, breath work, moving meditation, and relaxation; participants asked to practice yoga for 15 minutes daily.
citation: Reinhardt KM, Noggle Taylor JJ, Johnston J, et al. Kripalu yoga for military veterans With PTSD: a randomized trial. J Clin Psychol. 2018 Jan;74(1):93-108. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22483. PMID: 28524358.

treatment_desc: No treatment; participants completed assessments as a group (except CAPS, completed individually).
citation: Reinhardt KM, Noggle Taylor JJ, Johnston J, et al. Kripalu yoga for military veterans With PTSD: a randomized trial. J Clin Psychol. 2018 Jan;74(1):93-108. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22483. PMID: 28524358.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy where patients learn to label events, thoughts, and subsequent emptions while therapist uses Socratic questioning to help patients examine the facts and context, and develop new, more balanced thinking about traumatic events
trauma_detail: combat-related, child sexual abuse
citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Mintz J, et al. A randomized clinical trial of group cognitive processing therapy compared with group present-centered therapy for PTSD among active duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2015 Dec;83(6):1058-68. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000016. PMID: 25939018.

treatment_desc: Therapists help patients manage current symptoms through problem solving, directing discussion of trauma back to present time
trauma_detail: combat-related, child sexual abuse
citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Mintz J, et al. A randomized clinical trial of group cognitive processing therapy compared with group present-centered therapy for PTSD among active duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2015 Dec;83(6):1058-68. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000016. PMID: 25939018.

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy including cognitive therapy and exposure in the form of writing and reading about the traumatic event
session_length: 60 minutes for initial session, all others 90 minutes
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

treatment_desc: Includes education-rationale, breathing retraining, behavioral exposures, and imaginal exposures
session_length: 60 minutes for initial session, all others 90 minutes
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

treatment_desc: Participants were encouraged to call therapist for client-centered telephone counseling
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy that teaches skill of recognizing and challenging dysfunctional cognitions
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

treatment_desc: Exposure-focused component of CPT where patients wrote about index event and discussed emotional response regarding event, but did not include cognitive therapy or challenge to client's dysfunctional statements
session_length: 60 minutes for initial 2 sessions, 2 hours for remaining sessions
frequency: Twice weekly for first week, then weekly
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

treatment_desc: Identical to manualized CPT but without written account component
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy in groups of 8 to 10 participants; cognitive-only version following manual developed for military and veterans and incorporating special considerations for military population; one individual meeting with therapist prior to treatment to review trauma history; therapy aim to teach patients to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions (stuck points) about the traumatic event(s) and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world. Participants who missed 4 sessions were dropped from group treatment.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (noncombat death)
citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Dondanville KA, et al. Effect of group vs individual cognitive processing therapy in active-duty military seeking treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2017 Jan;74(1):28-36.  PMID: 27893032.

treatment_desc: Individual trauma-focused cognitive therapy; cognitive-only version following manual developed for military and veterans and incorporating special considerations for military population; therapy aim to teach patients to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions (stuck points) about the traumatic event(s) and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world. Participants who couldn't complete treatment in 3 months for reasons other than military assignments had treatment ended.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (noncombat death)
citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Dondanville KA, et al. Effect of group vs individual cognitive processing therapy in active-duty military seeking treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2017 Jan;74(1):28-36.  PMID: 27893032.

treatment_name: Imaginal exposure followed by live exposure
treatment_desc: Imaginal exposure involved patients reliving their traumatic memories until anxiety is reduced. Live exposure involved patients re-entering trauma-related situations that they had been avoiding.
treatment_duration_qual: 4 sessions each of imaginal and live exposure
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Richards DA, Lovell K, Marks IM. Post-traumatic stress disorder: evaluation of a behavioral treatment program. J Trauma Stress. 1994 Oct;7(4):669-80. doi: 10.1007/BF02103014. PMID: 7820356.

treatment_name: Live exposure followed by imaginal exposure
treatment_desc: Imaginal exposure involved patients reliving their traumatic memories until anxiety is reduced. Live exposure involved patients re-entering trauma-related situations that they had been avoiding.
treatment_duration_qual: 4 sessions each of imaginal and live exposure
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Richards DA, Lovell K, Marks IM. Post-traumatic stress disorder: evaluation of a behavioral treatment program. J Trauma Stress. 1994 Oct;7(4):669-80. doi: 10.1007/BF02103014. PMID: 7820356.

treatment_desc: Individual + group therapy sessions; adapted version expanded group component to "maximize the focus on behaviour change away from ongoing perpetration of violence within the community, and to increase the emphasis on peer support". Individual sessions involved construction of lifeline, exploration of traumatic events (act of perpetrated violence). Group sessions "aimed to develop skills and motivation to avoid perpetrating violence within the community" and group members encouraged to support each other and introduced a 'buddy system'.
session_length: Individual sessions: 90 to 120 minutes; Group sessions: 60 to 90 minutes
frequency: Individual sessions: weekly; Group sessions: weekly
def_treatment_completion: attended all individual and group therapy sessions (6 sessions each)
citation: Robjant K, Koebach A, Schmitt S, et al. The treatment of posttraumatic stress symptoms and aggression in female former child soldiers using adapted Narrative Exposure therapy - a RCT in Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Behav Res Ther. 2019 Dec;123:103482. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2019.103482. PMID: 31639529.

treatment_desc: Services available through NGO, including: "occupational training courses, empathic listening and basic counselling, problem solving and practical support, provided whenever needed"; participant was visited at home if more than a week from last drop in.
citation: Robjant K, Koebach A, Schmitt S, et al. The treatment of posttraumatic stress symptoms and aggression in female former child soldiers using adapted Narrative Exposure therapy - a RCT in Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Behav Res Ther. 2019 Dec;123:103482. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2019.103482. PMID: 31639529.

treatment_desc: Extended-release alpha-1 noradrenergic antagonist with 15 to 19 hour half-life; initiated at 4 mg/day and increased by 4 mg every 4 days to final dose of 16 mg/day
dose: Initiated at 4 mg, titrated to 16 mg
citation: Rodgman C, Verrico CD, Holst M, et al. Doxazosin XL reduces symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans with PTSD: a pilot clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2016 May;77(5):e561-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.14m09681. PMID: 27249080.

treatment_desc: Placebo capsules identical to active treatment, dose increased over study period
citation: Rodgman C, Verrico CD, Holst M, et al. Doxazosin XL reduces symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans with PTSD: a pilot clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2016 May;77(5):e561-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.14m09681. PMID: 27249080.

treatment_desc: Intervention follow method as described by Shapiro (1995). Subjects asked to concentrate on a visual image, the negative statement, and the sensation while tracking the therapist's finger back and forth. When subjects report minimal distress, they were asked to concentrate on the visual image and positive cognition during eye movements.
citation: Rogers S, Silver SM, Goss J, et al. A single session, group study of exposure and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in treating posttraumatic stress disorder among Vietnam War veterans: preliminary data. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 Jan-Apr;13(1-2):119-30. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00043-7. PMID: 10225504.

treatment_desc: Intervention based on explosion procedure described in Lyons and Keane (1989). Subjects were guided in a progress muscle relaxation exercise, then visualized the experience while paying attention to sensory, cognitive, and emotional cues. The scene was repeated with relaxation.
citation: Rogers S, Silver SM, Goss J, et al. A single session, group study of exposure and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in treating posttraumatic stress disorder among Vietnam War veterans: preliminary data. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 Jan-Apr;13(1-2):119-30. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00043-7. PMID: 10225504.

treatment_desc:
Resistance training and pedometer-based walking program. Resistance training included one supervised exercise session and two home-based unsupervised exercise sessions per week.

Participants also received usual care which could include psychotherapy, pharmaceutical interventions, and group therapy.
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
trauma_detail: other (trauma experienced through occupation, not specified)
citation: Rosenbaum S, Sherrington C, Tiedemann A. Exercise augmentation compared with usual care for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2015 May;131(5):350-9. doi: 10.1111/acps.12371. PMID: 25443996.

treatment_desc: Usual care which could include psychotherapy, pharmaceutical interventions, and group therapy.
trauma_detail: other (trauma experienced through occupation, not specified)
citation: Rosenbaum S, Sherrington C, Tiedemann A. Exercise augmentation compared with usual care for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2015 May;131(5):350-9. doi: 10.1111/acps.12371. PMID: 25443996.

treatment_desc: Individual sessions following treatment manual; patient imagines a scene that represents the entire trauma, focusing on sensations of anxiety while rehearsing words that match the picture and simultaneously follows therapist's finger moving back and forth until anxiety is decreased; patient then follows same procedure while rehearsing new, preferred belief, until the new statement feels true to the patient. The first session was comprised of information gathering, without EMDR.
citation: Rothbaum BO. A controlled study of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disordered sexual assault victims. Bull Menninger Clin. 1997 Summer;61(3):317-34.  PMID: 9260344.

Rothbaum BO. A controlled study of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disordered sexual assault victims. Bull Menninger Clin. 1997 Summer;61(3):317-34.  PMID: 9260344.

treatment_desc: Patient imagines a scene representing the worst part of the trauma, focuses on sensations of distress and rehearses negative thoughts, simultaneously following therapist's fingers back and forth at least 20 times each repetition until distress drops to 0 or 1 (measured 0 to 10 on subjective units of discomfort scale); patient then rehearses new, preferred belief while tracking therapist's finger until new statement feels true to the participant; uses cognitive interweaves to accomplish cognitive work. First two sessions for education and treatment planning; remaining 7 sessions were EMDR treatment.
citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

treatment_desc: Patients instructed to imaging assault scene and describe aloud while anxiety levels are monitored, repeating the process for 45 to 60 minutes, followed by discussion of patient's reaction; patients instructed to listen to recording of narrative at least once a day and assigned homework. Two sessions for treatment planning including construction of a hierarchy of avoided situations for in vivo exposure homework; 7 sessions of imaginative exposure.
citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

treatment_desc: Waitlist after pretreatment assessment, then randomly assigned to PE or EMDR after posttreatment assessment.
citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant and prolonged exposure therapy comprised of psychoeducation, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, prolonged imaginal exposure, and homework.
dose:
Sertraline dose: 25 to 200 mg, previously titrated to maximum dose tolerated in Phase I

PE session length: 90 to 120 minutes
frequency:
Sertraline: daily

PE: Twice a week
def_treatment_adherence: Sertraline: compliance as number of tablets taken divided by number of tablets that should have been taken, using medication dispensing data and unused medication returns (average % compliance with regimen)
adhered_pharmacotherapy_percent_detail: Average % compliance with regimen 7.1% (SD 7.99) at Week 10 and 97.1% (SD 5.86) at Week 15 endpoint for both sertraline groups (% of patients being 100% adherent NR)
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 173.1 mg at Week 10 and 173.5 mg at Week 15 (average for both sertraline groups)
dose_at_study_end_point_sd: (44.26) mg at Week 10 and (42.82) mg at Week 15 (average for both sertraline groups)
trauma_detail: child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, combat-related, other (death [not combat-related] of another person)
citation: Rothbaum BO, Cahill SP, Foa EB, et al. Augmentation of sertraline with prolonged exposure in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2006 Oct;19(5):625-38. doi: 10.1002/jts.20170. PMID: 17075912.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant, continuation of medication following 10 weeks of open-label treatment with flexible dosing titrated over first 5 weeks.

treatment_desc: Augmentation of an SSRI antidepressant (sertraline) with an atypical antipsychotic; all participants treated with sertraline in phase 1, and non-responders randomized to augmentation with risperidone or placebo; dose increased weekly by 0.5 mg/day as tolerated to maximum 2 mg/day, or 3 mg/day "on a case-by-case basis." Sertraline continued through phase 2, mean dose at endpoint 147 mg for risperidone arm.
dose: Initiated at 0.5 mg, titrated to maximum of 2 or 3 mg
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence, other (stalking, break-in, witnessed killing or suicide attempt)
citation: Rothbaum BO, Killeen TK, Davidson JRT, et al. Placebo-controlled trial of risperidone augmentation for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor-resistant civilian posttraumatic stress disorder. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2008;69(4):520-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.v69n0402. PMID: 18278987.

treatment_desc: Augmentation of an SSRI antidepressant (sertraline) with placebo matching risperidone; all participants treated with sertraline in phase 1, and non-responders randomized to augmentation with risperidone or placebo; sertraline continued through phase 2.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence, other (stalking, break-in, witnessed killing or suicide attempt)
citation: Rothbaum BO, Killeen TK, Davidson JRT, et al. Placebo-controlled trial of risperidone augmentation for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor-resistant civilian posttraumatic stress disorder. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2008;69(4):520-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.v69n0402. PMID: 18278987.

treatment_desc:
Virtual reality exposure: sessions comprised of exposure to subject's most traumatic memories using computer-generated virtual Iraq or Afghanistan environments with simulated field/combat situations and trigger stimuli (auditory, visual, olfactory, and tactile), manipulated by the therapist with attempt to match patient-described stimuli followed by experience processing, integration, and associations. This therapy differed from typical exposure therapy in that there was no homework assigned. 

D-cycloserine: NMDA glutamate receptor partial agonist
dose:
Drug dose: 50 mg (30 minutes prior to session)

Sessions: 90 minutes (30 minutes prior to exposure for medication and assessments including startle responses and cortisol sampling). 30 to 45 minutes continuous exposure, until anxiety level decreases, 15 to 20 minutes processing time. One introductory session without medication or exposure was given.
citation: Rothbaum BO, Price M, Jovanovic T, et al. A randomized, double-blind evaluation of D-cycloserine or alprazolam combined with virtual reality exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in Iraq and Afghanistan War veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;171(6):640-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2014.13121625. PMID: 24743802.

treatment_desc:
Virtual reality exposure: sessions comprised of exposure to subject's most traumatic memories using computer-generated virtual Iraq or Afghanistan environments with simulated field/combat situations and trigger stimuli (auditory, visual, olfactory, and tactile), manipulated by the therapist with attempt to match patient-described stimuli followed by experience processing, integration, and associations. This therapy differed from typical exposure therapy in that there was no homework assigned. 

Alprazolam: benzodiazepine

treatment_name: Exposure with eyes fixated and moving
treatment_desc: Exposure with eyes moving while fixated on therapist's moving hand; treatment followed EMDR manual by Solomon and Shapiro, except for variation in stimulation (eye movement); treatment focuses on  distressing trauma-related images, beliefs, and bodily sensations; therapy ended when PTSD diagnostic criteria no longer met, or 3 sessions without subjective symptom reduction, with maximum of 8 sessions.
trauma_detail: accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (sexual trauma)
citation: Sack M, Zehl S, Otti A, et al. A comparison of dual attention, eye movements, and exposure only during Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing for posttraumatic stress disorder: results from a randomized clinical trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2016;85(6):357-65. doi: 10.1159/000447671. PMID: 27744424.

treatment_name: Exposure with eyes fixated and not moving
treatment_desc: Exposure with eyes fixated on therapist's nonmoving hand; treatment followed EMDR manual by Solomon and Shapiro, except for variation in stimulation (eye movement); treatment focuses on distressing trauma-related images, beliefs, and bodily sensations; therapy ended when PTSD diagnostic criteria no longer met, or 3 sessions without subjective symptom reduction, with maximum of 8 sessions.

treatment_desc: Exposure without explicit task of fixating on external focus of attention (eyes closed or eyes open and looking unfocused into the room); treatment followed EMDR manual by Solomon and Shapiro, except for variation in stimulation (eye movement); treatment focuses on distressing trauma-related images, beliefs, and bodily sensations; therapy ended when PTSD diagnostic criteria no longer met, or 3 sessions without subjective symptom reduction, with maximum of 8 sessions.
trauma_detail: accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (sexual trauma)

treatment_desc: Intranasal oxytocin (Syntocinon, Novartis, Brazil) administered 45 minutes before trauma-script exposure. Trauma-script stress exposure used a script of 2 minutes and did not include an imagery period.
dose: 24 IU
def_treatment_adherence: NA (administered in clinic)
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other ("non-sexual violence by a family member")

treatment_desc: Intranasal placebo administered 45 minutes before trauma-script exposure. Placebo spray included all ingredients as the oxytocin intranasal spray except for the oxytocin. Trauma-script stress exposure used a script of 2 minutes and did not include an imagery period.
