ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for alcohol use
treatment_desc: CBT for AUD plus supportive counseling. CBT was based on Project MATCH and the Combined Behavioral Intervention Manual (same as AUD portion for Integrated therapy intervention). Included structured homework. Supportive counseling is present-centered, manualized therapy, and targeted AUD symptoms only in this intervention.
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence, accidents, other ("witnessed injury/killing/mutilation", "news of someone close", "danger of losing life/other")
citation: Sannibale C, Teesson M, Creamer MC, et al. Randomized controlled trial of cognitive behaviour therapy for comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorders. Addiction. 2013 Aug;108(8):1397-410. doi: 10.1111/add.12167. PMID: 25328957.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Integrated cognitive behavioral therapy for PTSD and AUD
treatment_desc: Integrated exposure-based CBT for PTSD and AUD. CBT for PTSD was manualized, and incorporated exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring; integrated with CBT for AUD, a manual-guided therapy based on Project MATCH and the Combined Behavioral Intervention Manual (same as AUD portion for Alcohol support intervention). Included structured homework.
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence, accidents, other ("witnessed injury/killing/mutilation", "news of someone close", "danger of losing life/other")
citation: Sannibale C, Teesson M, Creamer MC, et al. Randomized controlled trial of cognitive behaviour therapy for comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorders. Addiction. 2013 Aug;108(8):1397-410. doi: 10.1111/add.12167. PMID: 25328957.

treatment_desc: Therapy includes identification of  disturbing memories of traumatic event and focusing on these memories while following finger movements performed by therapist
citation: Santarnecchi E, Bossini L, Vatti G, et al. Psychological and brain connectivity changes following trauma-focused CBT and EMDR treatment in single-episode PTSD patients. Front Psychol. 2019;10:129. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00129. PMID: 30858808.

treatment_desc: Includes narrative recollection of traumatic event, relaxation exercises, psychoeducation, exposure therapy, and home assignments
citation: Santarnecchi E, Bossini L, Vatti G, et al. Psychological and brain connectivity changes following trauma-focused CBT and EMDR treatment in single-episode PTSD patients. Front Psychol. 2019;10:129. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00129. PMID: 30858808.

treatment_desc: PTSD treatment and couples-based therapy by individual therapist; manual-based interventions organized within a stress inoculation therapy (SIT) framework including psychoeducation (2 sessions), emotion activation and skills training (4 sessions), and disclosure-based exposure (6 sessions); homework assignment with each session. Up to 3 additional sessions were permitted if it wasn't possible to complete the protocol within 12 sessions.
citation: Sautter FJ, Glynn SM, Cretu JB, et al. Efficacy of structured approach therapy in reducing PTSD in returning veterans: A randomized clinical trial. Psychol Serv. 2015 Aug;12(3):199-212. doi: 10.1037/ser0000032. PMID: 26213789.

treatment_desc: PTSD treatment and couples-based therapy, manualized and adapted from the Support and Family Education (SAFE) program and behavioral family therapy family education sections; treatment using lectures, discussion, and written materials designed to educate about PTSD and PTSD-related conditions. Avoided skills training and other therapeutic interventions. Up to 3 additional sessions were permitted if it wasn't possible to complete the protocol within 12 sessions.
citation: Sautter FJ, Glynn SM, Cretu JB, et al. Efficacy of structured approach therapy in reducing PTSD in returning veterans: A randomized clinical trial. Psychol Serv. 2015 Aug;12(3):199-212. doi: 10.1037/ser0000032. PMID: 26213789.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant; flexible dosing based on "clinical status"
dose: 50 to 100 mg
citation: Saygin MZ, Sungur MZ, Sabol EU, et al. Nefazodone versus sertraline in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Klinik Psikofarmakol B√ºlteni. 2002 Jan;12(1):1-5.

treatment_desc: Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor; flexible dose based on "clinical status"
dose: 200 to 400 mg
citation: Saygin MZ, Sungur MZ, Sabol EU, et al. Nefazodone versus sertraline in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Klinik Psikofarmakol B√ºlteni. 2002 Jan;12(1):1-5.

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum (2007) that includes breathing retraining for relaxation and imaginal and in vivo exposure. Incentive was gift card or clinic fee voucher beginning at $30 for Session 1, escalating $10 per session  with maximum total amount equaling $480. If the participant missed a session, the next attended session reset earnings to $30. Participants who missed 4 consecutive weeks were withdrawn from PE therapy but remained eligible to participate in followup assessments
def_treatment_completion: completed 12 sessions or at least 9 sessions and demonstrated a 70% reduction on MPSS-R score
trauma_detail: child sexual assault, child physical assault, intimate partner violence, other (unexpected death of loved one)
citation: Schacht RL, Brooner RK, King VL, et al. Incentivizing attendance to prolonged exposure for PTSD with opioid use disorder patients: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2017 Jul;85(7):689-701. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000208. PMID: 28414485

treatment_desc: Manualized therapy according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum (2007) that includes breathing retraining for relaxation and imaginal and in vivo exposure. Participants received $40 for completing each followup assessment
def_treatment_completion: completed 12 sessions or at least 9 sessions and demonstrated a 70% reduction on MPSS-R score
trauma_detail: child sexual assault, child physical assault, intimate partner violence, other (unexpected death of loved one)
citation: Schacht RL, Brooner RK, King VL, et al. Incentivizing attendance to prolonged exposure for PTSD with opioid use disorder patients: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2017 Jul;85(7):689-701. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000208. PMID: 28414485

treatment_desc:
PE: trauma-focused CBT comprised of guided exposure to traumatic memories and situations to enhance emotional processing.

Paroxetine: controlled-release; SSRI
dose:
Session length: 90 minutes

Dose: 12.5 mg for 1 week, then 25 mg for 3 weeks, then increased as tolerated to maximum of 50 mg
def_treatment_adherence: NR ("monitored compliance using pill counts")
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 32.2 mg (mean maximum daily dose for at least 1 week)
citation: Schneier FR, Neria Y, Pavlicova M, et al. Combined prolonged exposure therapy and paroxetine for PTSD related to the World Trade Center attack: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2012 Jan;169(1):80-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2011.11020321. PMID: 21908494.

treatment_desc:
PE: trauma-focused CBT comprised of guided exposure to traumatic memories and situations to enhance emotional processing.

Placebo: matching placebo tablets
dose:
Session length: 90 minutes

Dose: matching placebo to paroxetine which was prescribed at 12.5 mg for 1 week, then 25 mg for 3 weeks, then increased as tolerated to maximum of 50 mg
def_treatment_adherence: NR ("monitored compliance using pill counts")
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 36.8 mg (paroxetine equivalent) (mean maximum daily dose attained for at least 1 week)
citation: Schneier FR, Neria Y, Pavlicova M, et al. Combined prolonged exposure therapy and paroxetine for PTSD related to the World Trade Center attack: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2012 Jan;169(1):80-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2011.11020321. PMID: 21908494.

treatment_desc: Atypical antidepressant (tetracyclic, alpha-2 antagonist); mirtazapine increased after 4 weeks' treatment based on response and adverse events. All patients in both treatment arms also received the SSRI sertraline, initiated at 25 mg/day and titrated up to 200 mg/day.
dose: 15 to 45 mg; initiated at 30 mg for 4 weeks, increased as tolerated if continued PTSD symptoms to maximum of 45 mg, decreased if needed for adverse events to minimum dose of 15 mg
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
citation: Schneier FR, Campeas R, Carcamo J, et al. Combined mirtazapine and SSRI treatment of PTSD: a placebo-controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Aug;32(8):570-9. doi: 10.1002/da.22384. PMID: 26115513.

treatment_desc: Placebo capsules matching mirtazapine; all patients in both treatment arms also received the SSRI sertraline, initiated at 25 mg/day and titrated up to 200 mg/day.
dose: 15 to 45 mg mirtazapine equivalent; initiated at 30 mg for 4 weeks, increased as tolerated if continued PTSD symptoms to maximum of 45 mg, decreased if needed for adverse events to minimum dose of 15 mg
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
citation: Schneier FR, Campeas R, Carcamo J, et al. Combined mirtazapine and SSRI treatment of PTSD: a placebo-controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Aug;32(8):570-9. doi: 10.1002/da.22384. PMID: 26115513.

treatment_desc: Individual therapy delivered according to a manual, with focus on current life problems as manifestations of PTSD; included psychoeducation about PTSD and treatment rationale; review of general daily difficulties,  with therapist helping patient to identifying daily stresses and discussing in supportive, nondirective mode; reviewing accomplishments made during therapy; and making plans for the future.
trauma_detail: combat-related, MST, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (sexual trauma, not specified)
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Engel CC, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in women: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Feb 28;297(8):820-30. doi: 10.1001/jama.297.8.820. PMID: 17327524.

treatment_desc: Individual therapy delivered according to a manual; treatment included psychoeducation about common reactions to trauma; breathing retraining; imaginal exposure through prolonged (repeated) recounting of trauma memories during sessions; exposure homework, both imaginal (listen to recording of trauma recounting) and in vivo (safe situations avoided due to trauma-related fear); discussion of thoughts and feelings related to exposure exercises.
trauma_detail: combat-related, MST, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (sexual trauma, not specified)
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Engel CC, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in women: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Feb 28;297(8):820-30. doi: 10.1001/jama.297.8.820. PMID: 17327524.

treatment_desc: Exposure-based treatment in a group context following manualized protocol; includes psychoeducation, symptom self-management, coping resource assessment, exposure, cognitive restructuring, relapse prevention, and coping skills training, and exposure homework.
frequency:
Active treatment: weekly

Booster sessions: monthly
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Foy DW, et al. Randomized trial of trauma-focused group therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003 May;60(5):481-9. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.5.481. PMID: 12742869.

treatment_desc: Group therapy following manualized protocol; includes psychoeducation, connection between PTSD symptoms and difficulties in relationships, problem-solving, specific individual issues, development of plans to deal with issues with interaction of group members for input and feedback, review of experience and progress.
frequency:
Active treatment: weekly

Booster sessions: monthly
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Foy DW, et al. Randomized trial of trauma-focused group therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003 May;60(5):481-9. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.5.481. PMID: 12742869.

treatment_desc: Collaborative care delivered by primary care provider and care manager (psychologist). Treatment at primary care provider's discretion and could include mental health specialty referral. Support calls by care managers until trial end or participant met response criteria (30% reduction in PCL, for those with depression also 50% reduction in PHQ-9 score); calls focused on barriers to adherence, helping to overcome barriers, and measuring treatment response.
frequency: Support calls: weeks 1, 4, and 8, then every 4 weeks
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disaster, community/school violence
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Oxman TE, et al. RESPECT-PTSD: re-engineering systems for the primary care treatment of PTSD, a randomized controlled trial. J Gen Intern Med. 2013 Jan;28(1):32-40. doi: 10.1007/s11606-012-2166-6. PMID: 22865017.

treatment_desc: Treatment at primary care provider's discretion and could include referral to a mental health specialist.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disaster, community/school violence
citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Oxman TE, et al. RESPECT-PTSD: re-engineering systems for the primary care treatment of PTSD, a randomized controlled trial. J Gen Intern Med. 2013 Jan;28(1):32-40. doi: 10.1007/s11606-012-2166-6. PMID: 22865017.

treatment_desc: 200 trials of the Dot-Probe test (80% neutral/trauma-related pairs; 20% neutral/neutral pairs); performed at home on a secured website.

treatment_desc: 200 trials of the Dot-Probe test (no neutral/neutral pairs); performed at home on a secured website.

dose: Initiated at 30 mg, titrated to maximum 90 mg

treatment_desc: Placebo

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT plus SSRI; 5 additional sessions of PE augmented with addition of controlled release paroxetine. (Participants randomized after Phase I if SPRINT ≥6 or CGI-S ≥3 after eight 90- to 120-minute individual PE sessions over a 4- to 6-week period).
dose:
Session length: 90 to 120 minutes

Dose: 12.5 to 62.5 mg; titration: flexible dose initiated at 12.5 mg titrated up to maximum dose of 62.5 mg based on efficacy and tolerability
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (exposure to war)
citation: Simon NM, Connor KM, Lang AJ, et al. Paroxetine CR augmentation for posttraumatic stress disorder refractory to prolonged exposure therapy. J Clin Psychiatry. 2008 Mar;69(3):400-5. PMID: 18348595.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT plus placebo; 5 additional sessions of PE augmented with addition of matched pill placebo. (Participants randomized after Phase I if SPRINT ≥6 or CGI-S ≥3 after eight 90- to 120-minute individual PE sessions over a 4- to 6-week period).
dose:
Session length: 90 to 120 minutes

Dose: equivalent to 12.5 to 62.5 mg paroxetine controlled release; titration: flexible dose initiated at 12.5 mg titrated up to maximum dose of 62.5 mg based on efficacy and tolerability
frequency:
Psychotherapy: once every 2 weeks

Placebo: daily
dose_at_study_end_point_mean: 44.8 mg equivalent to paroxetine controlled release
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (exposure to war)

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused therapy; patients taught to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions about their traumatic event and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world; write 2 trauma accounts (at home) including sensory details, thoughts, and feelings associated with the trauma then read the account daily until the next session; additional between-session assignments given after each session.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Lee DJ, et al. A brief exposure-based treatment vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2018 Mar 1;75(3):233-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.4249. PMID: 29344631.

treatment_desc: Patients instructed to write about a specific traumatic event, focusing on details of the event and the thoughts and feelings that occurred during the event, for 30 minutes each session; no assignments between sessions.
def_treatment_completion: received written exposure therapy as randomized
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Lee DJ, et al. A brief exposure-based treatment vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2018 Mar 1;75(3):233-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.4249. PMID: 29344631.

treatment_desc: Core components of present-centered treatment include psychoeducation, peer support, and  peer-facilitated problem solving. No trauma-focused work or clinician instruction in skill development. Weekly home therapy assignments.
trauma_detail: Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (death or trauma to friend or loved one)
citation: Sloan DM, Unger W, Lee DJ, et al. A randomized controlled trial of group cognitive behavioral treatment for veterans diagnosed with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2018b Dec;31(6):886-98. doi: 10.1002/jts.22338. PMID: 30499227.

treatment_desc: Group cognitive-behavioral intervention focused on trauma. Includes in vivo, written, and imaginal exposure, progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive restructuring, and behavioral activation. Between-session practice (homework) emphasized.
trauma_detail: Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (death or trauma to friend or loved one)
citation: Sloan DM, Unger W, Lee DJ, et al. A randomized controlled trial of group cognitive behavioral treatment for veterans diagnosed with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2018b Dec;31(6):886-98. doi: 10.1002/jts.22338. PMID: 30499227.

treatment_desc: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic/distressing experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; in second and third sessions, could write about same or different experience.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, other (witness to murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP. A closer examination of the structured written disclosure procedure. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2004 Apr;72(2):165-75. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.72.2.165. PMID: 15065952.

treatment_desc: Participants instructed to write about how they spent their time without describing any emotion or opinions, in as much detail as possible.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, other (witness to murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP. A closer examination of the structured written disclosure procedure. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2004 Apr;72(2):165-75. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.72.2.165. PMID: 15065952.

treatment_name: Written disclosure focused on emotional expression
treatment_desc: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; participant asked to write about the same experience at each writing session.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

treatment_name: Written disclosure focused on insight and cognitive assimilation
treatment_desc: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic experience of their lives with a focus on what the event has meant to them, how the event changed their lives (both good and bad), and challenge their dissonant thoughts about the event; asked to write about the same experience at each writing session.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

treatment_desc: Participants instructed to write about how they spent their time without describing any emotion or opinions.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

treatment_desc: Procedure following Pennebaker 1997; participants were asked to write about the most traumatic experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; asked to write about the same traumatic experience at each session.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, combat-related, other (witness to a murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Greenberg EM. A test of written emotional disclosure as an intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):299-304. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.02.001. PMID: 21367400.

treatment_desc: Procedure following Pennebaker 1997; participants were asked to write about how they spent their time each day without describing any emotion or opinions.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, combat-related, other (witness to a murder)
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Greenberg EM. A test of written emotional disclosure as an intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):299-304. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.02.001. PMID: 21367400.

treatment_desc: Exposure through writing about the same motor vehicle accident each session. Initial session focused on describing the event in detail and delving into deepest emotions and thoughts at the time of the accident; remaining sessions focused on most distressing part of the event ("hot spot"), and how it had affected participant's life. The therapist read writing instructions and answered questions; participants were left alone in the room for the writing exercise; therapists addressed concerns at the end of the writing exercise, checked that instructions were followed, and instructed participant to allow experiencing of trauma-related memories, images, thoughts, or feelings in between sessions.
session_length: 1 hour (first session), 40 minutes (remaining 4 sessions); writing exercises 30 minutes per session
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Bovin MJ, et al. Written exposure as an intervention for PTSD: a randomized clinical trial with motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2012 Oct;50(10):627-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2012.07.001. PMID: 22863540.

treatment_desc: Participants encouraged to contact project coordinator any time if experiencing problems; contacted prior to followup assessments for reminder and to make sure they had not experienced a substantial increase in PTSD symptom severity. Participants were offered written exposure therapy after the 18-week assessment was completed.
citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Bovin MJ, et al. Written exposure as an intervention for PTSD: a randomized clinical trial with motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2012 Oct;50(10):627-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2012.07.001. PMID: 22863540.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant, initiated at 50 mg, dose increased to 100 mg after 14 days based on tolerability
dose: Initiated at 50 mg, titrated to 100 mg
citation: Smajkic A, Weine SM, Djuric-Bijedic Z, et al. Sertraline, paroxetine, and venlafaxine in refugee posttraumatic stress disorder with depression symptoms. J Trauma. Stress. 2001 Jul;14(3):445-52. doi: 10.1023/A:1011177420069. PMID: 11534876.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant, dose maintained after 14 days if tolerated
dose: 20 mg

treatment_desc: SNRI antidepressant, initiated at 37.5 mg, dose increased to 75 mg after 14 days based on tolerability

treatment_desc: Participants write about traumatic event, it's effect on their thoughts, feelings, and sensations, and the rationality of their negative beliefs

treatment_desc: Participants write about time management and their daily plans

treatment_desc: SSRI with 10 sessions with psychiatrist/medical doctor for drug management and pscyhoeducation, 16 sessions with psychologist using flexible manual-based cognitive therapy with elements of trauma-focused therapy, acceptance commitment therapy, and mindfulness. Group and individual sessions with a social worker offered.
dose:
Session length: NR

Dose: sertraline initiated at 25 to 50 mg/day, titrated weekly by 25 to 50 mg for first 6 weeks, then monthly up to 200 mg/day

treatment_desc: SNRI with 10 sessions with psychiatrist/medical doctor for drug management and pscyho-education, 16 sessions with psychologist using flexible manual-based cognitive therapy with elements of trauma-focused therapy, acceptance commitment therapy, and mindfulness. Group and individual sessions with a social worker offered.
dose:

treatment_desc: Online lessons include in vivo and imaginal exposure, cognitive restructuring, and de-arousal strategies. Also includes an online discussion forum moderated by the therapist and written resources about assertiveness skills, anger management, strategies for improving sleep, diet, exercise, and reducing drug and alcohol use
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
citation: Spence J, Titov N, Dear BF, et al. Randomized controlled trial of internet-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Depress Anxiety. 2011 Jul;28(7):541-50. doi: 10.1002/da.20835. PMID: 21721073.

treatment_desc: Lessons include psychoeducation, stress management, and cognitive restructuring

treatment_desc: Lessons include psychoeducation, stress management, cognitive restructuring, and exposure components
def_treatment_adherence: completing ≥2 session of in vivo exposure, ≥2 sessions of imaginal exposure, or ≥2 sessions each of in vivo exposure and imaginal exposure

dose: 4 mg

treatment_desc: Scripted condition for attention control condition; participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Nutrition guidance as "comparable length interaction with the therapist that involved learning something germane to health but not specifically relevant to either PTSD or problematic alcohol use". Participants learned plate method of nutrition, assessed current eating habits, and how to align diet with recommendations.
frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

treatment_desc: Scripted condition for coping skills training;  participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Participants were taught "how trauma exposure can lead to distorted thoughts and beliefs, which in turn can lead to negative feelings and unhealthy behaviors. They were given “A-B-C” sheets and taught how to identify the antecedent..., beliefs and thoughts, and consequences" and taught 3 questions from skill set in Cognitive Processing Therapy to evaluate accuracy of thought/belief, and guided through use of ABC sheet for a recent drinking or craving episode; participants were to practice at home with ABC sheets.
frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

treatment_desc: Scripted condition for coping skills training;  participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Participants introduced "to the idea that avoiding thoughts and feelings is often associated with more distress and poorer coping. Instead, accepting thoughts and feelings can enable one to make choices consistent with one's values rather than having one's behavior driven by distress or urges to drink.", and to "urge surfing" and mindful breathing meditation; participants identified ways they avoided or tried to change thoughts or feelings and how experiential acceptance concepts could be used.
frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
treatment_desc: CBT-based telephone session to identify and address beliefs about PTSD treatment
citation: Stecker T, McHugo GJ, Xie HY, et al. RCT of a brief phone-based CBT intervention to improve PTSD treatment utilization by returning service members. Psychiatr Serv. 2014 Oct;65(10):1232-7. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201300433. PMID: 24933496.

treatment_desc: Received baseline assessment and followup assessments calls only.
citation: Stecker T, McHugo GJ, Xie HY, et al. RCT of a brief phone-based CBT intervention to improve PTSD treatment utilization by returning service members. Psychiatr Serv. 2014 Oct;65(10):1232-7. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201300433. PMID: 24933496.

treatment_desc: Atypical antipsychotic + previously prescribed SSRI (fluoxetine, paroxetine or sertraline). Olanzapine started at 10 mg daily for 2 weeks, increased to 20 mg daily if needed and tolerated.
dose: 10 to 20 mg; titration: 10 mg for 2 weeks, optional increase to maximum of 20 mg
citation: Stein MB, Kline NA, Matloff JL. Adjunctive olanzapine for SSRI-resistant combat-related PTSD: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2002 Oct;159(10):1777-9. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.159.10.1777. PMID: 12359687.

treatment_desc: Placebo + previously prescribed SSRI. Placebo started at 10 mg equivalent daily for 2 weeks, increased to 20 mg equivalent daily if needed and tolerated.
dose: 10 to 20 mg equivalent; titration: 10 mg daily for 2 weeks, then optional; increase to 20 mg maximum
citation: Stein MB, Kline NA, Matloff JL. Adjunctive olanzapine for SSRI-resistant combat-related PTSD: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2002 Oct;159(10):1777-9. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.159.10.1777. PMID: 12359687.

treatment_name: Resource-oriented trauma therapy combined with EMDR
ncptsd_treatment_name: Resource-oriented trauma therapy combined with Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR)
treatment_desc: Manualized trauma therapy aimed at strengthening resilience and coping capacities. Treatment elements include: psychoeducation; establishing a sense of safety and control; strengthening the adult ego of the patient, and focus on resource activation to enhance emotion regulation; techniques taught to patients include: imaginative techniques to distance from overwhelming traumatic emotions and intrusions; grounding techniques to help manage dissociative crises; and resource development and installation (an EMDR technique).
trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (trafficking)
citation: Steinert C, Bumke PJ, Hollekamp RL, et al. Treating post-traumatic stress disorder by resource activation in Cambodia. World Psychiatry. 2016 Jun;15(2):183-5. doi: 10.1002/wps.20303. PMID: 27265714.

trauma_detail: intimate partner violence, accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (trafficking)
citation: Steinert C, Bumke PJ, Hollekamp RL, et al. Treating post-traumatic stress disorder by resource activation in Cambodia. World Psychiatry. 2016 Jun;15(2):183-5. doi: 10.1002/wps.20303. PMID: 27265714.

treatment_desc: Therapist assists patient construct a chronological narrative of their life stories with emphasis on traumatic experiences. Therapeutic re-exposures to traumatic experiences continue until associated fear responses decline
citation: Stenmark H, Catani C, Neuner F, et al. Treating PTSD in refugees and asylum seekers within the general health care system. A randomized controlled multicenter study. Behav Res Ther. 2013 Oct;51(10):641-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2013.07.002. PMID: 23916633.

treatment_desc: Therapists can use any intervention except for steps specific to NET, such as help with sleep problems, depressive symptoms, problems related to asylum status, etc.
citation: Stenmark H, Catani C, Neuner F, et al. Treating PTSD in refugees and asylum seekers within the general health care system. A randomized controlled multicenter study. Behav Res Ther. 2013 Oct;51(10):641-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2013.07.002. PMID: 23916633.

treatment_desc:
Single dose paired with reactivation of a specific trauma memory.

Sirolimus also known as rapamycin; developed as an antifungal, used as an immunosuppressant; regulates dendritic protein synthesis in the amygdala and dorsal hippocampus through the systemic inhibition of the protein kinase mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) pathway. After administration of sirolimus, participants wrote script describing most distressing combat trauma memory (about 45 minute process), in next session 7 days later, the participant listened to 3 recordings: standard neutral script, followed by personal combat script, then another standard neutral script (scripts approximately 30 to 40 seconds duration).
dose:
Session length (session 2 when drug administered): mean 45 minutes (range 30 to 75)

Dose: 15 mg
citation: Stenmark H, Catani C, Neuner F, et al. Treating PTSD in refugees and asylum seekers within the general health care system. A randomized controlled multicenter study. Behav Res Ther. 2013 Oct;51(10):641-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2013.07.002. PMID: 23916633.

treatment_desc: Placebo. After administration, participants wrote script describing most distressing combat trauma memory (about 45 minute process), in next session 7 days later, the participant listened to 3 recordings: standard neutral script, followed by personal combat script, then another standard neutral script (scripts approximately 30 to 40 seconds duration).
dose:
Session length (session 2 when drug administered): mean 45 minutes (range 30 to 75)

Dose: NA

treatment_desc: CBT designed for treatment of rape-related PTSD, includes education, cognitive restructuring, and writing trauma narratives
citation: Suris A, Link-Malcolm J, Chard K, et al. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive processing therapy for veterans with PTSD related to military sexual trauma. J Trauma Stress. 2013 Feb;26(1):28-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.21765. PMID: 23325750.

treatment_desc: General support, education, problem-solving and improving relationships, daily journaling
citation: Suris A, Link-Malcolm J, Chard K, et al. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive processing therapy for veterans with PTSD related to military sexual trauma. J Trauma Stress. 2013 Feb;26(1):28-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.21765. PMID: 23325750.

treatment_name: Dexamethasone + brief trauma memory reactivation task
treatment_desc: Glucocorticoid paired with brief trauma memory reactivation task; patients in each arm received four treatment sessions, receiving drug or placebo 60 minutes before therapy sessions that included writing a trauma narrative and listening to staff audio recordings of the narrative; audio recordings were 30 to 45 seconds.
dose: 0.15 mg/kg
citation: Suris A, Link-Malcolm J, Chard K, et al. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive processing therapy for veterans with PTSD related to military sexual trauma. J Trauma Stress. 2013 Feb;26(1):28-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.21765. PMID: 23325750.

treatment_name: Placebo + brief trauma memory reactivation task
treatment_desc: Placebo paired with brief trauma memory reactivation task; patients in each arm received four treatment sessions, receiving drug or placebo 60 minutes before therapy sessions that included writing a trauma narrative and listening to staff audio recordings of the narrative; audio recordings were 30 to 45 seconds.
citation: Suris A, Link-Malcolm J, Chard K, et al. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive processing therapy for veterans with PTSD related to military sexual trauma. J Trauma Stress. 2013 Feb;26(1):28-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.21765. PMID: 23325750.

treatment_desc: Patients instructed to write about a specific traumatic event, focusing on details of the event and the thoughts and feelings that occurred during the event, for 30 minutes each session; no assignments between sessions.
citation: Talbot LS, Maguen S, Metzler TJ, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Sleep. 2014 Feb 1;37(3):327-41. doi: 10.5665/sleep.3408. PMID: 24497661.

treatment_desc: Monitored sleep using sleep diary and actigraphy; weekly telephone or email check-ins from study coordinator.
citation: Talbot LS, Maguen S, Metzler TJ, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Sleep. 2014 Feb 1;37(3):327-41. doi: 10.5665/sleep.3408. PMID: 24497661.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused therapy seeking habituation of emotional responses; patient described and visualized event with exposure continuing until emotional reactions decreased; hierarchy of events approaching most intense aspect of trauma could be used
trauma_detail: accidents, other (crime, not specified)
citation: Tarrier N, Pilgrim H, Sommerfield C, et al. A randomized trial of cognitive therapy and imaginal exposure in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999 Feb;67(1):13-8. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.67.1.13. PMID: 10028204.

treatment_desc: Emotion focused therapy eliciting patients' beliefs about the meaning of the traumatic event, and identifying and modifying maladaptive cognitions and emotions; discussion of trauma itself avoided
trauma_detail: accidents, other (crime, not specified)
citation: Tarrier N, Pilgrim H, Sommerfield C, et al. A randomized trial of cognitive therapy and imaginal exposure in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999 Feb;67(1):13-8. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.67.1.13. PMID: 10028204.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Shapiro 1995 protocol, including Safe Place exercise and processing of a traumatic memory by recalling the memory and its associated feature while making lateral eye movements following therapist's finger until distress subsides
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Taylor S, Thordarson DS, Maxfield L, et al. Comparative efficacy, speed, and adverse effects of three PTSD treatments: exposure therapy, EMDR, and relaxation training. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003a Apr;71(2):330-8. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.71.2.330. PMID: 12699027.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Marks et al. 1998 manual, including imaginal and in vivo exposure but does not include breathing retraining as part of Foa 1999 protocol

treatment_desc: Treatment following Marks et al. 1998 protocol, including 3 different relaxation exercises

treatment_desc: Alpha-1 adrenoreceptor antagonist, titrated over 10 days with 1-mg dose increases every 2 to 3 days based on response and tolerability; 3-week crossover periods separated by 1-week washout
dose: Initiated at 1 mg, maximum NR
trauma_detail: child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence

treatment_desc: Placebo capsules indistinguishable from active drug, titrated over 10 days with 1-mg equivalent dose increases every 2 to 3 days based on response and tolerability; 3-week crossover periods separated by 1-week washout
dose: Initiated at 1 mg equivalent, maximum NR

treatment_desc: Included treatment planning and preparing patient for trauma-focused treatment (3 sessions), followed by desensitization and reprocessing (6 sessions), and evaluation; total 12 hours treatment. During desensitization and reprocessing, a focus on a traumatic image and the thoughts, sensations, feelings and memories that it elicits, is combined with an attention-demanding task such as tracking the therapist's fingers with the eyes. Followed Dutch version of EMDR protocol.
session_length:
Treatment planning and preparation sessions: 60 minutes

EMDR sessions: 90 minutes
trauma_detail: terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence
citation: Ter Heide FJJ, Mooren TM, Van de Schoot R, et al. Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing therapy v. stabilisation as usual for refugees: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2016 Oct;209(4):311-8. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.115.167775. PMID: 26892849.

treatment_desc: Phase-oriented treatment in which first phase (stabilization) is aimed at enhancing safety, control over symptoms, and socio-psychological competencies through interventions such as emotion regulation and relational skills building, stress management, and cognitive restructuring; reprocessing of traumatic memories occurs in second phase. Stabilization as usual (not structured) used; 12 hours total treatment.
trauma_detail: terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence
citation: Ter Heide FJJ, Mooren TM, Van de Schoot R, et al. Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing therapy v. stabilisation as usual for refugees: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2016 Oct;209(4):311-8. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.115.167775. PMID: 26892849.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Foa et al. 2007 protocol, including breathing retraining skills, imaginal exposure, and in-vivo exposures
trauma_detail: combat-related, natural or manmade disasters
citation: Thorp S, Glassman LH. A randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure therapy versus relaxation training for older veterans with military-related PTSD. J Anxiety Disord. 2019 May;64:45-54. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2019.02.003. PMID: 30978622.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Taylor et al. 2003 protocol, includes systematic steps to relax through tensing and releasing 16 muscle groups
trauma_detail: combat-related, natural or manmade disasters

treatment_desc: Seeking Safety in group format (2 groups of 10 women each); manualized intervention addressing both trauma and substance abuse, and "designed to promote trauma recovery, increase coping strategies, reduce drug and alcohol use, and address mental health issues such as depression and PTSD that stem from traumatic exposure"; consists of 25 modules covering cognitive-behavioral and interpersonal skills, with group leader tailoring topics to the needs of participants.
citation: Tripodi SJ, Mennicke AM, McCarter SA, et al. Evaluating seeking safety for women in prison: a randomized controlled trial. Res Soc Work Pract. 2019 Mar;29(3):281-90. doi: 10.1177/1049731517706550.

treatment_desc: Treatment-as-usual, available programming included residential substance abuse treatment, psychological services, mindful meditation, group intervention, and anger management.
citation: Tripodi SJ, Mennicke AM, McCarter SA, et al. Evaluating seeking safety for women in prison: a randomized controlled trial. Res Soc Work Pract. 2019 Mar;29(3):281-90. doi: 10.1177/1049731517706550.

treatment_desc: SSRI antidepressant, dose increase of 10 mg/day allowed every 2 weeks based on clinician judgment; one dose reduction allowed for illness or adverse event if taking at least 30 mg/day; randomization followed 1-week placebo run-in, with responders excluded
dose: Initiated at 20 mg, titrated to maximum 50 mg

treatment_desc: Yohimbine HCl: alpha-2 adrenergic receptor antagonist; oral dose given 1 hour prior to first imaginal exposure of PE treatment (session 3). PE: manualized trauma-focused treatment including psychoeducation, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and discussion or processing of traumatic events, with homework focused on imaginal and in vivo exposures; early termination criteria: ≥1.5 standard deviation improvement from baseline on PCL-M, or total PCL-M score <30.
def_treatment_completion: completed the entire course of care
def_treatment_adherence: administered in clinic
citation: Tuerk PW, Wangelin BC, Powers MB, et al. Augmenting treatment efficiency in exposure therapy for PTSD: a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial of yohimbine HCl. Cogn. Behav. Ther. 2018 Sep;47(5):351-71. doi: 10.1080/16506073.2018.1432679. PMID: 29448886.

treatment_desc: Placebo: matching placebo given 1 hour prior to first imaginal exposure of PE treatment (session 3). PE: manualized trauma-focused treatment including psychoeducation, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and discussion or processing of traumatic events, with homework focused on imaginal and in vivo exposures; early termination criteria: ≥1.5 standard deviation improvement from baseline on PCL-M, or total PCL-M score <30.
def_treatment_completion: completed the entire course of care
def_treatment_adherence: administered in clinic

treatment_desc: Brief cognitive intervention targeting the intrusive symptoms of PTSD; procedure includes minimal, nontraumatizing exposure to target trauma, providing dissociative experiences of traumatic memory with structural alterations as needed, design of nontraumatizing versions, and ending when trauma can't be evoked and narrative can be told without significant autonomic arousal. Sessions were separated by ‚â•24 hours.
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (not specified)
citation: Tylee DS, Gray R, Glatt SJ, et al. Evaluation of the reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol for the treatment of PTSD: a randomized, wait-list-controlled trial. J Mil Veteran Fam Health. 2017;3(1):21-33. doi: 10.3138/jmvfh.4120.

treatment_desc: Waitlist with no active contact with research team outside of assessments.
trauma_detail: combat-related, other (not specified)
citation: Tylee DS, Gray R, Glatt SJ, et al. Evaluation of the reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol for the treatment of PTSD: a randomized, wait-list-controlled trial. J Mil Veteran Fam Health. 2017;3(1):21-33. doi: 10.3138/jmvfh.4120.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
treatment_desc: 3 sessions of CBT for insomnia followed by 3 sessions of imagery rehearsal therapy; CBT for insomnia: individually tailored behavioral regimen based on sleep restriction theory, stimulus control, sleep hygiene, and identification and restructuring of dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes regarding sleep; imagery rehearsal therapy: included education about the role of learning in nightmares, visual imagery skill building, and instruction in rescripting nightmares. Participants also used an electronic sleep diary to record subjective sleep symptoms daily (interactive program on hand-held computer).
citation: Ulmer CS, Edinger JD, Calhoun PS. A multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention for sleep disturbance in veterans with PTSD: a pilot study. J Clin Sleep Med. 2011 Feb 15;7(1):57-68.  PMID: 21344046.

treatment_desc: Participants also used an electronic sleep diary to record subjective sleep symptoms daily (interactive program on hand-held computer).
citation: Ulmer CS, Edinger JD, Calhoun PS. A multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention for sleep disturbance in veterans with PTSD: a pilot study. J Clin Sleep Med. 2011 Feb 15;7(1):57-68.  PMID: 21344046.

treatment_desc:
EEG training following flexible, principle-based manual; training intended to teach subjects to alter the power spectrum of specific filtered frequencies of activity; reward indicated with auditory and visual feedback (auditory tones, progress in simple computer games); adjustment of reward frequency based on rated symptoms of over-arousal and under-arousal; training time increased by 3-minute increments when subject reported positive change.

Continuation of all ongoing treatments (psychotherapeutic and pharmacological).
dose:
Dose:
Inhibit frequencies: 2 to 6 Hz, and 22 to 36 Hz
Reward frequency: initial 10 to 13 Hz
trauma_detail: child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, other (not specified)
citation: Van der Kolk BA, Hodgdon HB, Gapen MA, et al. A randomized controlled study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. PLoS One. 2016 Dec 16;11(12):e0166752. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0166752. PMID: 27992435.

treatment_desc: Continuation of all ongoing treatments (psychotherapeutic and pharmacological) during waiting period, received neurofeedback intervention after completing week 12 evaluation
trauma_detail: child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, other (not specified)
citation: Van der Kolk BA, Hodgdon HB, Gapen MA, et al. A randomized controlled study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. PLoS One. 2016 Dec 16;11(12):e0166752. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0166752. PMID: 27992435.

treatment_name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
ncptsd_treatment_name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
treatment_desc: Manualized intervention combining techniques of virtual reality and EMDR. Participant walks on treadmill while viewing synchronized virtual reality environment, personalized for individual participant with images and music, and going through sequence for EMDR. Each session ended wth therapist-led discussion of experiences.
trauma_detail: combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other ("severe human suffering", "death caused to someone else", "explosion or fire")

treatment_desc: Non-trauma-focused treatment delivered by a team with psychiatrist and mental health worker; allowed "case management, medication consults, stabilizing interventions, psychoeducation, systemic interventions and cognitive behavioral therapy without trauma-focused elements such as exposure or cognitive restructuring of distorted cognitions related to traumatic events"

treatment_desc: A psychotherapeutic approach that reduces PTSD symptom-severity by systematically exposing the subject, in both imaginary and in vivo ways, to previously avoided traumatic internal and external stimuli.
def_treatment_completion: NR; early completion defined as PSS-SR ≤10 on two consecutive occasions
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic psychosis, war, physical abuse)

treatment_desc: A psychotherapeutic approach in which memory representations of traumatic life experiences are processed in order to change dysfunctional beliefs about self or others that originated from damaging traumatic experiences.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
treatment_desc: EMDR followed by CBT. Two introductory sessions with psychoeducation and discussion of grief and social support (introductory session content was the same for all interventions); 3 sessions of EMDR with alternating eye movements following standard Dutch EMDR treatment protocol; 3 sessions of CBT focused on identifying, challenging, and changing negative cognitions related to the loss with use of behavioral experiments and cognitive restructuring.

treatment_name: Transcranial direct current stimulation + Virtual reality exposure
ncptsd_treatment_name: Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) + Virtual reality exposure (VRET)
treatment_desc:
Simultaneous transcranial direct current stimulation and virtual reality exposure
Transcranial direct current stimulation: stimulation targeting ventromedial prefrontal cortex using neuroConn DC Stimulator Plus
Virtual reality exposure: "head-mounted display with integrated head tracking and stereo earphones presenting combat-related multisensory information". Each session included driving scenarios with presentation of warzone events.
dose: Dose: 2 mA (transcranial direct current stimulation)
citation: van 't Wout-Frank M, Shea MT, Larson VC, et al. Combined transcranial direct current stimulation with virtual reality exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility and pilot results. Brain Stimul. 2019 Jan - Feb;12(1):41-3. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2018.09.011. PMID: 30266416.

treatment_name: Sham transcranial direct current stimulation + Virtual reality exposure
treatment_desc:
Simultaneous sham transcranial direct current stimulation and virtual reality exposure
Sham transcranial direct current stimulation: sham stimulation using neuroConn DC Stimulator Plus
Virtual reality exposure: "head-mounted display with integrated head tracking and stereo earphones presenting combat-related multisensory information". Each session included driving scenarios with presentation of warzone events.
citation: van 't Wout-Frank M, Shea MT, Larson VC, et al. Combined transcranial direct current stimulation with virtual reality exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility and pilot results. Brain Stimul. 2019 Jan - Feb;12(1):41-3. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2018.09.011. PMID: 30266416.

treatment_desc: Individual therapy delivered following the culturally adapted Spanish version of PE manual; this version includes language, idioms, and examples relevant to Latino culture. An addition, optional introductory session was provided with participants and spouse or partner, giving an overview of PTSD and the goals and methods of PE. PE therapy included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, discussion of exposure and processing of traumatic memories, and homework with imaginal and in vivo exposure.
citation: Vera M, Reyes-Rabanillo ML, Juarbe D, et al. Prolonged exposure for the treatment of Spanish-speaking Puerto Ricans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a feasibility study. BMC Res. Notes. 2011 Oct 17;4:415. doi: 10.1186/1756-0500-4-415. PMID: 22005187.

treatment_desc: Participants referred to mental health provider at the study setting or could self-refer for outside provider; treatment in "most cases" included pharmacologic medication and/or psychotherapy; allowed changes in psychotropic medication.
citation: Vera M, Reyes-Rabanillo ML, Juarbe D, et al. Prolonged exposure for the treatment of Spanish-speaking Puerto Ricans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a feasibility study. BMC Res. Notes. 2011 Oct 17;4:415. doi: 10.1186/1756-0500-4-415. PMID: 22005187.

treatment_desc: Second generation antipsychotic
dose: Target 400 mg, initiated at 25 mg daily, titrate to 400 mg by 2 weeks. Could go up to 800 mg max (50 mg minimum)
citation: Villarreal G, Hamner MB, Ca√±ive JM, et al. Efficacy of quetiapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2016 Dec;173(12):1205-12. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2016.15070967. PMID: 27418378.

treatment_desc: Placebo titrated as per active study drug
citation: Villarreal G, Hamner MB, Ca√±ive JM, et al. Efficacy of quetiapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2016 Dec;173(12):1205-12. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2016.15070967. PMID: 27418378.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Bartell et al. 2001 protocol, including behavioral analyses for assessing avoidance patterns, activity scheduling and monitoring of reactions, present-centered strategies to decrease rumination, and psychoeducation
citation: Wagner AW, Jakupcak M, Kowalski HM, et al. Behavioral activation as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder among returning veterans: a randomized trial. Psychiatr Serv. 2019 Oct 1;70(10):867-73. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201800572. PMID: 31337325.

treatment_desc: Participants were allowed any standard care, including PE, CPT, alternative treatments and coping-skills training (e.g., acceptance and commitment therapy, anger management). All patients were offered ≥6 individual psychotherapy appointments
citation: Wagner AW, Jakupcak M, Kowalski HM, et al. Behavioral activation as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder among returning veterans: a randomized trial. Psychiatr Serv. 2019 Oct 1;70(10):867-73. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201800572. PMID: 31337325.

treatment_desc: Identification and enactment of activities that are reinforcing to individual's long-term goals. Program includes identification of goals and activities, identification of patterns of avoidance that block attainment of these goals, and alternative coping strategies. Psychoeducation modified to include descriptions of PTSD symptoms and emphasize the role of avoidance in PTSD
citation: Wagner AW, Zatzick DF, Ghesquiere A, et al. Behavioral activation as an early intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among physically injured trauma survivors. Cogn Behav Pract. 2007 Nov;14(4):341-9. doi: 10.1016/j.cbpra.2006.05.002.

treatment_desc: Participants offered a list of community referrals
citation: Wagner AW, Zatzick DF, Ghesquiere A, et al. Behavioral activation as an early intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among physically injured trauma survivors. Cogn Behav Pract. 2007 Nov;14(4):341-9. doi: 10.1016/j.cbpra.2006.05.002.

treatment_desc: Body scan mindfulness technique training; at each session the research assistant read a script defining mindfulness, explaining each aspect of the definition and provided examples for how to deepen the skills and their importance to mindfulness practice; training was with an audio recording, performed in silence, stillness and sitting upright; instructed to gently redirect wandering attention back to the body part that was the focus of awareness. Guided meditation did not direct attention to the breath or breathing process. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions using the same recording, and submit weekly logs of practice.
citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

treatment_desc: Used the RESPeRATE breathing biofeedback device designed to reduce respiratory rate.
citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

treatment_desc: Mindfulness training focusing attention on the breath; at each session the research assistant read a script defining mindfulness, explaining each aspect of the definition and provided examples for how to deepen the skills and their importance to mindfulness practice; training was with an audio recording and participants sat upright; attention directed to the breath with conscious observation of breathing, naturally slowing their breath. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions using the same recording, and submit weekly logs of practice.
citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

treatment_desc: Participants sat quietly while listening to a neutral-content audiobook during sessions. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions by sitting quietly alone and engaging in an activity besides watching TV or browsing the internet, asked to submit weekly logs of practice.
citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
treatment_desc:
IRT: manualized therapy for nightmares; did not include exposure to the nightmare
CBT-I: comprised of "psychoeducation on chronic insomnia, sleep restriction, stimulus control, sleep hygiene, stress reduction and relaxation, decatastrophization of consequences through cognitive restructuring, and relapse prevention"
citation: Walters EM, Jenkins MM, Nappi CM, et al. The impact of prolonged exposure on sleep and enhancing treatment outcomes with evidence-based sleep interventions: a pilot study. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Feb;12(2):175-85. doi: 10.1037/tra0000478. PMID: 31246050.

treatment_desc: Nondirective Rogerian therapy, strictly avoided components of IRT and CBT-I. Uses empathetic listening, clarification of goals, and nondirective questioning to help participants "better understand their emotional response to PTSD symptoms and provide supportive, unconditional positive regard to managing their own PTSD symptoms".
citation: Walters EM, Jenkins MM, Nappi CM, et al. The impact of prolonged exposure on sleep and enhancing treatment outcomes with evidence-based sleep interventions: a pilot study. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Feb;12(2):175-85. doi: 10.1037/tra0000478. PMID: 31246050.

treatment_desc: Scalp electroacupuncture on Sishencong, Baihui, Shenting, and Fengchi points using continuous wave of 100 Hz.
dose: 30 minutes
citation: Wang Y, Hu YP, Wang WC, et al. Clinical studies on treatment of earthquake-caused posttraumatic stress disorder using electroacupuncture. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2012;2012:431279. doi: 10.1155/2012/431279. PMID: 23049609.

treatment_desc: SSRI
dose: 20 mg
citation: Wang Y, Hu YP, Wang WC, et al. Clinical studies on treatment of earthquake-caused posttraumatic stress disorder using electroacupuncture. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2012;2012:431279. doi: 10.1155/2012/431279. PMID: 23049609.

treatment_desc: Participants seated in a comfortable reclining chair and instructed to relax as much as possible
citation: Watson CG, Tuorila JR, Vickers KS, et al. The efficacies of three relaxation regimens in the treatment of PTSD in Vietnam War veterans. J Clin Psychol. 1997 Dec;53(8):917-23. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(199712)53:8<917::AID-JCLP17>3.0.CO;2-N. PMID: 9403395.

treatment_name: Relaxation Instruction with deep breathing exercise
treatment_desc: Participants seated in a comfortable reclining chair and instructed to relax and practice deep breathing
citation: Watson CG, Tuorila JR, Vickers KS, et al. The efficacies of three relaxation regimens in the treatment of PTSD in Vietnam War veterans. J Clin Psychol. 1997 Dec;53(8):917-23. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(199712)53:8<917::AID-JCLP17>3.0.CO;2-N. PMID: 9403395.

treatment_name: Relaxation instruction with deep breathing and biofeedback
ncptsd_treatment_name: Relaxation with deep breathing and biofeedback
treatment_desc: Participants seated in a comfortable reclining chair and instructed to relax and practice deep breathing. In addition, a tone indicating level of relaxation by change one tone for every tenth of a degree Fahrenheit was played
citation: Watson CG, Tuorila JR, Vickers KS, et al. The efficacies of three relaxation regimens in the treatment of PTSD in Vietnam War veterans. J Clin Psychol. 1997 Dec;53(8):917-23. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(199712)53:8<917::AID-JCLP17>3.0.CO;2-N. PMID: 9403395.

treatment_desc: Neuronetic 2100 (Neuronetics, LLC, Marietta, GA) used. Before the first session, the right motor threshold was determined by increasing the intensity of stimulation by 2.5% increments over the right motor cortex until there is any movement of the digits of the left hand. For subsequent treatments the coil was placed 4 cm anterior parasagittally and 2 cm laterally of the motor strip location that caused hand movement. This placement approximated the location of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Active rTMS was delivered to the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex at 90% of motor threshold
dose: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
session_length: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (multiple trauma)
citation: Watts BV, Landon B, Groft A, et al. A sham controlled study of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder. Brain Stimul. 2012 Jan;5(1):38-43. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2011.02.002. PMID: 22264669.

treatment_desc: Motor threshold determined by increasing the intensity of stimulation by 2.5% increments over the right motor cortex until left-hand digit movement. Subsequent treatments given using a sham magnetic coil that looks and sounds identical to the active coil, but prevents magnetic energy from leaving the device.
dose: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
session_length: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (multiple trauma)
citation: Watts BV, Landon B, Groft A, et al. A sham controlled study of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder. Brain Stimul. 2012 Jan;5(1):38-43. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2011.02.002. PMID: 22264669.

treatment_desc: Manualized Intervention (Wells, 2009; Wells & Sembi, 2004) intends to modify metacognitive beliefs about rumination, worry, attention, and symptoms, and generate generic plans for coping with threat
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents
citation: Wells A, Colbear JS. Treating posttraumatic stress disorder with metacognitive therapy: a preliminary controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2012 Apr;68(4):373-81. doi: 10.1002/jclp.20871. PMID: 24469928.

trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents
citation: Wells A, Colbear JS. Treating posttraumatic stress disorder with metacognitive therapy: a preliminary controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2012 Apr;68(4):373-81. doi: 10.1002/jclp.20871. PMID: 24469928.

treatment_desc: Manualized intervention according to Wells & Sembi 2004 that teaches participant to postpone worry, rumination, and going over memories in response to trigger thoughts. Intervention also includes attention modification to shift individual out of threat-modes of processing
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (fire)
citation: Wells A, Walton D, Lovell K, et al. Metacognitive therapy versus prolonged exposure in adults with chronic post-traumatic stress disorder. Cognit Ther Res. 2015 February;39(1):70-80. doi: 10.1007/s10608-014-9636-6.

treatment_desc: Trauma-focused CBT according to manual by Marks et al. (1998)
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (fire)
citation: Wells A, Walton D, Lovell K, et al. Metacognitive therapy versus prolonged exposure in adults with chronic post-traumatic stress disorder. Cognit Ther Res. 2015 February;39(1):70-80. doi: 10.1007/s10608-014-9636-6.

trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (fire)
citation: Wells A, Walton D, Lovell K, et al. Metacognitive therapy versus prolonged exposure in adults with chronic post-traumatic stress disorder. Cognit Ther Res. 2015 February;39(1):70-80. doi: 10.1007/s10608-014-9636-6.

treatment_desc: Individual sessions in which "participants learned about various topics unrelated to exercise, trauma, or PTSD (e.g., nutrition, human anatomy, the universe) through videos and handouts."
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (unspecified type of child abuse, unspecified "other")
citation: Whitworth JW, Nosrat S, SantaBarbara NJ, et al. High intensity resistance training improves sleep quality and anxiety in individuals who screen positive for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled feasibility trial. Ment Health Phys Act. 2019b;16:43-9. doi: 10.1016/j.mhpa.2019.04.001.

treatment_desc: Individual resistance training; each session comprised of: "5-min warm up on a stationary bicycle, five resistance training exercises (i.e., squat, bench press, pulldown, overhead press, and biceps curl) done over the course of 20 min, and a 5-min cool down on a stationary bicycle."
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (unspecified type of child abuse, unspecified "other")
citation: Whitworth JW, Nosrat S, SantaBarbara NJ, et al. High intensity resistance training improves sleep quality and anxiety in individuals who screen positive for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled feasibility trial. Ment Health Phys Act. 2019b;16:43-9. doi: 10.1016/j.mhpa.2019.04.001.

treatment_desc: One-on-one sessions of resistance exercise; each 30-minute session included 5 minutes warm up on stationary bicycle, 5 resistance exercises over 20 minutes, and 5 minutes cool down on stationary bicycle, led by certified personal trainer.
cih_subclass: Other physical activity and recreational therapies
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("sudden or unexpected loss of a child or spouse")
citation: Whitworth JW, Nosrat S, SantaBarbara NJ, et al. Feasibility of Resistance Exercise for Posttraumatic Stress and Anxiety Symptoms: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Study. Journal of Traumatic Stress. 2019 Dec;32(6):977-84. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1002/jts.22464. PMID: 31743507.

treatment_desc: One-on-one sessions by same interventionist and same site as for the exercise intervention (Intervention A); sessions included videos on educational topics, excluding exercise and mental health.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("sudden or unexpected loss of a child or spouse")
citation: Whitworth JW, Nosrat S, SantaBarbara NJ, et al. Feasibility of Resistance Exercise for Posttraumatic Stress and Anxiety Symptoms: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Study. Journal of Traumatic Stress. 2019 Dec;32(6):977-84. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.1002/jts.22464. PMID: 31743507.

treatment_desc: Initiated at 25 mg/day, increased weekly by 25 mg/day up to 200 mg/day
dose: 25 to 200 mg
def_treatment_adherence: compliance monitored by pill count
citation: Yeh MS, Mari JJ, Costa MC, et al. A double-blind randomized controlled trial to study the efficacy of topiramate in a civilian sample of PTSD. CNS Neurosci Ther. 2011 Oct;17(5):305-10. doi: 10.1111/j.1755-5949.2010.00188.x. PMID: 21554564.

treatment_desc: Placebo
citation: Yeh MS, Mari JJ, Costa MC, et al. A double-blind randomized controlled trial to study the efficacy of topiramate in a civilian sample of PTSD. CNS Neurosci Ther. 2011 Oct;17(5):305-10. doi: 10.1111/j.1755-5949.2010.00188.x. PMID: 21554564.

treatment_desc: Administered according to manualized protocol (Foa et al, 2007); includes education about reactions to trauma, breathing retraining, exposure to trauma memories and situation the patient avoids, and discussion of thoughts and feelings related to exposure exercises.
def_treatment_completion: completed, did not choose to discontinue treatment
citation: Yehuda R, Pratchett LC, Elmes MW, et al. Glucocorticoid-related predictors and correlates of post-traumatic stress disorder treatment response in combat veterans. Interface Focus. 2014 Oct 6;4(5):20140048. doi: 10.1098/rsfs.2014.0048. PMID: 25285201.

treatment_desc: Delivered according to manualized protocol developed by Foa et al. 2007; phone calls by study therapist to the patient to monitor symptoms
citation: Yehuda R, Pratchett LC, Elmes MW, et al. Glucocorticoid-related predictors and correlates of post-traumatic stress disorder treatment response in combat veterans. Interface Focus. 2014 Oct 6;4(5):20140048. doi: 10.1098/rsfs.2014.0048. PMID: 25285201.

treatment_desc: Synthetic glucocorticoid with anti-inflammatory effects administered 20 minutes prior to PE sessions 3 to 10 + manualized PE consisting of guided imaginal exposure.
dose:
Session length: NR

treatment_desc: Home-based telehealth PE by videoconferencing; main components of PE included psychoeducation, situational (in vivo) exposure, and imaginal exposure followed by processing of imaginal recounting experience. Number of sessions (8 to 12) determined on a case-by-case basis, mutually agreed upon by participant and therapist.
def_treatment_completion: variable number of sessions agreed upon with therapist
citation: Yuen EK, Gros DF, Price M, et al. Randomized controlled trial of home-based telehealth versus in-person prolonged exposure for combat-related PTSD in veterans: preliminary results. J Clin Psychol. 2015 Jun;71(6):500-12. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22168. PMID: 25809565.

treatment_desc: In-person PE; main components of PE included psychoeducation, situational (in vivo) exposure, and imaginal exposure followed by processing of imaginal recounting experience. Number of sessions (8 to 12) determined on a case-by-case basis, mutually agreed upon by participant and therapist.
citation: Yuen EK, Gros DF, Price M, et al. Randomized controlled trial of home-based telehealth versus in-person prolonged exposure for combat-related PTSD in veterans: preliminary results. J Clin Psychol. 2015 Jun;71(6):500-12. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22168. PMID: 25809565.

treatment_desc: Manualized intervention (Shapiro 2013) based on Recent Traumatic Episode Protocol (Shapiro and Laub, 2008) that includes procedures and measures for containment and safety
citation: Yurtsever A, Konuk E, Akyüz T, et al. An Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) group intervention for Syrian refugees with post-traumatic stress symptoms: results of a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychol. 2018 Jun 12;9:493. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2018.00493. PMID: 29946275.

Yurtsever A, Konuk E, Akyüz T, et al. An Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) group intervention for Syrian refugees with post-traumatic stress symptoms: results of a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychol. 2018 Jun 12;9:493. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2018.00493. PMID: 29946275.

treatment_desc: Device emitting LED green light (~500 nm, 500 lux)
def_treatment_adherence: days initiated treatment
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Zalta AK, Bravo K, Valdespino‐Hayden Z, et al. A placebo‐controlled pilot study of a wearable morning bright light treatment for probable PTSD. Depress Anxiety. 2019 Jul;36(7):617-24. doi: 10.1002/da.22897. PMID: 30995350.

treatment_desc: Same device with additional filter that reduces light intensity to a level that will not shift circadian timing (7 lux)
def_treatment_adherence: days initiated treatment
trauma_detail: combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
citation: Zalta AK, Bravo K, Valdespino‐Hayden Z, et al. A placebo‐controlled pilot study of a wearable morning bright light treatment for probable PTSD. Depress Anxiety. 2019 Jul;36(7):617-24. doi: 10.1002/da.22897. PMID: 30995350.

treatment_desc: Treatment following Schauer et al. 2005 manual, includes patient constructing a detailed chronological report of his/her own biography with a special focus on traumatic experiences and encouraged to relive emotions.
citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. A randomised controlled pilot study: the effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with adult survivors of the Sichuan earthquake. BMC Psychiatry. 2013 Jan 31;13:41. doi: 10.1186/1471-244X-13-41. PMID: 23363689.

Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. A randomised controlled pilot study: the effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with adult survivors of the Sichuan earthquake. BMC Psychiatry. 2013 Jan 31;13:41. doi: 10.1186/1471-244X-13-41. PMID: 23363689.

treatment_desc: Standard Narrative Exposure Therapy; patients constructed detailed autobiography with special focus on traumatic experiences; encouraged to relive emotions while reporting events; received written report of narrative
def_treatment_completion: completed entire course of treatment and followup
citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

treatment_desc: Revised Narrative Exposure Therapy adapted to a single traumatic event; patient first constructed detailed earthquake narrative, then completed chronologic autobiography; encouraged to relive emotions while reporting events; final reading of autobiography without written report
def_treatment_completion: completed entire course of treatment and followup
citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

treatment_desc: Received NET-Revised after 3-week waiting period; assessed at 2 weeks after trial entry, comparable to post-treatment assessment for immediate treatment groups (T2)
citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

treatment_desc:
Seeking safety: group modality (3 to 5 women per group) while in prison, with optional individual "booster" sessions upon release from prison; "primary goals of SS are psychoeducation and the development of coping skills to help clients attain safety from both PTSD and SUD; it is present-focused, abstinence-oriented, and emphasizes an empowering, compassionate approach."
TAU: abstinence-oriented residential substance use treatment program following 12-step model in "psychoeducation large-group format, with weekly individual case management and drug counseling"; participants required to attend all components of TAU treatment to remain in program.
session_length: Seeking Safety group sessions: 90 minutes; Seeking Safety individual sessions: 60 minutes; TAU: NR (total 30 hours per week)
frequency: Seeking Safety group sessions: three times a week; Seeking Safety individual sessions: weekly; TAU: NR (total 30 hours per week)
treatment_duration_qual: Seeking Safety group sessions: 6 to 8 plus; Seeking Safety individual sessions: 12 weekly sessions offered for all participants in the SS group after group sessions ended; TAU: 12
psychotherapy_sessions_qual: Seeking Safety group sessions: 15.6 (6.2); Seeking Safety individual sessions: 3.3 (3.8)
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
citation: Zlotnick C, Johnson JE, Najavits LM. Randomized controlled pilot study of cognitive-behavioral therapy in a sample of incarcerated women with substance use disorder and PTSD. Behav Ther. 2009 Dec;40(4):325-36. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.09.004. PMID: 19892078.

ncptsd_treatment_name: Treatment as usual (TAU) for substance use
treatment_desc: Abstinence-oriented residential substance use treatment program following 12-step model in "psychoeducation large-group format, with weekly individual case management and drug counseling"; participants required to attend all components of TAU treatment to remain in program.
trauma_detail: rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
citation: Zlotnick C, Johnson JE, Najavits LM. Randomized controlled pilot study of cognitive-behavioral therapy in a sample of incarcerated women with substance use disorder and PTSD. Behav Ther. 2009 Dec;40(4):325-36. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.09.004. PMID: 19892078.

treatment_desc: Intervention based on Linehan's Dialectical Behavior Therapy (Linehan, 1993) and Matsakis's Treatment Guide for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (Matsakis, 1994). Intervention includes psychoeducation, skill building, and application skills. Materials covered include dissociation, flashbacks, "safe" sleep, identification of emotions, crisis planning, anger management, techniques for distraction, self-soothing, distress tolerance, and relaxation. Participants also received individual psychotherapy with medication management.
citation: Zlotnick C, Shea MT, Rosen KH, et al. An affect-management group for women with posttraumatic stress disorder and histories of childhood sexual abuse. J Trauma Stress. 1997 Jul;10(3):425-36. doi: 10.1023/A:1024841321156. PMID: 9246650.

treatment_desc: Participants continued to receive individual psychotherapy with medication management
citation: Zlotnick C, Shea MT, Rosen KH, et al. An affect-management group for women with posttraumatic stress disorder and histories of childhood sexual abuse. J Trauma Stress. 1997 Jul;10(3):425-36. doi: 10.1023/A:1024841321156. PMID: 9246650.

treatment_desc: Biofeedback training using portable StressEraser device (Helicor, New York) which non-invasively measures respiratory sinus arrhythmia of heart rate oscillations; optimal heart rate rhythm achieved at about 6 breaths-per-minute.

treatment_desc: Recorded progressive muscle relaxation exercise instruction derived from Putting Your Worries on a Shelf (Linehan, 2005).
